The hunt is an in-game mechanic intended to complicate further investigation of a location by the player(s). During hunts, the ghost will materialize itself and proceed to roam around the location in order to kill one or more players. For the duration of the hunt, all exit doors will become locked and the ghost will cause all nearby lights and electronic equipment to malfunction. A cursed hunt is a variant of a hunt caused by cursed possessions. Mechanic-wise, cursed hunts are mostly similar to regular hunts. ==Initiating a hunt== ===Standard protections=== Hunts cannot occur while the setup phase is ongoing. The duration of the setup phase by difficulty is as follows: {| class="article-table" !Difficulty !Duration of setup phase |- |Amateur |5 minutes |- |Intermediate |2 minutes |- |Professional
Nightmare
Insanity |No setup phase |} The setup phase can be ended early if a cursed possession is used or activated. Once a hunt ends, there is a minimum cooldown of 25 seconds (20 seconds for a Demon) before the ghost can attempt to initiate another hunt. This does not affect the activation of cursed hunts. Ghosts do not necessarily hunt immediately once this cooldown is over. ===Regular hunt requirements=== At least one player must be within the investigation area for a hunt to begin. All ghosts have a sanity hunt threshold below which they will be able to hunt, and some ghosts may have abilities which may modify the threshold, or even override it entirely. Using "trigger words" or swearing does not increase the chance of a hunt. ====Hunt sanity thresholds==== For most ghosts, the average team sanity is used to determine whether the ghost can hunt. The average sanity is of all players who are alive, regardless of whether they are inside or outside the investigation area. Dead players do not count towards the average team sanity. For most ghosts, the hunt sanity threshold is 50%; ghosts can choose to initiate hunts at random once the average sanity is at or below 50%. Generally, a lower average sanity increases the frequency of hunts, but other factors may affect this. The following table lists the hunt sanity thresholds and abilities for all ghosts: {| class="article-table" style="margin: auto;" !Ghost !Condition !Hunt sanity threshold
(if non-standard) (%) !Non-threshold based ability/
additional notes |- |Banshee |Always |Standard |Only checks target's sanity |- | rowspan="2" |Dayan |When a nearby player is moving |65 | |- |When a nearby player is still |45 | |- | rowspan="2" |Demon |On ability phase activation |N/A |Hunts regardless of sanity
Can use its ability during the setup phase, but it will not hunt. |- |Always |70 | |- |Deogen |Always |40 | |- | rowspan="2" |Gallu |In "enraged" state |60 | |- |In "weakened" state |40 | |- | rowspan="2" |Mare |Lights turned off or broken at ghost's current room |60 | |- |Lights turned on at ghost's current room |40 |Regardless of fuse box status |- | rowspan="2"|Obambo |In "aggressive" state |65 | |- |In "calm" state |10 | |- | rowspan="3" |Onryo |Every third flame blown out and no other flame nearby |N/A |Hunts regardless of sanity |- |Always |60 | |- |Near a flame |40 | |- |Raiju |In the presence of active electronic equipment |65 | |- | rowspan="2" |Shade |Always |35 | |- |At least one player in ghost's current room |N/A |Does not hunt regardless of sanity |- | rowspan="3" |Thaye |Initial threshold (Age 0) |75 | |- |Modifier per age added (Age +1) | -6 | |- |Final threshold (Age 10) |15 | |- |The Mimic | colspan="3" |Inherits hunt thresholds & abilities of currently-mimicked ghost |- |Yokai |At least one player uses voice chat nearby |80 | |- |All other ghosts/
standard |Always |50 | |} ===Cursed hunts=== Cursed hunts can only be initiated directly by using cursed possessions. Cursed hunts ignore sanity thresholds and hunt cooldowns; they can start right after a normal hunt, but normal hunts respect the cooldown after cursed hunts. Cancelled cursed hunts (due to empty locations) don't count toward the cooldown timer. ===Activity=== During hunts, the activity monitor shows level 10. However, activity level doesn't indicate hunting probability, and level 10 readings don't always mean a hunt is occurring. ===Preventing a hunt=== Hunt prevention equipment: *Crucifix: Stops hunts if ghost is within range when attempting to hunt. Ghost must wait 25 seconds (20 for Demon) before trying again. Tier I prevents 1 hunt; Tiers II and III prevent 2 hunts. *Fire sources: A lit fire source, such as a firelight or a campfire, within 4 meters of an Onryo prevents hunting, but the Onryo can blow out flames, potentially triggering a hunt regardless of sanity. *Incense: Prevents hunt initiation for varying durations when lit within 3-5 meters (tier-dependent) of the ghost: **Demon: 60 seconds **Spirit: 180 seconds **All other ghosts: 90 seconds *Monkey Paw: "I wish to trap the ghost" prevents hunting for 1 minute but triggers a guaranteed hunt immediately afterward. Cursed hunts can only be prevented by a tier III crucifix with two charges remaining. Incense blinds ghosts during cursed hunts but won't prevent them. ==Start of a hunt== Each hunt consists of a grace period (not to be confused with the cooldown between hunts) and the actual hunting phase. During the grace period, the ghost will remain invisible and still for a number of seconds, giving players a chance to escape before it begins chasing them. All exit doors lock at the beginning of the grace period, preventing players from entering or exiting the investigation area. The duration of this grace period depends on difficulty or the type of the hunt: *Amateur: 5 seconds *Intermediate: 4 seconds *Professional: 3 seconds *Nightmare: 2 seconds *Insanity: 2 seconds *Cursed hunt: 1 second *Custom: 0 - 5 seconds The ghost cannot detect or see players during this grace period. Subsequent hunts after a cursed hunt, where not activated by a cursed possession again, are not "true" cursed hunts and hence revert to the difficulty-based grace period. The duration of a hunt depends on the difficulty and the map size. These are as follows, excluding the grace period: {| class="article-table" style="margin: auto;" ! rowspan="2" |Difficulty ! colspan="3" style="text-align:center;" |Duration of hunt |- !Small map !Medium map !Large map |- |Amateur
Hunt duration: Low |15 seconds |30 seconds |40 seconds |- |Intermediate
Hunt duration: Medium |20 seconds |40 seconds |50 seconds |- |Professional
Nightmare
Insanity
Hunt duration: High |30 seconds |50 seconds |1 minute |}
After a cursed hunt is initiated, all subsequent hunts in the same contract, whether regular or cursed, including the ongoing cursed hunt, will last 20 seconds longer than the original duration. The hunt duration is the same for all ghosts. If the Kills extend hunts setting is not off, each successful kill will extend the current hunt duration: {| class="article-table" style="margin: auto;" ! rowspan="2" |Difficulty ! colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|Added duration |- !Small map !Medium map !Large map |- |Nightmare
Insanity
Kills extend hunts: Low |15 seconds |20 seconds |25 seconds |- |Kills extend hunts: Medium |25 seconds |30 seconds |35 seconds |- |Kills extend hunts: High |35 seconds |40 seconds |45 seconds |}
Using the Monkey Paw's "I wish to leave" wish will unlock all exit doors even during a hunt, but with temporary side effects. Hunts always initiate from wherever the ghost is standing (except for The Twins in specific cases); it does not have to start from any specific room. Once the grace period begins, an EMF 4 signal will be emitted at the point where the ghost is standing. ==Ghost movement== Once the grace period ends, the ghost will proceed to either wander in a random direction, or chase a player. Ghosts cannot teleport during hunts. Within the investigation area, the ghost is able to access practically all places that players can access. It may also phase through certain furniture such as doors, some beds, and some clutter. The ghost cannot physically enter closets, lockers and mini tents, though it can stand in front of (and appear to be partially inside) one. ===Wandering=== In a "wandering" (or "roaming") phase where the ghost is not aware of any player, the ghost randomly selects a waypoint on the map, moves to that waypoint, then repeats. The ghost always attempts to take the shortest path to its waypoint. ===Chasing phase=== If the ghost detects a player, its "wandering" phase will be disrupted and it will enter a "chasing" phase, setting a waypoint at the player's last known location. If it reaches the waypoint, it will repeat this action until it is unable to detect any player, upon which it will search in the immediate vicinity, before returning to its "wandering" phase. If multiple players are detected at the same time (such as a Deogen which immediately detects all players after the grace period ends), it will set a waypoint at the nearest player by straight-line distance. The following actions attract the ghost: ;Being seen by the ghost *Each player has a total of 6 tracking points, split into 2 groups of 3, each on the upper and lower parts of the hitbox. This is anchored to the player's current point-of-view. The ghost is considered to be able to see the player, or achieving line-of-sight (LoS), if it can see all 3 points of one group (e.g. seeing 2 upper group points and 2 lower group points does not count). The placement of these tracking points means that having the head poke through a closed closet will not allow the ghost to see non-VR players, but VR players could possibly be seen, since they are actually looking through the closet. *The ghost has a 360-degree vision. *The ghost can see players up to 75 meters away. *Each ghost model has the same "head" height. If the ghost is a crawling model, LoS will still be achieved as if the ghost was standing. *Most physical objects or structures, except throwable objects, will block LoS. This includes glass windows and doors, and cell walls and doors in Prison. ;Voice communications *During a hunt, ghosts can hear players up to 9 meters away on the same floor. *Whether the ghost can hear the player is dictated by their voice chat settings. When voice chat is activated, any sound above a certain volume, whether from the player talking or background noise, will attract the ghost within the specified distance. *Using global chat within 9 meters of the ghost, even without talking, will attract it to the player using it. This does not attract the ghost to other players; players outside the investigation area using global chat will not cause players inside to die. ;Active electronic equipment *The ghost will be attracted by any active electronic equipment held by players in their hand, placed on the VR toolbelt, or being worn on their head, within 7.5 meters of it on the same floor during a hunt. Items that do not make any noise such as flashlights or thermometers will still attract the ghost. Regular flashlights (but not UV flashlights) that are swapped into the inventory but still turned on will also attract the ghost. *Equipment dropped on the floor or offhand, as well as deactivated Head Gear that is still being worn, do not attract the ghost. *The player model always has a default, short shoulder flashlight (different from the ones collected from the truck wall). This small flashlight is always turned on and does not attract the ghost. For comparison, the normal electronic interference range is 10 meters. Voice communication and electronic detection are similar in terms of detection priority. If the ghost is considered to be on a different floor from the player, the ghost can only detect the player through LoS. Otherwise, the ghost will not be able to detect the player through other methods. The following do not attract the ghost: *Footsteps; *Door, closet and locker noises; *Electronics on the floor, even when turned on; *Electronics that are held and turned off; *Crucifixes; *Lit incense; *Firelights and glowsticks, even when lit; *Players outside the investigation area (except Deogen in some cases). ====Special detection cases==== =====Waypoint memory between hunts===== During the hunt, the ghost will remember the last seen location of a player before the hunt ended. When a new hunt starts, the ghost first has a 50% chance to set a waypoint at this location. This may include the location of a player it killed. If there is no such instance or otherwise, the ghost will "forget" this location and proceed with either regular wandering or chasing. *This is not relevant when the ghost is not hunting; the ghost does not remember player locations outside of a hunt. It is theoretically safe to hide in a closet or locker indefinitely if the doors remain closed and the player avoids being seen, since ghosts cannot walk into them. *The ghost can only remember one waypoint per hunt; the same waypoint does not carry across multiple hunts. =====Detection in hiding spots with doors===== If the player is detected in a closet, locker, or small tent, the ghost will set a waypoint just outside that location, then force open the door(s) of that hiding spot when it arrives, overriding the player holding the door if applicable. This usually results in death unless the player is standing in such a way that delays LoS from being achieved, and they can close the closet door again fast enough. =====Hiding behind opened room doors===== If there is an opened room door in the ghost's interaction range, it will check if there are players nearby. If this is true, it will roam to the player's location and forcefully close the door, similar to how ghosts open closet/locker doors if a player is detected inside. =====Smudging===== If the ghost is within range of a burning Incense, regardless of who is holding the Incense, and is successfully "pinged", the ghost will be unable to detect or kill players for 5 seconds, causing it to enter the "wandering" phase. When the effect ends, it will be able to detect and kill players again, resuming its normal hunting behaviour. The Incense technically does not "repel" the ghost away from the player, only that it will randomly set a new waypoint which may or may not be in the same direction as the player. =====Monkey Paw===== Using the Monkey Paw's "I wish to be safe" will enable the ghost to detect the wisher's voice and electronics from infinite range (including from different floors) for the rest of the contract. =====Ghost-specific detection behaviours===== Some ghosts have different behaviours in terms of detecting players during hunts: *If the Banshee's target is currently within the investigation area, it cannot detect nor kill non-targets. *The Deogen always has LoS with all players, meaning it always knows everyone's location. *Blinding the Moroi using Incense is effective for 50% longer. *The Yokai can only detect voices and electronics within 2.5 meters of it, instead of the respective 9 and 7.5 metres. ===Ghost speeds=== The speeds listed below assume a default Ghost speed (%) setting of 100. The speeds will scale accordingly if this setting is changed. Most ghosts move at a base speed of 1.7 m/s. If a ghost maintains active line-of-sight (LoS) with a player it is chasing, its speed will gradually increase at a rate of 0.05 times its base speed per second, taking up to 13 seconds to reach the cap of 1.65 times its base speed. If it loses detection of a player, it will maintain the speed until it gives up its "immediate area search", thereafter slowly decreasing its speed at 0.01 times its base speed per second. This takes 65 seconds to return to base speed if from maximum speed. Ghosts do not carry over their speed across hunts. The following ghosts obey LoS, but have additional modifiers that may or may not conditionally override it: *The Dayan moves at a fixed speed of 2.25 m/s (overriding LoS acceleration) if a player is moving within 10 metres, or at a fixed speed of 1.2 m/s (also overriding LoS acceleration) if the player is standing still within 10 metres. It obeys normal ghost speeds if there is no player within 10 metres. *The Jinn moves at a fixed speed of 2.5 m/s (overriding LoS acceleration) if it has LoS with a player, that player is further than 3 meters away, and the fuse box is on. It obeys normal ghost speeds if any of these conditions are not met. *The Raiju moves at a fixed speed of 2.5 m/s (overriding LoS acceleration) if it is within a certain distance of any active electronic equipment. It obeys normal speeds outside of the radius. The following ghosts ignore standard LoS speed rules: *The Deogen moves slower the shorter its pathing distance is to the player; its speed ranges from 0.4 m/s (within 2.5 meters of the player) to 3 m/s (further than 6 meters). If it is not chasing anyone (e.g. when smudged), it stays at its previous speed, or 1.6 m/s if its previous speed was higher than 3 m/s. *The Hantu's speed increases the lower the room temperature is, going from a minimum of 1.4 m/s to a maximum of 2.7 m/s. *The Revenant moves at 1 m/s if it has not detected any player. If it detects a player, it will move at 3 m/s until it reaches the last known position of the player, before decelerating at a rate of 0.75 m/s² (for ~2.7 s) back to 1 m/s. *The Thaye's speed is fixed at 2.75 m/s initially. Every time it ages, this speed decreases by 0.175 m/s; it will reach 1 m/s once it has aged completely. Additionally, if the weather is Blood Moon, the ghost's speed is increased by 15%. For comparison, the player walks at 1.6 m/s and can sprint at 3 m/s for 3 seconds with a 5-second cooldown, resulting in an average speed of 2.125 m/s if continuously sprinting off-cooldown. ==Interacting with objects== Ghosts are able to perform interactions during hunts. There are similarities and differences from non-hunt interactions: *All ghosts have a 50% chance (100% chance for Poltergeist) of throwing one object near them (within their interaction range) every 0.5 seconds during hunts, 4 seconds after the beginning of the hunt. *Ghosts can interact with all types of doors, except exit doors and other types of furniture doors. If a ghost with the Ultraviolet evidence interacts with a door, it will leave the evidence accordingly. **If the player is holding a normal or closet door, the ghost cannot override it unless it detects the player as defined above. It can still leave an EMF signal and Ultraviolet (if applicable) if it cannot override the door. **Ghosts cannot randomly interact with small tent (hiding) doors but will do so if a player is detected in the small tent. *The ghost can blow out firelights within 5 meters during a hunt, though this is technically not a true interaction. Most other objects cannot be interacted with by the ghost during a hunt. ==Other hunt-related behaviour== During hunts, the ghost will always produce footsteps and one specific vocalization that is used for all hunts in that contract. The interval between footsteps depends on the moving speed of the ghost. Without adjusting for volume fall-off, the maximum distance a player can hear ghost footsteps and vocalizations during a hunt is 20 meters (12 meters for Myling). If the player(s) and the ghost are located on different floors during the hunt, there will be no electronic interference and the ghost's footsteps and vocalizations will be greatly muffled, though the range is still the same. Sound occlusion and electronic interference does not account for physics; a ghost going up a staircase may sound muffled and not cause electronic interference on the upper floor until it reaches the top, for example. Within 10 meters of the ghost (15 meters for Raiju), all active electronic equipment and map lights, as well as global chat, will malfunction and/or flicker rapidly. Players can hear their own heartbeat if the ghost is within 10 meters, and there are no walls, floors, or doors between the ghost and the player, and the closer the ghost is to the player, the louder the heartbeats. Most, if not all pieces of furniture do not prevent heartbeats even when the ghost technically does not have line-of-sight with the player. During a hunt, the ghost will flicker or flash in and out of existence. The first flicker-in occurs immediately when the grace period ends. The following shows the flickering rates of various ghosts: {| class="fandom-table" !Ghost !Visibility length (s) !Invisibility length (s) !Total per-flicker length (s) !Average visibility compared to standard ghost |- |Standard |0.08 - 0.30 |0.10 - 0.92 |0.30 - 1.00 |N/A |- |Deogen* |0.20 - 0.30 |0.01? - 0.40 |0.30 - 0.60 |More visible/less invisible |- |Oni* |0.02? - 0.50 |0.01? - 0.50? |0.30? - 1.00? |More visible/less invisible |- |Phantom |0.08 - 0.30 |0.70 - 1.92 |1.00 - 2.00 |More invisible/less visible |}*Note: values for Deogen and Oni are measured values and may not be accurate.
The total per-flicker length refers to the time between two consecutive flicker-ins, i.e. the total duration of 1 set of the ghost being visible and then invisible, in that order. The visibility length and invisibility length added together will not exceed the total per-flicker length. For example, if a normal ghost has a visibility length of 0.30 seconds in 1 set, the invisibility length in that same set will not exceed 0.70 seconds (the total not exceeding 1 second). In addition, the Obake occasionally shapeshifts into a different ghost model on one flicker-in, before returning to its normal model on the following flicker-in. Timed correctly, one can obtain Ghost photos during a hunt while the ghost flashes visible. The hunt also allows for Hunting Ghost videos and sounds to be obtained. ==Dying== For the ghost to kill a player, their "collision boxes" must intersect, and line-of-sight must be achieved. When the ghost kills a player, the player will drop all of their equipment and grotesque hands will appear on their screen before they are teleported into an otherworldly room alone with the ghost. The dead player will then return to their location with their entire screen covered in bright fog. From another player's perspective, the victim drops their equipment and reaches for their neck as they're being strangled by an invisible force, before dropping dead. One dead player chosen at random can be revived if a tarot card labeled The High Priestess is drawn or if the Monkey Paw's "I wish for life" wish is used with a 50% chance of killing the wishing player. If all players die, the contract will end. ==End of a hunt== A hunt ends when the ghost successfully kills a player (when Kills extend hunts is off), the ghost's hunting time is up, or there are no alive players within the investigation area for any reason, including if every player is killed, if every player glitches out at the start of a hunt/during a hunt, or if the exit doors are unlocked with the Monkey Paw's "I wish to leave" wish and every player exits during a hunt. When the hunt ends, the ghost will disappear and be teleported back to its ghost room, the exit door can be unlocked again, all on-site lights will turn off and can once again be toggled. ==Related difficulty settings== *Ghost speed (%): How quickly the ghost moves *Friendly ghost: The ghost will never hunt. Turning this setting on will result in zero rewards *Grace period (s): The duration before the ghost can kill you at the start of a hunt *Hunt duration (s): The duration the ghost will hunt for *Kills extend hunts (s): The time added to the hunt duration when killing a player *Setup time (s): How long before the ghost can start a hunt ==Trivia== *Hunts do not count toward witnessing a ghost event. *The number of hunts during a given game will appear on the resume screen in the lobby. *It is possible for a hunt to start without any players inside the investigation area; when a player stands perfectly in an exit doorway, it's possible for a hunt to start, as the game thinks they are inside the investigation area, but with the player getting pushed outwards and out of the investigation area when the doorway is blocked. If this happens, the hunt will immediately end. ==See also== *Guides/Surviving a hunt *Guides/Identifying ghosts *Guides/Common misconceptions ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- ! rowspan="2" |2 February 2020 |Doubled the hunt duration. |- |Ghosts now have a higher chance of teleporting if it cannot find players while hunting. |- ! rowspan="2" |5 March 2020 |Global chat is now unusable during hunts. |- |Ghosts will now flash in and out during hunts. |- !10 March 2020 |Ghosts will no longer teleport while hunting on smaller maps. |- ! 19 March 2020 |Added a grace period of 3 seconds to the start of the hunt. |- !23 March 2020

Incense is a purchasable item that can be used to temporarily deter the ghost from hunting or blind the ghost during a hunt when ignited. ==Usage== To light incense, have an igniter in the inventory, hold the incense, then press the key. Incense thrown on the ground can also be lit by aiming at it while holding an igniter or firelight, then pressing . Once lit, the incense will emit smoke for a certain amount of time depending on the tier level: *Tier I: 5 seconds *Tier II: 6 seconds *Tier III: 7 seconds While burning, the incense attempts multiple times per second to successfully apply its effect(s), but can only apply the effect(s) once. When the incense is used up, the smoke will stop being emitted and the model will finish burning to a stub. There is no explicit indication of whether the incense was used effectively or not. Used incense can still be handheld, but since there's nothing to use, it is normally discarded. ===Effects=== The incense has a range in which the ghost must be for its effects to be successfully applied. This range depends on the tier level: *Tier I: 3 metres *Tier II: 4 metres *Tier III: 5 metres ====Regular "cleansing"==== When the ghost is within the incense's range while it is burning, the following will occur: *Ghost activity will be increased marginally *The ghost will be unable to initiate a hunt on its own for a certain duration: **Demon: 60 seconds **Spirit: 180 seconds **All other ghosts: 90 seconds *If the ghost is a Gallu, it will switch to its "enraged" state if it was in a "normal" state, or to its "normal" state if it was in a "weakened" state. *If the ghost is a Yurei, it will also return to its favorite room and cannot roam out for 90 seconds. This will not prevent ghost events from happening outside the room. Lighting incense will not prevent cursed hunts nor stop an already ongoing hunt, but doing this during a hunt will prevent further attempts to initiate regular hunts for the specified duration starting from when the incense effect is applied. If another incense is used while this effect from a previous incense is ongoing, this effect will not be re-applied and the timer will not be reset. Due to a quirk in how incense works, ghosts which are standing on stairs will not be affected by the "cleansing" property of incense, though they will be affected by the "blinding" ability described below. ====Blinding during hunts====
This image has flashing lights.
Incense can be used to "blind" the ghost during a hunt. For this effect to apply, the ghost must be within the incense's range. When the effect is successfully applied, the ghost will: *Be forced into its "wandering phase", walking in a random direction *Be unable to detect or kill players; one can walk through it without dying *Temporarily lose its accumulated speed from line-of-sight *The Tier II incense additionally slows the ghost down to 50% of its speed. *The Tier III incense additionally stops the ghost from moving entirely. This effect lasts for 5 seconds for most ghosts, 4 seconds for an enraged Gallu, 6 seconds for a weakened Gallu, and 7.5 seconds for a Moroi. After this period, the ghost will return to its regular hunting behaviour, and be able to see and kill players again. Multiple incenses can be used for the same purpose during the same hunt with no diminishing returns, to blind the ghost for up to 20 seconds (30 for a Moroi) consecutively. If another incense is used while this effect from a previous incense is ongoing, this effect will be re-applied and the timer will be reset. ==Tips== *When lighting incense near a ghost during a hunt, the ghost may coincidentally take the same path as a player, especially in tight hallways. It does not mean that the ghost can still see the player. If possible, light the incense near (but not in) a hiding spot, so that you can reach it before the ghost is no longer blind. *If you are not the host, and especially if there is some latency between you and the server, the game may register the ghost killing the player before the incense effect actually applies. To avoid this, try lighting the incense earlier. *In some scenarios, it may be beneficial to use a lower-tier incense, for example if the ghost detects a player in a hiding spot and corners them, and an incense is used to protect the player; using a Tier III incense will freeze the ghost in place, possibly in a location where they can still see the player in the hiding spot and force them to switch to another hiding spot, while a Tier I or Tier II incense will cause the ghost to move away and allow the player to stay in said hiding spot. Using a lower-tier incense is also beneficial if the ghost is significantly faster than the player e.g. against a naturally fast ghost such as a young Thaye, or in custom difficulties where the ghost is faster and/or the player is slower; a Tier I incense will allow the ghost to stay relatively fast while blind, potentially moving the ghost much further away and putting a much larger distance between the player and the ghost compared to a Tier II or Tier III incense. ==Gallery== Smudge sticks.png|Pre-Exposition model being held in the player's hand. ==Objectives== {| class="article-table" !Objective !Actual requirements |- |Cleanse the area near the ghost using Incense |Light Incense within range of the ghost |- |Repel the Ghost with Incense while it's chasing someone |Smudge a hunting ghost while it has line-of-sight with a player, making it wander |} ==Trivia== *Before 0.9.0, Incense was referred to as "Smudge Sticks". Despite being referred to as "smudging", the smudge sticks are used more akin to "smoke cleansing". Smudging is a spiritual and religious practice found in various Native American cultures, many of which use white sage, a plant native to North America. Smudging is typically used for personal spiritual cleansing, prayer, and ceremonial occasions, the technique varying from tribe to tribe. Smoke cleansing, on the other hand, is used predominantly to ward off negative energy and evil spirits, and is used by wafting the smoke of sage or herbs around an area, sometimes accompanied by prayer, chanting, or incantations. Smoke cleansing is a practice commonly found in modern-day Wicca and witchcraft. *The original description for this item was as follows: "This has always been one of the main ways to weaken the more common ghosts. To do this you will need to grab some Smudge Sticks and burn it near the Ghost." ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !6 February 2020 |Increased the effective distance of White Sage. |- !28 March 2020 |Renamed White Sage to Smudge Sticks. |- ! rowspan="2" |15 July 2020 |The ghost no longer has a chance to change rooms after Smudge Sticks are used. |- |Using Smudge Sticks near the ghost now temporarily increases its activity. |- !10 September 2020 |Smudge Sticks now stop active hunts if lit near the ghost. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !26 September 2020 |The Smudge Sticks smoke is now more noticeable. |- !28 September 2020 |Smudge Sticks no longer stop active hunts, and instead prevent the ghost from killing players for a short time while making it wander. |- !0.29.6 |Smudge Sticks now smoke for 6 seconds instead of 15 seconds. |- !0.3.0 |Changed the Smudge Sticks model. |- !? |The smudge effects can now apply while burning instead of at the start or end of burning. |- !0.6.2.3 |The player can no longer light other players' smudge sticks. |- ! rowspan="7" |0.9.0 |Renamed to Incense. |- |The Incense now has 3 tiers. |- |The interval in which the ghost checks if an Incense is active, is now much smaller, making repelling the ghost much more consistent. |- |Using Incense during another Incense's blinding effect will now reset the blinding timer instead of doing nothing. |- |Now a "consumable" item; tiers I and II will be consumed when used on contracts. |- |Incense will now have an extra 50% duration (per Tier) against Moroi. |- |You can no longer repel the ghost for another player with an unlimited range (e.g. lighting a smudge in the truck). |- !0.13.0 |Incense will now temporarily disable a ghost's accumulated speed from line-of-sight. |}

content: Ghost Writing is a piece of evidence used to determine which ghost is haunting a location. It can be obtained by using a Ghost Writing Book with an applicable ghost. ==Mechanics== If Ghost Writing is a piece of evidence, if the ghost chooses to interact with an opened Ghost Writing Book, the book will rise and frantic scribbling will be visible. Ghost Writing cannot be given if the Ghost Writing Book is closed and/or the ghost is outside of its range. If the ghost writes in the book, an EMF Level 2 reading will be created (33% chance of being an EMF Level 5 reading instead if the ghost has EMF Level 5 as evidence). There are several different types of Ghost Writing that a ghost can put in the book, with the tier I and tier III books both having three, and the tier II book having six. Each has an equal chance of occurring and the type of writing does not narrow down the type of ghost any more than the fact that the ghost writes in the book at all. Each book may contain different types of writing. {| class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed fandom-table" !colspan="2"|Advanced mechanics |- !colspan="2"|WARNING: This data is not officially verified. |- !Interaction chance |The ghost will try to write in a book every 45 to 90 seconds. The timer starts as soon as the equipment is loaded and is different for each book. The interaction chance depends on the ghost writing book tier: 50%, 66.67%, 75% for tiers 1, 2, 3, respectively. |} ===Rewards=== Taking a photo of the Ghost Writing Book after it has been written in will yield a photo labelled as Ghost Writing, and reward up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the tier of the Photo Camera and whether there is a Unique stamp. A video and a sound labelled as Ghost Writing, each awarding up to $12 and 12 XP, can also be recorded when the ghost is writing in the book. ==Tips== *If a ghost throws a Ghost Writing Book, then it either does not have Ghost Writing as evidence, or is hiding it on reduced-evidence difficulties. ==Possible ghosts== {| class="article-table" |+ |Demon |Ghost Writing |Ultraviolet |Freezing Temperatures |- |Deogen |Ghost Writing |D.O.T.S. Projector |Spirit Box |- |Mare |Ghost Writing |Ghost Orb |Spirit Box |- |Moroi |Ghost Writing |Freezing Temperatures |Spirit Box |- |Myling |Ghost Writing |EMF Level 5 |Ultraviolet |- |Obambo |Ghost Writing |Ultraviolet |D.O.T.S. Projector |- |Poltergeist |Ghost Writing |Ultraviolet |Spirit Box |- |Revenant |Ghost Writing |Freezing Temperatures |Ghost Orb |- |Shade |Ghost Writing |EMF Level 5 |Freezing Temperatures |- |Spirit |Ghost Writing |EMF Level 5 |Spirit Box |- |Thaye |Ghost Writing |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S. Projector |} ==Writing Patterns== ;Tier I <gallery> T1BookWriting1.png|Violent Scribbles T1BookWriting2.png|Asking for help T1BookWriting3.png|Promise </gallery> ;Tier II <gallery> OpenBook_Writing1_Render.png|Asking for help 1 OpenBook_Writing2_Render.png|Violent Scribbles OpenBook_Writing3_Render.png|Asking for help 2 OpenBook_Writing4_Render.png|Unintelligible OpenBook_Writing5_Render.png|Fleeing the sun OpenBook_Writing6_Render.png|"Run" "Help" "See" Etc. </gallery> ;Tier III <gallery> T3BookWriting1.png|666 T3BookWriting2.png|Ritual T3BookWriting3.png|Pentagram </gallery> ==Trivia== *One of the patterns of the tier II Ghost Writing Book, labeled "Unintelligible", is an easter egg of content creator Dodorododo, being their username written several times in particularly bad cursive script. *Another of the patterns of the tier II Ghost Writing Book, labeled "Fleeing the Sun", is an easter egg of the 2013 horror movie "Mama", referencing one of the drawings of the children. ==References== Category:Evidence fr:Écriture fantomatique ru:Записи в блокноте

content: |265x265px]] Hiding Spots are features within a Map that allow players to survive hunts. ==Mechanics== ===Availability=== The number of available hiding spots depends on the difficulty as well as the number of players: *Amateur: All spots available *Intermediate: At least 3 spots available *Professional: At least 2 spots available *Nightmare/Insanity: At least 1 spot available *3 players: +1 spot available *4 players: +2 spots available For example, a Professional game with 3 players will have at least 3 hiding spots available throughout the entire map. By using a custom difficulty, hiding spots can also be turned off entirely, overriding all other rules. When a spot is unavailable, it can be blocked off with "junk"/storage equipment, be sealed behind a locked door, or have its concealing elements removed. The unavailable spots are randomly chosen at the beginning of each investigation. ===List of hiding spots=== A full list of hiding spots is available on each map's own page. See Map § List of maps. ==Tips== ]] * The ghost cannot open a closet/locker door that is currently being held by a player; Ideally, using this method, the ghost can only open one of the closet doors. Both doors can be held, in multiplayer. ** When hiding in a closet with one door fully open, you must hug the door you are holding to have better chances at survival. ** However, if the ghost detected the player inside or near a closet/locker, the ghost will forcibly open the doors, overriding the player holding the door shut. * Players are not forced to use "official" hiding spots. Some players may improvise and use furniture such as kitchen tables/islands to hide. As a general rule of thumb, if an object covers the player to at least their eye level, it can (but may not) work as a viable hiding spot. Category:Map Features fr:Cachettes

content: .]] Keys are used to unlock exit doors to investigation areas within maps, or to turn off a car alarm. ==Usage== At the start of every investigation, the location's Main Door Key will be hung on the hook beside the door keypad in the truck. A player needs to collect it in order to unlock the exit doors and enter the location. If the map has a car, a car key can also be found within the map; using a car key on the car will cause it to beep twice and turn off the alarm if it was previously on. Keys are shared across all players and can be used at any time, except during hunts where all exit doors will be locked. Keys that have been collected in the contract will show up in the journal. ===Types of keys=== * Main Door Key: Found in the truck, the Main Door Key is used to unlock the main door or side doors of a building. * Car Key: Found in 6 Tanglewood Drive, 13 Willow Street, 42 Edgefield Road, and 10 Ridgeview Court. Can be used to turn off car alarms set off by the ghost. *Cabin Key: Found in Maple Lodge Campsite, under the rug near the cabin door. Used to unlock the door to the Cabin. *Lantern Cabinet Key: Found in Point Hope, at the pool ball exit after solving a certain riddle at the pool. Can be used to unlock the lantern cabinet in Lantern Room. ==Trivia== *In earlier updates, Garage Keys and Basement Keys were formerly present on certain small maps, intended to unlock the doors to their respective rooms. These doors could also be locked by the ghost. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- ! rowspan="3" |5 January 2020 |Collected keys are now permanent. |- |Some doors will now be randomly locked within the map, requiring keys to be unlocked. |- |The list of keys collected is now shown in the Journal. |- !6 January 2020 |Keys are now synced across players. |- !2 February 2020 |The Main Door Key now only spawns once all players have connected. |- !22 August 2020 |Added a sound effect when picking up keys. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.28.? |Removed the Garage and Basement keys. |- !0.4.0 |Added a Cabin Key for the Maple Lodge Campsite cabin. |} Category: Map Features fr:Clé ru:Ключи zh:钥匙

Grafton Farmhouse is a small map in Phasmophobia, and one of the two variants of the Farmhouse, alongside Bleasdale Farmhouse. This isolated, half-ruined three-story farmhouse has a spacious ground floor, a smaller second floor, and an attic. ==Structure== Grafton Farmhouse includes 3 bedrooms, a dining room, a library, an attic, and a workshop, among other rooms. ===Layout tips=== *On the second floor, to the left of the door to the Master Bathroom, there is a door seemingly leading to another spacious room; however, it is jammed. *The Foyer's main light is shattered and provides intermittent illumination; consider turning on the lantern on some boxes near the stairs for much better visibility. *The fuse box only warms up Downstairs Bathroom, Work Room, Master Bedroom, Master Bathroom, and Child Bedroom. All the other rooms stay at the weather's ambient temperature. *The following rooms will drain sanity with 80% of the rate even if all lights are turned on: Foyer, Attic. See Third-party tools for a list of detailed map viewers that players may use. ===General tips=== *The ghost has a unique interaction when near the mannequins located in the Work Room, being able to change their pose and teleport them around the house. *The ghost can interact with the pullstring dolls in the Child Bedroom to make them talk, change their pose, or teleport them around the house. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 9 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Grafton: *Kitchen, behind fridge door *Utility Room, behind upright mattress *Dining Room, behind shelf opposite the fireplace *Work Room, behind curtain opposite the door *Upstairs Hallway, behind cardboard boxes next to an armchair *Master Bedroom, behind room divider *Child Bedroom, cupboard *Twin Bedroom, cupboard *Attic, cupboard Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots may be blocked by the presence of bulky items or their concealing elements removed: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 2 *Professional: 4 *Nightmare/Insanity: 5 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None Looping the ghost may be performed around the kitchen island, the living room piano, or the dining table, among other places. ==Bone locations== Bones spawn randomly, but will only spawn in areas that a ghost can also walk on. ;Examples ==Cursed possession locations== Grafton-Circle.png|The Summoning Circle spawns in the Child Bedroom. This guide will teach you how to earn more money in Phasmophobia, mainly focusing on maximizing the value of photo rewards. == Photo rewards == Photo rewards can be obtained by taking photos of various objects or appearances using a Photo Camera. The overall reward will vary based on the number of photos taken, and the type and quality of these photos. For the purpose of this guide only, the photos shall be separated into 3 "groups": * Group A (high reward): Ghost (including in D.O.T.S.) * Group B (medium reward): Bone, Burned Crucifix, Dirty Water * Group C (low reward): Cursed possession, Dead Body, Disturbed Salt, Fingerprint, Footprint, Ghost Writing, Interaction The rewards from these groups are as follows: {| class="article-table sortable mw-collapsible" |+Photo rewards summary ! Group ! 1 star ! 2 stars ! 3 stars |- | A | $5
5 XP | $10
10 XP | $20
20 XP |- | B | $2
2 XP | $5
5 XP | $10
10 XP |- | C | $1
1 XP | $2
2 XP | $5
5 XP |} The absolute maximum payout obtainable is $110/110 XP, but this is generally hindered by the lack of objects required to obtain this reward. Additionally, the reward cannot be multiplied higher than x1. Realistically, one can expect a maximum of $85 - $90 on most contracts. The following are a few examples of the photo rewards players could obtain (there are many more combinations): * 1 Ghost + 1 Bone + 4 Burned Crucifix + 4 Dirty Water (maximum of $110/110 XP) * 1 Ghost + 1 Bone + 4 Burned Crucifix + 1 Dirty Water + 3 Group C photos ($95/95 XP) * 1 Ghost + 1 Bone + 1 - 4 Burned Crucifix + 4 - 7 Group C photos ($75/75 XP - $90/90 XP) * 1 Bone + 1 - 4 Burned Crucifix + 5 - 8 Group C Photos ($60/60 XP - $75/75 XP) In case of a wasted photo shot or one that is below 3 stars, up to two photos can be deleted from the journal. Three-star photos cannot be deleted. Deleting photos is best used as a margin of error for getting a perfect investigation bonus, and not for min-maxing photo rewards. === Ghost === Ghost photos are worth the most, giving you $20 and 20 XP. However, only the first ghost photo will count; subsequent photos are blank. In the unlikely case that multiple players manage to take one at the same time, they will all count and provide rewards, though this is likely a bug. * Using the Summoning Circle, Music Box, or Monkey Paw is preferred over ghost events, and ghost events are preferred over taking the picture during a hunt. ** Singing ghost events last for the longest duration, and the ghost stands in place; this is preferred over other types of events. * In ghost events, ghosts disappear if the "event target" collides with it, so make sure that this player (or all players, if it is unclear which person is being targeted) maintains a safe distance from the ghost before the picture is taken. ** Ghost events almost always start in the same room as where the event target was. * During hunts, there is no clear strategy other than attempting to time the flickering and snapping at the right time, and is ultimately down to intuition, reflexes, and a bit of luck. **Taking a photo during a hunt should be seen as a last resort if no alternatives are available, as it is easy to not only miss the shot wholesale, but also to take it from too far away to not be ranked at 3 stars, and ruin the chance for the perfect game bonus, and there's also an inherent risk involved in exposing yourself during a hunt to try and take a photo, which will almost certainly put you in the ghost's line-of-sight and attract its attention. * Taking photos during a hunt is even harder with the Phantom, but easier with the Deogen and Oni. * If the ghost has D.O.T.S. Projector as evidence, taking a picture of the ghost's D.O.T.S. silhouette will also count as a full ghost photo. This should be the preferred way to get the ghost photo if using Tier II or III D.O.T.S. Projectors. === Bone === * On larger maps, finding the bone should be treated as a side task after all other objectives have been completed, due to the sheer amount of space that needs to be checked to find it. If the Ouija Board is available, you can use it to locate the bone. === Cursed possession === * The middle of the summoning circle must be within the frame to be registered as a valid photo; crouch and aim for the centre of the circle. === Fingerprint === * A photo of a fingerprint can only be obtained after a UV Light has charged it. If the EMF reading is still active, taking a photo of the same surface will yield an Interaction photo that can also help in filling the journal. * Each surface can only "store" one fingerprint at a time - if the ghost touches the door three times, you can only get the most recent fingerprint in photo. * Each fingerprint can only be taken in photo once. Ensure that none of your teammates have already taken a photo of the fingerprint. === Footprint === * Footprints are easy to get provided the ghost can generate them and walks around. If footprints are placed on top of each other due to the ghost stepping on the same spot, listening to the heavy footstep sounds and counting the steps may help the player know how many valid pictures can be taken of that spot. ** A ghost may enter its idling phase after stepping on salt and can potentially leave no or few footprints. Listen for the ghost's footsteps to tell if it is moving and hence creating footprints. * If you are using a tier II UV Light, only activate it after the ghost has stepped in the salt and you are ready to take photos. This will ensure that the glowstick is shining brightly when you need it. A secondary measure is to right click while the glowstick is in hand to "re-invigorate" it to get more light. === Disturbed salt === * When disturbed, the salt pile itself counts as a "Disturbed Salt" photo, which can be obtained even if the ghost does not have Ultraviolet evidence. * If the player is simply trying to fill up the journal with 3-star photos to obtain a Perfect Investigation bonus and don't care as much about the value of photo rewards themselves, piling up a large amount of salt piles on a chokepoint is an extremely easy way to fill up the journal with 3-star photos; when the ghost walks through the chokepoint, all of the salt piles will be disturbed at once, allowing for 6 Disturbed Salt photos with Tier I Salt, or 9 photos with Tier II or III Salt. === Interaction === * The Ouija Board, if available, is a valuable source of interaction pictures. Each successful question answered by the ghost counts as an individual interaction photo, and the use of low-cost questions can be used to quickly fill up the journal without having to wait for the ghost to perform multiple interactions. * The Voodoo Doll causes the ghost to create an interaction, and thus a new photo opportunity, with each use, but also risks starting a cursed hunt. Stay some distance away from the ghost (room) before pushing pins. * Saying recognized phrases will increase the chance of the ghost interacting with something, though there is a cooldown on this and the player has to be near the ghost. * Shades cannot use or throw items while the player is in the room. Try standing just outside the room if you intend to obtain interaction photos. * Wraiths leave no fingerprints and do not step in salt at all, making it much more difficult to fill a journal. Try placing multiple props in and around the ghost room to get interaction photos. === Burned crucifix === * Each photo of a burned crucifix is worth twice an interaction, and may warrant the extra risk. Place crucifixes spaced apart in/near the favourite room (or nearby, depending on the room's size). * The crucifix's overall effectiveness is hampered in larger rooms, as there is more area for the ghost to walk and find a spot that both crucifixes miss, or fully consume one crucifix while walking to places that the other one doesn't cover and hunts from there. Regardless of how large the room is, the ghost can simply begin a hunt while wandering away from the favourite room at an area where crucifixes have not been set up. * If the ghost can teleport or walk to a player (e.g. Wraith, Banshee, Phantom), it may be wise to stay on top of the crucifix to ensure that the ghost using its ability does not cause it to move away from the crucifixes, keeping in mind if a hiding spot can be reached with enough ease if the ghost manages to avoid the crucifix regardless and hunts. * Taking a second picture of a crucifix while the EMF reading from the successful hunt prevention is active provides an additional interaction photo. * Two photos can be taken of a Tier II and Tier III crucifix, one on each use; this can net the player a maximum of 4 burned crucifix photos per contract. * As a last resort if the ghost refuses to hunt, if the player has an unused Tier III crucifix, a cursed possession can be used to force a hunt to begin to immediately consume the Tier III crucifix for photos. === Dirty water === * As dirty water is highly dependent on having the ghost linger in rooms with sinks, it is generally not worth waiting around for the ghost to produce it, though you should always take a picture of dirty water if it occurs. * Dirty water can only be obtained once per sink, even if the ghost interacts with it several times. * As with the burned crucifix, taking a second photo of a sink while the EMF reading is still active will provide an additional interaction photo. ** Further interactions with a sink with dirty water by the ghost will continue to provide interaction photos. === General tips === * For all subjects, you need to take a picture of its centre. If the centre is not within frame, the photo will not count. For the ghost, this rule is less strict. * Each individual dead body, disturbed salt, or footprint can be photographed by multiple players. In a 4-player game, just 3 instances of disturbed salt are technically enough to fill up the whole journal. * Where needed, crouch to reduce the distance between you and the photo subject, allowing a 3-star photo to be taken. * It may sometimes be more worth it to move on to a new investigation, instead of waiting around for the last few photos to take. == Custom difficulties ==
This section needs expansion. (February 2024)
Depending on your skill level, you can create a custom difficulty with increased multipliers over Insanity that will allow you to earn more money per unit time than you normally would on a standard difficulty. If the player is skilled enough and has good knowledge of ghosts, a common strategy is to turn off all evidence, which grants a large bonus, and attempt to identify the ghost through behaviour. Although photo rewards are practically pocket change in comparison to objective rewards at very high multipliers, filling up the journal with three-star photos is still required for obtaining a perfect investigation bonus, even if the photos themselves are relatively not as worthwhile. * When playing before level 16 is reached, setting "Sanity Medication restoration amount" to 0% is completely free, as Sanity Medication is not unlocked until then. == Investigation bonuses == * Investigation bonus: Identify the ghost correctly and escape alive. This will double all rewards from ghost identification and all completed objectives, which is then further multiplied by the difficulty multiplier. * Perfect investigation bonus: In addition to the above, fill your journal with 10 3-star photos of any category, collect the bone, and complete all objectives. Besides rewards from completing these items, an additional bonus of $50 and 50 XP will be rewarded, which is affected by the difficulty multiplier. == Other rewards and tips == * Avoiding death is possibly the easiest way to earn money, and avoid losing it. * While it may be tempting to be stingy and minimize the use of consumable items, the overall low price of them will be drastically overshadowed by the reward from objectives successfully completed by electing to use them when they're needed. * Daily and Weekly Tasks are available for the player to earn extra money. Some of these are easy, like buying an item, but some may require more proactiveness, like taking a ghost photo, and some can be extremely difficult, such as the "Earn Perfect Investigation Bonuses on Nightmare or harder" weekly task. * Concerning weekly tasks, completing the Challenge Mode weekly task is one of the most time-efficient ways to earn money, potentially netting the player $5000 in three games, meaning the player effectively gets an extra ~$1667 per game in addition to the rewards given by each game themselves; however, the difficulty of challenges themselves can vary greatly, ranging from very easy ones such as Speedrun! to extremely difficult ones such as The Apocalypse Draws Near. * "Get a ghost to blow out a Firelight" can be completed via the static candles or the campfires that appear on some maps if you light those and the ghost blows them out, which saves a consumable. title: Guides/Earning monetary rewards

content: The Mare is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. The Mare has a distaste for light and will be enhanced in the dark. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== Mares cannot interact with lights to turn them on, and they are more likely to choose turning off lights as an interaction. They also cannot perform the light flickering interaction (the one that specifically leaves an EMF reading at a light switch as opposed to the "atmospheric" light flickering). The Mare does not have any affinity with computer monitors, televisions, Bleasdale Farmhouse's motion activated lights, and the fuse box, and can turn them on or off like most other ghosts. The Mare also does not have any affinity with fire sources and can still light them up. The Mare has a higher chance of performing light-shattering ghost events over other types, as this will disable the lights, making it easier to hunt. When the lights are on in its current room, the Mare is more likely to perform long roams. Contrary to most other ghosts, the Mare is able to perform long roams while its current room is not the favourite room. ===Ability=== If a player turns on a light (excluding TVs and computers) that is within 4 metres of a Mare, it has a 1/7 chance of turning the light off almost instantly, with a maximum delay of 1 second. Each light has a cooldown per player of 10 seconds after it has been turned on or off, and the Mare cannot perform its ability on a light that has an active cooldown. The Mare can use this ability even if the fuse box is turned off or broken, but not if the light is shattered. The ability also works during a ghost event. ===Hunt=== A Mare has a modified hunt sanity threshold depending on whether the room it is currently in is lit. If the lights are turned off, the hunt sanity threshold is increased to 60%, and if the lights are turned on, the threshold is decreased to 40%. This applies even if the fuse box is turned off or broken, but not if the room's lights are destroyed. Other sources of light, such as brought-in equipment and Firelights, do not affect this threshold. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: A Mare will have an increased chance to attack in the dark. Weakness: Turning the lights on around the Mare will lower its chance to attack. ==Strategies== Players should be cautious when using the Spirit Box or looking for Ghost Orbs to verify the ghost's current location or favourite room, as the Mare is more likely to hunt when the lights in its room are off, potentially catching players dangerously close to the Mare when it begins to hunt. Once a Mare is identified, there are two ways to counteract it: *Leave the lights in its favourite room and neighbouring rooms turned on. This will lower its hunt sanity threshold. *Once the sanity threshold is below 40%, the Mare will be able to hunt regardless of whether the lights are on or not. Hence, it may be wise to leave the lights in its favourite room turned off. This way, the Mare is less likely to wander away, and will be more likely to hunt in that room, making it less dangerous than a case where the Mare is constantly roaming into other rooms (and possibly changing its favourite room). In both cases, keeping a player near the light switches can help to counteract the Mare's ability if they are turned off by the ghost or from an electrical overload. Whether the lights are turned on or off do not affect the Mare's chance of performing a light-shattering ghost event. Where possible, avoid staying in rooms where you want the lights turned on, so that the Mare is less likely to shatter them. ===Identification=== The Mare is generally one of the more difficult ghosts to identify based on behaviour, though one can look for the following: *The ability to turn a light back off the moment a player turns it on: try to pause a few seconds between turning the lights on. **When the ghost manifests itself during a ghost event, try turning nearby lights on. As ghosts can't normally interact with lights during manifestation ghost events, if a light is turned off during one (and not at the beginning or at the end), it definitively confirms the Mare's ability being used. *A preference for light-shattering ghost events. *A ghost that hunts slightly earlier in the dark or slightly later in the light, though this is not very reliable. *If you tend to keep the lights near the ghost turned on, and you find the ghost frequently wandering into rooms that players have not entered, and changing favourite rooms frequently on Professional difficulty or higher, then the ghost could be a Mare. A ghost turning on the light directly eliminates the possibility of it being a Mare. On the other hand, any ghost may choose to never turn on a light throughout the entire game, so this negative should not be used to confirm the ghost type. In fact, any ghost may turn off a light immediately after you turn it on purely by chance. Additionally, some ghost events turn the lights off at their beginning or at their end; this does not count as a Mare's ability. When seeing lights flickering outside of ghost events and hunts, if an EMF reading happens to be created at a light switch, it is not a Mare. ==Trivia== *In 0.3.1.0's Journal overhaul, the Mare's description was incorrectly changed to an old version where Mares caused hallucinations that dropped a person's sanity, which could be stopped by toggling one's flashlight. This feature was replaced with the current light-based hunt sanity threshold before early access release. Hallucinations that are not tied to one ghost will be added in a future update as part of the "Horror 2.0" overhaul. *The Mare is based on the Scandinavian and Germanic mythological creature "Mara". The Mare in mythology was not technically a spirit but rather a normal woman that transformed at night due to a curse applied by circumstances of her birth. This curse applied to a man would instead create a Werewolf. The Mara would enter peoples homes at night and then place themself on their victims chest, making them paralyzed and giving them a feeling of suffocation. She was also responsible for nightmares and gave name to that phenomenon; Nightmare in English and Mardröm in Swedish. She also had a tendency to attack livestock making them exhausted and sickly. A sign that a Mare was active was that humans and animals attacked by her tended to get strange tangles and knots in their hair or fur. To drive off a Mare, one had to find its "mare tree" which was a specific tree the Mare had bound itself to, and could be identified by its tangled twigs (in reality, this is a phenomenon called "Witch's broom", and is caused by phytoplasmas). A twig from that tree, placed in the bed of the sufferer, would drive away the Mare. The Mare is usually depicted as a pale, gaunt woman with claw-like hands, long tangled hair and pale orb-like eyes. This of course does not apply to Phasmophobia; the ghost may take any appearance, including being male. ==History== {| class="wikitable" |+ ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !18 March 2020 |Spirit Box is now required as one of the evidences instead of EMF 5. |- !7 August 2020 |Looking at a Mare will now lower sanity and at a rate slightly faster than other ghosts. |- !17 August 2020 |Changed the Mare's ability from causing hallucinations to being able to hunt in the dark at higher sanity levels and in light at lower sanity levels. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.2.11.0 |Mares can no longer turn lights on. |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was Spirit Box, Ghost Orb, and Freezing Temperatures. |- !0.3.1.0 |An incorrect description of the Mare describing its old ability was added. This was reverted in a same-version hotfix. |- ! rowspan="4" |0.5.0 |Mares now have an ability to turn off lights immediately if a player turns them on. |- |Mares now prefer turning off lights as an interaction. |- |Mares now wander more if the lights are on. |- |Mares now prefer light bulb-breaking ghost events. |- !0.9.0 |Mares will no longer count keyboards and TV remotes as light sources. |} ==References== ==Notes== ru:Мара fr:Cauchemar Category:Ghosts
title: Mare

content: The main menu board allows the player to select different game modes (singleplayer/multiplayer lobbies or training), access options and view credits. It also shows the given player's ID Card as well as available Daily and Weekly Tasks. In the bottom left corner of the board, the player's Unity ID is shown. ===Loading screen tips=== While loading into the map, the loading screen displays a random tip about gameplay: {| class="fandom-table" !Tip !Remarks |- |Be careful of the dark, the Ghost can sense you |The ghost's vision remains the same throughout the game. However, the player's vision is reduced to 1 meter if there is no source of light. This tip most likely encourages players to never take advantage of darkness (particularly during hunts). |- |Don't stay in the dark too long | rowspan="2" |Staying in any unlit area drains sanity, even if the player has its own source of light. The only exception to this are candles. The lower the sanity, the more likely a ghost is to manifest itself or start hunting. |- |Keep your sanity high by staying in the light |- |Ghosts have been known to stalk their victims in the dark | rowspan="2" |Light does not affect general ghost behaviour other than their likeliness to perform interactions. Some ghosts do have a special ability that allows them to "stalk" the player but the lighting does not affect this. |- |Ghosts have been known to target those who stay in the light too long |- |Listen for distant sounds | |- |Read your Journal by pressing [J] for more information | |- |Running isn't always the best option | Some ghosts move faster than the player can run even without any customizeable buffs; for example, it is impossible to outrun a Moroi at its maximum speed. |- |Use the truck screens to help locate the ghost | |- |Use your equipment to locate the ghost and find evidence | |- |Watch what you are saying, the Ghosts are listening |Ghosts can detect players talking if their voice chat is active, while the Yokai has a higher hunt sanity threshold if players are talking near it. In addition, saying recognised phrases near all ghosts has a chance of causing them to perform an interaction. |} Category:Gameplay fr:Tableau du menu principal

The UV light is a buyable starter item used to detect Ultraviolet evidence such as fingerprints and footprints. ==Usage== The UV light can be enabled using the key while holding it. The UV light can be activated at the same time as a standard flashlight, but any visible fingerprints or footprints may contrast poorly and be hard to see under their light. The UV light projects purple light and this light is weak relative to flashlights. The Tier I and III UV Lights will not work if Flashlights are turned off in custom difficulty settings. Ghosts that give ultraviolet evidence can leave prints on certain surfaces doors, light switches, and windows. They may also leave prints on floors after stepping through salt. These prints become visible and green when a UV light is shone towards them. The Tier I UV Light is a flashlight with a narrow spotlight. It counts as an electronic equipment. So it will flicker rapidly near a manifesting ghost and will attract the ghost during a hunt when it is nearby. Tier II UV Light is a small glowstick. When activated, it glows brightly for 1 minute, then fades to half intensity over the next 10 seconds. After dimming, the glowstick can be shaken with to revitalize the light it produces. The tier III UV Light is also a flashlight. However, it has a much wider spotlight and a lesser charge time than tier I. It also counts as an electronic equipment. ==Tips== *As of patch 0.9.0, UV prints must be illuminated by a UV light to take a successful photo. *Many regard the Tier II UV Light as superior to the Tier I and III versions, due to the fact that the player can simply throw the glowstick on the floor and it will continuously illuminate any prints nearby, and it is also not an electronic, allowing the player to use it as a light source during hunts without the ghost detecting it. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !28 August 2020
(Part 3) |Added glowsticks. |- ! colspan="2" | Early Access |- ! rowspan="3" |0.3.0 |Changed the glowstick model. |- |The glowstick now fades after a short while. |- |Changed the UV flashlight model. |- !0.3.0.1 |The glowstick now fades to half intensity over 10 seconds after 1 minute. |- ! rowspan="3" |0.9.0 |UV light now has 3 tiers. |- |The glowstick has been repurposed as the Tier 1 UV light. |- |After it dims, the glowstick can now be shaken to revitalize the light it produces. |- !0.10.0 |Swapped tier I and tier II UV Light. |} Category:Equipment Category:Starter Equipment fr:Lampe UV ru:Ультрафиолетовый свет
title: UV Light

content: In Phasmophobia, players can visit several maps to execute a contract. Each investigation area is accessible after collecting and using the Main Door Key. Maps will come with a randomized weather type. ==List of maps== Phasmophobia currently has a total of 14 maps, comprising 7 small maps, 5 medium maps and 2 large maps. ===Small=== *6 Tanglewood Drive *42 Edgefield Road *10 Ridgeview Court *Nell's Diner *Grafton Farmhouse *13 Willow Street *Camp Woodwind ===Medium=== *Point Hope *Bleasdale Farmhouse *Sunny Meadows Restricted *Prison *Maple Lodge Campsite ===Large=== *Brownstone High School *Sunny Meadows ===Removed Maps=== *Asylum ==Effects== The map type affects money and experience gain, sanity drain, and light limits. Most maps require the player to reach a certain level to unlock them. One can play on a map they have yet to unlock by joining the lobby of another player that has unlocked that map. ===Light limits=== Each map has a maximum number of lights that can be turned on. This depends on map size: *Small maps: 9 *Medium maps: 8 *Large maps: 7 If the limit is exceeded, the fuse box will instantly trip (turn off), as well as all light switches and lamps. This refers to the number of interactable light switches and lamps on the map, and not the physical number of light bulbs or tubes. ==Segmentation== All maps are divided into "inside" (investigation area) and "outside" areas. The investigation area is further split into rooms, among which one will be the ghost room. ===Investigation area=== The investigation area (officially, the location) is bounded by physical barriers and one or more exits for all maps. The ghost can only be present within the investigation area; the ghost cannot exit or spawn outside the investigation area. Some maps also contain outdoor areas where the ghost may be present: *Maple Lodge Campsite and Camp Woodwind: Outdoor camping area (limited by the wooden gates) *Sunny Meadows Mental Institution/Restricted: Square courtyard *Point Hope: Balcony *Bleasdale Farmhouse: Garden Porch, Garden, Side Path For all other maps, only indoor areas are considered part of the investigation area; this includes hallways and corridors. ===Rooms=== Each map has a fixed number of rooms. Mechanics-wise, rooms may be segmented differently for the ghost than what is visually perceived by players. Rooms separated by walls may be merged to be considered as one room, while rooms that are not separated by walls may actually be regarded as multiple rooms. The Ouija Board's answers to the ghost's current location, as well as the location of Ghost Orbs, depend on each room's defined boundaries. ====Rooms not separated by visible walls==== Some rooms that seem like a single room are broken down into multiple rooms with no apparent visual barrier. For example: *The hallways on each level of Brownstone High School are divided into three separate sections: the left, front, and right. *In 10 Ridgeview Court, upon first entering the house, what appears to be one room actually consists of three different rooms: The Foyer, Dining Room, and Living Room. *In Maple Lodge Campsite, the outdoor paths and tenting areas are split up into several "rooms" not including the tents themselves. ====Rooms composed of multiple walled rooms==== Some rooms actually consist of two or more visually-distinct, walled rooms connected by doorways. For example: *Nearly all smaller bathrooms or storage rooms that are attached to a larger bedroom are considered as part of the same room as the bathroom. *In 42 Edgefield Road, the "Basement" room consists of both the hallway and the attached storage room. *In Brownstone High School, each Science Class Room (i.e., Science Class Room 1, 2, 3, and 4) is a room that consists of two rooms separated by a wall and a door. *On the Prison's second floor, the Infirmary as a room actually consists of two rooms that contain medical beds. In any room that consists of two or more walled rooms, Ghost Orbs may appear in any of the walled rooms, and the ghost can spawn for hunts in any of these rooms. This is essential to know, for example, to complete the crucifix objective. ===Ghost room=== The ghost room is akin to the ghost's "base"; it will usually spawn in that room, and most ghosts will generally linger in or near this room, subject to randomness and ghost abilities. ==References== Category:Maps fr:Carte ru:Карты
title: Map

content: An interaction is a core mechanic in Phasmophobia. It is an occurrence of the Ghost affecting its environment and items within it, and is one of the key parts of ghost activity. Although not evidence in and of itself, it both helps players to find certain pieces of evidence, and allows them to gather rewards by recording it. Ghost events and hunts do not count as interactions, but the ghost can still interact with the environment during both. ==Mechanics== Ghosts can interact with a variety of items, including handheld objects, doors, windows, electronics, and switches, among other things. Each interaction causes an EMF 2 reading, or an EMF 3 reading in the case of a thrown object, emitted at the point of interaction for 20 seconds. If an object levitates, there is an additional EMF 3 that only lasts for the duration of levitation. If the ghost has EMF Level 5 as one of its types of evidence, each individual reading has a 33% chance to be EMF 5 instead. When touching surfaces or switches, the relevant ghosts may also leave fingerprints on them. Most ghosts can interact with items located within a box centered on them. This box can rotate, making the effective range a cylinder limited by floors. The effective range is ~2.12 meters on small and medium maps (3m × 3m × 2m box), and ~4.24 meters on large maps (6m × 6m × 4m box). Ghosts can interact with objects through walls. Props (not fixed objects such as doors) are thrown with a "power" of 1 - 3 horizontally, 1 - 5 vertically, and in one of four ways: *40% chance of direct throw. *35% chance of levitation then throw. *20% chance of levitation then drop. *5% chance of levitation then throw at player. These chances also apply to the Poltergeist's ability. During hunts, ghosts have a 50% chance of throwing an object (if one is nearby) every 0.5 seconds. Ghosts can also interact with doors during hunts, 3 seconds after the beginning of the hunt, then every 4 - 8 seconds. The chance of an interaction can be increased through the following: *Playing on a lower difficulty *Customizing the ghost's interaction rate on the Custom difficulty settings *Cleansing the area near the ghost with Incense *Saying phrases that are recognised by the game, such as its name or questions **This has a cooldown of 10 seconds, and the player must have spent 2 seconds near the ghost *Having a Lower sanity *Using certain cursed possessions ===Ghost-specific modifiers=== Some ghosts have different interaction rates or mechanics: *Mares are more likely to choose turning off lights as an interaction *Oni are more likely to interact with objects if people are nearby *Poltergeists are more likely to throw objects, have a throwing power of 2 - 6 horizontally and of 3 - 6 vertically, can throw multiple objects at the same time, and have a 100% chance every 0.5 seconds of throwing nearby objects during hunts, instead of 50% *Shades perform interactions less often and cannot perform interactions if a player is in the same room *Thaye are initially twice as more likely to interact with objects; this decreases over time to a minimum of twice as less likely to interact as they age *When The Twins uses its ability, it can interact within two ranges; one within the normal range, and the other up to ~8.48m on small and medium maps (6m × 6m box) or ~16.97m on large maps (12m × 12m box) *Yokai are more active if people are talking nearby Interactions can be forced by using a Voodoo Doll. Ghosts cannot throw items if the lights in their current room are on, except for when the Poltergeist uses its multithrow ability. ===Rewards=== Most interactions can be filmed with a Video Camera to get rewards. Additionally, a Photo Camera can be used to take a photo of a levitating object. ===Types of interactions=== This is a (non-exhaustive) list of interactions that the ghost can perform: *Phone (wall-mounted, rotary dial-type or smartphone) ringing *A radio (not the Spirit Box) turning on or off *The Ouija Board's planchette moving after a successful question *Ghost Writing action *Fuse Box turning on or off *A musical instrument being played *A rocking chair rocking by itself *A grandfather clock chiming *A painting falling off the wall *Items being thrown *A teddy bear having its head twisted or giggling *A bear trap (only on Maple Lodge Campsite) *Car alarm being set off *A television turning on or off *Computer monitors turning on or off *Lights being turned on or off *Lights flickering *A shower being turned on or off *Fire sources being lit up or blown out *Doors being moved *Window/mirror knocks *A mannequin moving (either rotating or teleporting) ==Tips== *Common interactions in one room at the early stages of investigation can pinpoint to it being the ghost room, or at least near where the ghost is. *The overall number of interactions of a given game can be seen on the corkboard at the end of the mission. ==Related difficulty settings== *Activity level: Low/Medium/High ==References== ==Notes== Category:Gameplay fr:Interaction ru:Взаимодействие
title: Interaction
