This guide will teach you how to identify ghosts in Phasmophobia. ==Using evidences== The standard way of identifying a ghost is by collecting evidence. The list below presents a brief overview on how to collect evidences; more information may be found in their respective pages. ===D.O.T.S Projector=== A silhouette will appear when the ghost enters a "D.O.T.S state". Do not mistake your own breath for D.O.T.S. ===EMF Level 5=== When the ghost interacts with a door or object, take an EMF reader and check for any EMF level 5 readings at that spot. If the ghost has EMF Level 5 as one of its evidences, there is a 25% chance for that interaction to show level 5 instead of level 2 or 3. You can also use a Ouija Board to check for EMF level 5 by repeatedly asking questions with a reader nearby. Note that electronic interference during hunts or ghost events will never result in a reading of level 5, though it can be obtained if the ghost leaves EMF 5 on an object and moves far enough during a hunt. ===Ultraviolet=== When a ghost interacts with a door, light switch, or window, take a UV Light and shine it around the object it interacted with. On some maps, the ghost can leave fingerprints on many more objects, including string light poles, cooler boxes, tent windows, and more. Be aware that each fingerprint will only last 2 minutes (or 1 minute on Insanity difficulty) before disappearing, and some could last for much shorter if the ghost is an Obake. Alternatively, the ghost can leave footprints behind after stepping in salt. Take heed that the ghost may leave no footprint if it decides to stop moving after stepping in salt. ===Freezing Temperatures=== Freezing Temperatures can be confirmed using the thermometer with a reading of or less. It is recommended to wait for the reading to go below on a Tier I thermometer due to its inaccuracy. The player's cold breath does not count as Freezing Temperatures. ===Ghost Orb=== Ghost Orbs can be viewed via video cameras and appear as a small dot that glides around slowly, flashing in and out of existence. Unless the ghost room changes on higher difficulties, they will remain in the same room, but will move around the room from time to time. Take care in observing them in snow or foggy weather; snow will never go upwards while Ghost Orbs may move in any direction, while fog may make it harder to see. ===Ghost Writing=== Ghost Writing works similar to the D.O.T.S. Projector in that the player simply waits for it appear. However, Ghost Writing can take a much longer time to appear than the D.O.T.S. Projector silhouette. Removing all others props in the room (excluding player equipment) may help to increase the chance of the ghost choosing the book to interact with. ===Spirit Box=== When asking questions using the Spirit Box, ensure that the lights are off in the room, have only the questioner in the room if the ghost is stated to respond only to people who are alone (or on Professional difficulties and higher), and ask multiple times per room to improve accuracy. The ghost must be within the Spirit Box's range. Doing this only after the ghost has been located is usually less tedious. Motion Sensors can help pinpointing the ghost's exact location. ==Using traits== If the ghost refuses to give certain evidence, and when some pieces of evidence are hidden, observing the ghost's abilities and traits may be advantageous in finding out the ghost type. Certain ghosts will exhibit traits and behavior exclusive to their type, such as Mares interacting with lights more often, or Onis being more active and causing more ghost events. However, some of these traits are also subject to the game's random nature, and may or may not manifest itself because of this. ===General tips=== On Nightmare difficulty, after having obtained two pieces of evidence, it is generally best practice to compare the "tests" that can be performed, and first conduct those that are more objective, or easier to observe. For example, when given a choice between Mare and Revenant, it is usually easier to check the ghost's speed during a hunt, as the Revenant's slow wander or fast chase speed can identify it immediately, instead of looking for abilities from the Mare like instant light-switching or light-shattering ghost events, as these are more prone to error due to the game's random nature. In addition, certain behaviours that the ghost exhibits any time in the contract may allow for instant identification or elimination, such as the Obake's six-fingered handprints or the Oni's inability to produce a smoke ball ghost event. Since the rate of ghost footsteps is tied to its speed, listening to the rate of footsteps will be useful in eliminating or confirming ghosts. ===Narrowing ghosts to one with specific traits=== The following section is for ways to identify ghosts via specific traits and behaviours. A list of mechanics of each ghost can be found in their respective pages. {| class="fandom-table" |+An evidence icon below the ghost's name (e.g. Deogen ) means that the evidence is guaranteed for that ghost. This means that on difficulties with 1/2 evidence (e.g. Nightmare), that one of those 1/2 evidences will always be the guaranteed evidence for that ghost. If you do not obtain that evidence, then you can eliminate that ghost as a possibility. This does not apply on 0-evidence difficulties. !Ghost !Tests, unique identifiers, or anti-tells !Other possible identifiers |- !Banshee | *Will target a single player, ignoring all other players **If target is outside building/investigation area, will hunt normally (i.e. can chase and kill other players) **Test: During a hunt, have all players hidden inside the building, then let one player attempt to bait the ghost through line-of-sight (LoS) (e.g., by looping); if the ghost ignores the player, then it is a Banshee. If the player is chased, repeat with another player. *Chance of emitting a shriek-like sound via Parabolic Microphone (33% to replace a whisper) *Will never change favourite room; the ghost doing so (having confirmed by Haunted Mirror or other means) eliminates Banshee **Never changing favourite room could be (but not definitely) a Banshee; the larger the room is, the less likely the ghost is to change rooms | *More likely to perform singing ghost events *Frequently wanders away from favourite room to target; use motion sensors to check. Seeing ghost activity far away from the favourite room (especially on larger maps) could indicate a Phantom/Wraith/Banshee/The Twins, but this will be more common with Banshee *Hunts based solely on target's sanity (even if outside); no hunts despite low average sanity but with one high-sanity player may indicate them as target, and vice versa |- !Demon | *Minimum hunt cooldown of 20 seconds, instead of standard 25 seconds (excluding cursed hunts) **Test: If it hunts before 25 seconds, it is a Demon. Hunting 25 seconds or later does not exclude Demon *Hunt sanity threshold of 70%, with rare chance to hunt at any sanity | *Smudging prevents regular hunts for next 60 seconds, instead of standard 90 seconds **Test: If it hunts within 60 - 89 seconds, it is probably a Demon; hunting only after 90 seconds does not exclude Demon **Take care to not use Incense when the ghost is standing on stairs, as this can cause the cleansing effect to miss - hunting before 60 seconds means that the ghost was not actually cleansed *Effective crucifix range is 50% larger **Having a lazily placed crucifix burn when the ghost would normally not have used it may indicate a Demon, though ghosts could happen to wander away from their room into the crucifix's range **A crucifix being used while still on the truck wall on 42 Edgefield Road is almost certainly a Demon (usually in the garage or master bedroom) |- !Deogen
| *Always knows the location of all players, and speed is based on distance to currently targeted player (3 m/s when further than 6 metres, 0.4 m/s when closer than 2.5 metres) **Test: During a hunt, stay near or in a hiding spot, and listen for the ghost running quickly to a player and slowing down massively as it approaches **The Thaye has a similar speed to a Deogen far away when young; prepare an Incense in case it is not a Deogen *When using the Spirit Box within 1 metre of the Deogen, 33% chance per question to produce loud, deep breathing instead of a regular response **Set up motion sensors to accurately track the ghost's location, and use the spirit box near it **Ghost event/hunt vocalisations do not count | *Hunt sanity threshold of 40% |- !Goryo
| *D.O.T.S Projector silhouette only visible through a video camera, and while no players are in the ghost's current room **Seeing the silhouette without a video camera eliminates Goryo **Not based on where the D.O.T.S Projector or favourite room is; if you are in the favourite room and the Goryo roams out, you could still see the silhouette **Ghost events and hunts are not affected by this ability *Will never change favourite room; the ghost doing so (having confirmed by Haunted Mirror or other means) eliminates Goryo **Never changing favourite room could be (but not definitely) a Goryo; the larger the room is, the less likely the ghost is to change rooms | *Cannot perform long roams; ghost activity being relatively confined to favourite room and immediate vicinity (excluding ghost events and hunts) could indicate a Goryo |- !Hantu
| *Speed based on room's current temperature and will not speed up on line-of-sight: slowest at 1.4 m/s when above , fastest at 2.7 m/s below **Test: Listen for hunt speed; if it is very fast in a cold room (favourite room is usually but not always cold) but slower in warm rooms, then it is probably a Hantu. Alternatively, turn the fuse box off, then listen for its footsteps over several hunts *Will never turn on the fuse box; a ghost doing so eliminates Hantu *Will emit freezing breath during a hunt if fuse box is turned off | *Twice as likely to turn off the fuse box relative to other ghosts |- !Jinn | *Speed fixed at 2.5 m/s if three conditions are met: fuse box is on, Jinn is chasing player, and the player is further than 3 metres. Otherwise, chases at standard ghost speed **Test: Stand at the end of a long hallway or room, then wait for ghost to appear at the other end. If its speed increases instantly and not over a period of time, then it is a Jinn **Unlike Revenant, has normal speed when not chasing a player, and ability is not based on hearing player or detecting electronics *Occasionally, decreases sanity of a player in same room or within 3 metres by 25%, giving an EMF reading at the fuse box **Test: Place EMF Reader on fuse box. If it rings without anything else happening, then it is likely the Jinn's ability. Note that the fuse box turning on or its door moving is not indicative. Depending on where EMF is placed, it could also be another ghost using its own ability while standing near the fuse box *Will never turn off fuse box directly, but can still overload it if too many lights are turned on (set limit based on map size) | *Fuse box never being turned off after a long time could mean (but not definitely) a Jinn |- !Mare | *Will never turn individual lights on; a ghost doing so eliminates Mare **This does not include televisions, computers, car alarms, or radios *Has a chance of turning the lights off immediately if a player turns it on nearby, giving an EMF 2 reading **Note that any ghost can do this by chance **10-second cooldown on a per-light basis, if you turn the light on before the cooldown is over it will restart **Mare must be within 4 metres of the light to potentially trigger ability | *Hunt sanity threshold: 40% if lights on, 60% if off **Applies even if fuse box is off/broken *Decreases interactions if room is lit *More likely to perform light-shattering ghost events *More likely to perform long roams when lights are on; having the ghost roam frequently when lights are on could indicate a Mare |- !Moroi
| *Curses a player if Spirit Box response obtained or whisper through Parabolic Microphone heard. This doubles their sanity drain, and lights will not stop sanity drain. Curse temporarily pauses when player is outside the house, and Sanity Medications remove the curse for a player. **Take note of sanity at time of receiving spirit box/paramic response and a few minutes after; if one person's sanity drops noticeably quicker than others, then it could be due to the curse **Sanity can drain in other ways, such as ghost events or abilities; try to eliminate these possibilities *Speed based on current average sanity (1.5 m/s base speed above 45% sanity, 2.25 m/s at ~0% sanity). Will also increase speed in line-of-sight **If base speed increases over several hunts, then it could be a Moroi **Ensure that it is not a Hantu by keeping the fuse box on (if possible) *Smudging during a hunt "blinds" the Moroi for 50% longer. | |- !Myling | *Footsteps and vocalisations can only be heard within 12 metres (instead of 20 metres) *Test: Go to a hiding spot and place an active electronic on the ground. If the ghost's footsteps/vocalisations are audible only when the specified electronic starts flickering (within 10 metres of ghost), then it is probably a Myling **Note that the Raiju interferes with electronics from further (15 metres) **This test is not reliable if the ghost is on a different floor, since electronics will not flicker **Some vocalisations can be very soft; try listening for footsteps in this case **Note the audible range being slightly larger than the interference range. Some specific audio setups may allow you to hear the ghost before electronics flicker | *Increased frequency of paranormal sounds when listening through parabolic microphone |- !Obake
| *16.7% chance to leave unique fingerprint pattern: Six-fingered handprints instead of five, two fingerprints on light switches instead of one, and five fingerprints on keyboards and Prison cell block gates instead of four *During a hunt, can appear as a different ghost model during a flicker *25% chance to not leave fingerprints when interacting with a valid surface (for standard difficulties). If you see it leave a fingerprint once but not on another time, then it is probably an Obake *Occasional ability to halve the remaining duration of existing fingerprints on the map | |- !Oni | *Will never cause "airball" ghost event (airball chases a player, before disappearing with a hiss); a ghost doing so eliminates Oni **Will still hiss if it manifests to chase a player and disappears due to colliding with the player **Some maps have a larger mist that will fly out of the building in a straight line and disappear. Seeing this also eliminates Oni *Will be visible for a longer period when flickering during hunts; seeing a ghost that doesn't disappear as often as other ghosts during a hunt makes it probably an Oni | *During ghost events, more likely to use its full ghost model instead of a shadow or translucent form *Double sanity drain during a ghost event if it collides with a player (20% instead of 10%) |- !Onryo | *Will never light fire sources *If attempts to hunt within 4 metres of a flame (firelight, igniter, Maple Lodge Campsite campfire), it will blow out the flame instead *In addition, prioritises blowing out a flame instead of using a crucifix *Confusingly, every third flame that the Onryo blows out will also cause it to hunt **Can still be prevented by normal methods (crucifix/incense/another lit flame) *Test: At high sanity, place a crucifix down, then a lit firelight directly on top of it. Let it blow out the firelight 3 times; if it hunts on the third blowout, then it is likely an Onryo (try to eliminate Demon as a possibility) **This test is better performed using Tier I or II crucifixes, since they have a smaller or equal range as a flame. Tier III crucifixes may lead to inaccurate results if the ghost attempts to hunt within range of the crucifix but outside range of the flame *Test: Spread out multiple lit firelights in the favourite room and nearby (as desired), then keep them continously lit while average sanity is low. If it attempts to hunt (e.g. burns a crucifix) without blowing out the firelights, then it is not an Onryo. If the ghost refuses to hunt, it could be (but not definitely) an Onryo **The Shade will not hunt if at least one player is in its room. Try to eliminate this ghost before testing for Onryo | *Hunt sanity threshold of 60% |- !Phantom | *Taking a photo of a Phantom will make it instantly and temporarily disappear for that specific instance that it appears **Will not end the ghost event or hunt, but in ghost events, electronics will no longer flicker **Ghost photo will have no interference, and the ghost will not be visible. Note that this can occur for any ghost if the photo is taken exactly at the end of the ghost event/hunt, and the photo can also have no interference if taken from another floor **Best to check if the ghost event continues (listen for ghost vocalisations) **This also applies to photos taken while the Phantom is visible in D.O.T.S. *During a hunt, flashes visible every 1 to 2 seconds as opposed to every 0.3 to 1 seconds for other ghosts. The ghost being invisible for long periods could indicate a Phantom | *Will occasionally walk (invisibly) to a random player outside of hunts/ghost events; seeing ghost activity far away from the favourite room (especially on larger maps) could indicate a Phantom/Wraith/Banshee/The Twins |- !Poltergeist | *Has an ability to throw all nearby items at the same time. Create several piles of objects in and near the favourite room (try not to stack items), then see if the ghost throws multiple objects at once **Can throw items using its ability even when the lights are on, unlike other ghosts which can only throw things in the dark | *During a hunt, has a 100% chance to throw an item in its path every 0.5 seconds, instead of 50% with all other ghosts **Noticing a considerable number of items being thrown around (much more than usual) after the hunt could indicate a Poltergeist *Tends to throw objects more frequently than other ghosts in general **Note that all ghosts cannot throw items if the room they are currently standing in is lit, though the multithrow ability overrides this *Can throw items much further than other ghosts (up to twice as far). Noticing items being "shot" across the room (i.e, a dining utensil found across the living room from the nearby dining room) could indicate Poltergeist |- !Raiju | *Fixed speed of 2.5 m/s if there is at least one piece of active electronic equipment nearby (within 6-10 metres depending on map size) **Standard ghost speed if not near these equipment *Electronic interference range during ghost events or hunts is 15 metres, compared to the standard 10 metres **Like other ghosts, does not interfere with electronics on a different floor **Detection range is still 7.5 metres like other ghosts *Getting EMF Level 5 and Ghost Orbs on difficulties with 2 evidences (e.g. Nightmare) confirms Raiju, since the only other ghost that has these two evidences is the Obake, which has Ultraviolet as a guaranteed evidence | *Hunt sanity threshold is 65% if at least one piece of active electronic equipment nearby, otherwise 50% |- !Revenant | *During a hunt, moves at 1 m/s if no player detected. If a player is detected or when moving to last known player location, moves at 3 m/s. After arriving at last known location, it will decrease its speed by 0.75 m/s² until it reaches 1 m/s (over ~2.7 seconds) | |- !Shade | *Cannot interact with items, perform ghost events, or hunt if at least one player is in the same room as the ghost, regardless of average sanity **Can still happen if it wanders into a room with no players **Note that turning lights on in a standard ghost's current room will prevent EMF 3 interactions (throws) but not EMF 2 interactions (door touch, window knock, etc.) *If summoned by a Summoning Circle, a Music Box, or a Monkey Paw, has a chance of appearing as a shadow instead of a full form; will return to normal upon hunt starting | *Above 50% average sanity, increasing sanity means decreasing chance of ghost events; a ghost event at very high sanity may mean that a Shade is unlikely (but not impossible) *Hunt sanity threshold of 35% *Increased chance of airball ghost events instead of manifesting. If it does manifest, has increased chance of using shadow model instead of full/translucent form |- !Spirit | *Cleansing prevents hunts for 180 seconds instead of 90 seconds **Test: Get sanity as low as possible, then cleanse the ghost and wait. If it hunts before 180 seconds is up, then it is not a Spirit. Hunting only after 180 seconds may indicate (though not definitely) a Spirit **Take care to not use Incense when the ghost is standing on stairs, as this can cause the cleansing effect to miss - hunting before 60 seconds means that the ghost was not actually cleansed | |- !Thaye | *Has "age" parameter, where it will age the more time players spend in the same room as the Thaye. Speed is based on age and does not speed up with line-of-sight; is fast at youngest (2.7 m/s at age 0) and slow when old (1 m/s at age 10) *Getting Ghost Writing and D.O.T.S Projector on difficulties with 2 evidences (e.g. Nightmare) confirms Thaye, since the only other ghost that has these two evidences is the Deogen, which has Spirit Box as guaranteed evidence | *Age parameter also affects activity and hunt sanity threshold: **Twice as active compared to normal ghost when youngest, half as active compared to normal ghost when oldest **75% hunt sanity threshold at youngest, 15% at oldest |- !The Mimic | *Ghost Orbs as "secondary evidence" or ability in addition to main evidences; this means that they will always be present, even on 0-evidence difficulties **For example, you can obtain Ultraviolet, Spirit Box, and Ghost Orbs on Nightmare difficulty. If the difficulty gives less than 3 evidence, check for presence of additional evidence **If you get EMF 5, Ghost Writing, or D.O.T.S Projector, you can safely eliminate The Mimic since it cannot mimic evidence types from other ghosts *Randomly mimics another ghost, along with all its abilities and behaviour, such as 6-fingered handprints when mimicking Obake. Will change every 30 seconds to 2 minutes, but will not change during hunts **Look for the ghost demonstrating two completely different traits (such as noticing the ghost flickering slower like a Phantom during a hunt, when it was not doing so earlier) | *Since The Mimic can imitate any other ghost's properties, it is important to eliminate it as a possibility before making any conclusions about other ghosts (e.g. concluding that it's a Wraith because it didn't disturb salt) |- !The Twins | *Has two separate interaction ranges; the first within 2.12 metres (4.24 metres on large maps) and the second within 8.48 metres (16.97 metres on large maps). Occasionally, will interact with the environment almost simultaneously (within 1 second) using these two ranges; noticing two interactions occurring in very quick succession at two separate locations, especially several times, can indicate The Twins **Use EMF readers and see if both readings stop within less than 1 second of each other. **All ghosts can interact with items within about 2 seconds in between, while cursed possessions can also cause near-simultaneous interactions (e.g. repeatedly using Voodoo Doll) **Interactions for all ghosts happen in a radius confined to the same floor; they can interact through walls in an adjacent room *Depending on where hunt starts, has slightly different base speed; 1.5 m/s if it starts from where the ghost actually is, and 1.9 m/s if it starts from the location where the large-range interaction occurred | *Because it is one ghost with two interaction ranges, you could misidentify where the ghost actually is; noticing a single interaction in one area, but then realising that the ghost was never there (e.g. absence of low temperatures/another room is of low temperatures) could indicate The Twins. Other indicators of ghost presence include motion sensors to track ghost movement, and evidences *Look for items interacted with by the ghost far away from ghost room (e.g. thrown objects, turned-on lights). Seeing ghost activity far away from the favourite room (especially on larger maps) could indicate a The Twins/Phantom/Wraith/Banshee *50% chance to hunt from where the ghost actually is, or from "ranged" interaction **The ghost hunting far away from the favourite room could indicate The Twins, one of the ghosts mentioned above, or simply a very roamy ghost *Crucifixes only work from the ghost's actual position, so "Fast Twin" hunts can appear to begin directly on top of a crucifix |- !Wraith | *Will never disturb salt piles, even during hunts **If the ghost never steps in salt after a long time, then it is likely (though not definitely) a Wraith **Test: During a ghost event or while the ghost is in a visible D.O.T.S. state, place salt under the ghost. Alternatively, place salt beneath a Motion Sensor. If it doesn't disturb the pile despite walking over it, then it is a Wraith. This is best done with stationary ghost events (e.g. singing) | *Can teleport to a random player when not hunting/performing ghost events, leaving an EMF 2/5 reading. Seeing ghost activity far away from the favourite room (especially on larger maps) could indicate a Wraith/The Twins/Phantom/Banshee |- !Yokai | *Can only sense player voices/held electronics within 2.5 metres **Test: During a hunt, stand in a room at a suitable distance away from the ghost, hold an electronic equipment (to check if the ghost is within 10 metres), then repeatedly talk/use global chat (since voice detection for normal ghosts is 9 metres as opposed to electronic detection, which is 7.5 metres). If the ghost is nearby with no line-of-sight but does not enter the player's room despite the potential attraction, then it could be a Yokai. Note that the ghost going to the player does not eliminate Yokai, since it could have wandered over by chance | *Hunt sanity threshold is 80% if players are talking in the same room as the ghost, otherwise 50% *Increased ghost activity if players are talking near the ghost |- !Yurei | *Has an ability where it will drop the sanity of all players within 7.5 meters of it by 15%, while also closing a door gently at the same time **This does not count during ghost events or hunts *Cannot slightly move doors outside of hunts | *Will walk back to favourite room and not wander out for 90 seconds when smudged. Place a Motion Sensor at the doorway, then smudge the ghost. If the motion sensor is never set off by the ghost within the next 90 seconds, then the ghost could be a Yurei. This test is not very reliable **Ghost events override this mechanic |} ==Other tips== ===Elimination by negatives=== If you can be sure that the ghost will not provide a particular piece of evidence, you can eliminate all ghosts that have that piece of evidence. This also works on Nightmare difficulty, but requires two negatives instead; for example, if you can be sure that the ghost will not give both Fingerprints and Freezing Temperatures, then you can eliminate four ghosts: Demon, Hantu, Jinn, and The Mimic. Conclusively eliminating evidence may be trickier for chance-related evidence like EMF Level 5, for example. This strategy is more useful if you are unable to easily find evidence in the first place. ===Speed-altering defensive equipment=== Some higher-tier defensive equipment, such as Tier III Salt and Tier II and III Incense, can temporarily reduce or even halt the ghost's movement entirely, potentially masking the unique movement behavior of several ghost types. Past being mindful of these attributes, if the ghost needs to be identified through its speed or movement, using lower tier defensive items that do not affect the ghost's movement can be considered, although this will require giving up the significant power of these higher tier items. ==See also== *Ghost#Evidence *Ghost#Ghost types Category:Guides fr:Guides/Identifier les entités
title: Guides/Identifying ghosts

content: The Jinn is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. The Jinn can be empowered by an active Fuse Box to quickly close in on targets that it is chasing during a Hunt. ==Behavior== ===Activity=== The Jinn cannot directly turn off the fuse box. However, it can still indirectly turn off the fuse box by turning too many lights on and overloading it. There is a popular myth claiming the Jinn will interact with electronics more often rather than other interactions; this is not true. The Jinn has an equal chance of interacting with anything nearby. ===Ability=== When near a player and the fuse box is on, the Jinn will occasionally use an ability that lowers the sanity of one player in the same room or otherwise within 3 meters of it by 25%. The player who will lose sanity is the first in the list (established by the order the players joined the lobby) among players in range. An EMF 2 or 5 reading will then be generated at the fuse box. ===Hunt=== During a hunt, if all of the following three criteria are satisfied: *The fuse box is turned on *The Jinn has line-of-sight with a player it is targeting *The Jinn is further than 3 metres from that player Then its speed will be fixed at 2.5 m/s while the criteria are met. Otherwise, it will obey standard ghost speeds with one particularity: while it is travelling at the fixed 2.5 m/s speed, the speed increase from continuous line-of-sight adds in the background, and will be applied once one criteria is no longer satisfied. Whether there are lights turned on or not does not affect the Jinn's abilities. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: A Jinn will travel at a faster speed if its victim is far away. Weakness: Turning off the location's power source will prevent the Jinn from using its ability. ==Strategies== Turning off the location's breaker will prevent the Jinn from using any of its abilities. However, this will render the map's electrical lights inactive, leading to players' sanity draining as a consequence of being in the dark more often. Players will need to decide if preventing the Jinn from using its abilities is worth dealing with more frequent hunts as a result of lower average sanity, though this loss can be mitigated by holding lit candles to reduce passive sanity drain. ===Identification=== There are two ways to identify a Jinn, both methods with the breaker turned on: *Wait for a hunt at the end of a long room or corridor, standing far away from where the ghost is expected to enter the room, and with line-of-sight all the way through. Listen for its footsteps and observe its speed before and after it sees the player. If it instantly gains speed to chase the player, then it is likely a Jinn; use Incense if needed. **Be careful not to mistake this with a Revenant; while they both exhibit the same behaviour (instant speed-up upon spotting a player), a Revenant's speed change will be much more drastic. *Leave an EMF reader at the fuse box while the fuse box is on; if it picks up a reading but the fuse box never turned off, then it is very likely the Jinn using its ability, barring any other items that could have caused the reading (such as the fuse box door itself). Keep in mind that a fuse box turning off on its own does not rule out a Jinn, as they can still indirectly turn off fuse boxes by turning on too many lights and causing the fuse box to trip. If a fuse box trips, all light switches will also turn off, which can be used to distinguish from a ghost manually turning the fuse box off, which leaves light switches untouched. In custom difficulties with the fuse box broken, or if it is broken with the Monkey Paw's "I wish for activity" wish, a Jinn becomes impossible to identify through behavior, and thus can only be identified with evidence; in 0 evidence runs in particular, this makes a Jinn almost completely impossible to identify, as the only way to identify a Jinn under these conditions is to painstakingly rule out every other ghost type - depending on the room the ghost is in, this sometimes can become impossible. ==Trivia== *Jinns are derived from Arabic mythology, and were later integrated as part of Islamic theology. They are a type of spirit/being created before mankind out of smoke-free fire. Usually invisible, they can take shape in many forms including serpents, winged beings, giants, insects, or humanoids. Jinns are not undead, and they live, eat, age, and have children like humans. Like mankind, they were made to worship God, and they are not innately good nor innately evil. ==History== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !2 February 2020 |Changed the Jinn's ability from affecting the weather to running if its target is also running. |- !7 March 2020 |Increased the Jinn's running speed. |- !10 August 2020 |Jinns no longer turn the fuse box off. |- !24 August 2020 |Changed the Jinn's ability to having a faster speed when far away from its target. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was EMF Level 5, Spirit Box, and Ghost Orb. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.5.0 |Increased the Jinn's chasing speed to 2.5 m/s. |- |Decreased the slowdown gap to 3 metres. |- !0.6.2.0 |When using its ability, the Jinn will now leave EMF on the fuse box rather than its current place. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.7.0 |Ability will now apply if the player is in the same room as the ghost, or within 3 metres. |- |The EMF will now be generated at the fuse box when anyone's sanity is drained, instead of just the host. |} ==References== == Notes== ru:Джинн fr:Djinn de:Dschinn Category:Ghosts
title: Jinn

content: This guide dispels common misconceptions and myths about game mechanics in Phasmophobia. ==Investigation== ===Being in a lit room will always stop passive sanity drain=== Passive sanity drain is dependent on whether the room's "main lights" — chiefly ceiling light fixtures — are turned on or not. Other light sources that may be present in the room, such as table lamps, floor lamps, and electronic devices like televisions, will not prevent passive sanity drain despite illuminating the room to some degree. Additionally, in larger rooms with a lower overall light level, such as most hallways in Sunny Meadows Mental Institution, having the main lights on will not completely prevent passive sanity drain either, instead reducing it to 80% of the normal rate, which can cause sanity drain to be perceived as faster on these maps, depending on individual playstyle (whether the lights are usually turned on to preserve sanity). Firelights within 2 metres of the player will reduce, but not stop, passive sanity drain, with the effectiveness dependent on the tier. ===The radio messages at the beginning of an investigation will hint about the ghost type and/or its behaviour=== These messages are simply there for immersion and are chosen randomly. They do not correlate to the ghost type or give any indication about its behaviour at all. ===My dead body photo must be taken for me to receive insurance payout=== The dead body photo does not affect whether a player receives insurance, and instead awards a small amount of cash depending on how many stars the photo has much like any other. Insurance is instead given automatically, the value of which being a portion of the purchase price of all equipment added by that player for the contract. Insurance is only given on Intermediate difficulty and lower. ===A sloped line with a break on the activity graph is a dead giveaway of The Twins=== While the appearance of a sloped line containing a break on the activity graph can be indicative of The Twins, especially if it appears on both sides of a hump representing a rise in activity, it is not exclusive to The Twins ghost type and can appear with any given ghost. ==Items and Equipment== ===Higher EMF readings mean imminent danger=== The level of an EMF reading has no correlation to a ghost's overall activity or aggression. Instead, EMF readings are individually linked to specific actions from the ghost; for example, the ghost opening or closing a door gives an EMF level 2, and it throwing an object will give an EMF level 3. Also note that EMF readings do not add up on the EMF reader. This means that a ghost interacting with two adjacent doors (EMF level 2 each) will not give an EMF level 4, but will instead create two separate EMF 2 readings, one for each interaction. Continuing on this, an EMF Level 5 reading is simply a random chance of an EMF level 2 or EMF level 3, and is unrelated to whether the ghost is going to attack soon. In the same vein, getting a series of higher EMF readings does not necessarily mean that the ghost will trigger an EMF Level 5 either. ===The lowest temperature in the room indicates the ghost's exact location=== This is not true; the temperature at every point within a room will be exactly the same. Furthermore, the thermometer's reading always fluctuates, hence whether it is lower in a specific spot is not meaningful in terms of the exact position of the ghost. Even then, low or freezing temperatures is not a guarantee of the ghost being in a particular room at a specific time, as temperatures rise and fall slowly when the ghost leaves or enters a room. ==="What is your favourite room" with the Ouija Board gives the favourite room=== Asking for the name of the favourite room only gives an answer of the ghost's current room, regardless of how the location question is phrased. People may have found it to give the favourite room in earlier versions, but this is because the ghost tended to roam around less and stay in its favourite room, hence giving the impression that asking for the favourite room was accurate. On the other hand, the Haunted Mirror does show the favourite room, even if the ghost is elsewhere when it is used. ===The smoke emitted from extinguished firelights indicates that the ghost interacted with them=== No, candles will always emit the same type of smoke regardless of what caused them to go out. However, a "huffing" sound will be heard if a candle is blown out by the ghost, which is not the case if it burns out on its own. ===Using the Spirit Box/leaving the Spirit Box on lowers sanity=== Using the spirit box and obtaining a response will not drain sanity on its own. However, as using the spirit box requires the player to be in a dark room, passive sanity drain from darkness will apply normally. Note that the Moroi has a unique ability where it will "curse" the player using the Spirit Box upon answering, causing their passive sanity drain to be increased until the curse is lifted. ===Flashlights must be turned off when using the Spirit Box=== Using the spirit box requires on-site lights in the player's current room to be turned off, but not player-brought equipment. The ghost will still give responses even with flashlights on or if there are firelights burning in the room. This also applies for lights in adjacent rooms; the Spirit Box will still work even if doors are open or the "room" is not separated by a physical wall (such as the kitchen and the dining room on Bleasdale Farmhouse). ===Crucifixes can stop ongoing hunts and/or protect the player from the ghost=== The only function of the crucifix is to prevent hunts from happening if the ghost is within its effective range. Crucifixes will have no effect on the ghost once it starts hunting, even against Demons. The only way to stop an ongoing hunt before its natural expiration is either for one player to be killed, which stops the hunt if Kills extend hunt duration is turned off, or all players to manage to leave the investigation area while a hunt is ongoing, the only legitimate method of doing so being using the Monkey Paw to unlock the exit doors and then walking outside. ===Using onsite objects or items has repercussions on the ghost's activity=== Interacting with the map, furniture and objects, even in an excessive way, will not rile up or anger the ghost into hunting, performing a ghost event or increasing its activity. The only map items that can trigger a hunt, event or activity from the ghost are cursed possessions, depending on how the cursed possession is used. ==Maps== ===Certain map ambient sounds can hint at the ghost's location=== Map ambient sounds (such as the screams echoing through Sunny Meadows Mental Institution or branches cracking on Maple Lodge Campsite) are there simply for immersion and are not tied to the ghost in any way. ===Ghosts can change their favourite room to any other room on the map=== In theory, this is true, but this will vary widely depending on the ghost's abilities, the difficulty settings on roaming and favourite room changing chance, the layout of the map, and whether the player uses cursed possessions. Ghosts have a chance of changing favourite room when performing long roams. *A ghost can realistically change from the Dining Room in Tanglewood to the Master Bedroom in one roam. *A ghost in the Foyer of Bleasdale Farmhouse would have to minimally change favourite rooms to the Upstairs Hallway first, before possibly changing to the Attic. *A ghost in the A/B blocks of Prison would find it very hard to change rooms to the front section of the map, since the intermediate hallway cannot be chosen as a favourite room. In general, the further a room is from the ghost's current favourite room, the lower the chance is of the ghost changing its favourite room to there. Exceptions include Wraiths and Phantoms which have an ability to travel directly to a player's location no matter how far away said player is (and subsequently have a chance to change their favourite room to a nearby room), and the "I wish for sanity" Monkey Paw wish, which changes the ghost's favourite room to a random room, which can be anywhere on the map. ==Hunt== ===Ghosts can be triggered to hunt by swearing at them/addressing them in certain ways=== This is not true. Saying the ghost's name or certain trigger words near the ghost only increases the chance of an interaction, not hunts. The only ghost which may hunt more often when players are talking near it is the Yokai, and this merely raises the hunt sanity threshold rather than causing it to hunt on command (and additionally concerns any sort of speech, not just trigger words/phrases). In other words, there are no ways to make ghosts start hunting simply by being vocally active. ===Ghosts who have EMF Level 5 evidence will give it out during hunts=== This is only partially true. While hunting, the Ghost still makes EMF interactions when it interacts with the environment. For example, if the ghost touches a door while searching for players, the door will still make a readable interaction. Once the ghost goes far enough away/stops hunting, which makes electronic equipment usable, one can then read the EMF level from that door, which could potentially be a level 5 reading. However, regardless of whether the ghost has EMF Level 5 as evidence, electronic interference when the ghost manifests during a hunt or a ghost event will only give levels 1 - 4 on an active EMF Reader. It is hence useless to check for EMF Level 5 when the reader is being interfered with during hunts, and is generally dangerous, as the active reader may broadcast the player's location to the ghost if used. ===The ghost will not hunt so long as at least one teammate has high sanity=== The probability of a hunt happening takes into account the average sanity of all players (displayed at the top of the Sanity Monitor inside the truck), regardless if they are outside or inside the investigation area. This means that a lone player with high sanity will still face very "aggressive" behaviour from the ghost if the rest of the players have low sanity, even if they all stay outside. The ghost only checks for the presence of a player inside the investigation area to initiate a hunt, not their individual sanity level. One exception to this is the Banshee, which will only check its target's sanity to hunt; if it selects a teammate with high sanity as its target, then it will indeed not hunt so long as that teammate's sanity stays above the threshold, even if all other teammates have low sanity, which also applies if the target is outside of the investigation area. ===Ghosts can chase the player outside the investigation area/into the truck=== This is not a feature of the game. If you see a ghost clearly outside the investigation area (and perhaps it kills someone), then someone in your lobby is likely modifying/hacking the game. There is a bug in the game where the ghost can kill players through exterior doors if they stand too close to them, causing players to die while outside the building, but this is due to a hitbox issue and not due to the ghost leaving the building; there is also a delay between a player getting caught and actually dying (during which the death animation is playing out), and a player can still move around while this is happening, which means if they die close to an exit door, they can walk outside the building and die outside. As an aside, crucifixes can prevent hunts when located outside of the investigation area, or even when sitting on the equipment wall in the truck, as crucifixes do not check for walls, obstacles, or zone boundaries to block a hunt, nor do they need to be activated in any way, just that the ghost is within the crucifix's range. Hunts prevented from the truck usually occur on maps where the truck is parked close enough to certain rooms (e.g. the garage of 42 Edgefield Road), and the ghost just so happened to be on the very edge of said rooms while it attempted to hunt and got caught in the crucifix's effective range; this is more likely to happen with Demons who have an increased crucifix range. ===Ghosts can see through doors or walls=== In general, most ghosts cannot see players through doors or walls, even transparent ones. For example, in 13 Willow Street, if you close the glass doors between the living room and the kitchen, it's possible to watch the ghost through them during a hunt without it seeing you. The same goes for the bars in Prison. However, during hunts, all ghosts can pass through doors as if they didn't exist. The only ghost who can see through physical objects is the Deogen, who will always know the location of the player no matter where they are on the map, rendering hiding or line-of-sight breaking completely useless. ===Ghosts can remember where you hid in a previous hunt/hiding in the same spot multiple hunts in a row is unsafe=== Ghosts will only have a 50% chance to "remember" where a player was during the next hunt if it saw a player in that specific spot in the previous hunt. If nobody was seen at or near that spot, it will not remember that you hid there. In the case someone was seen in the general area of a hiding spot (however not necessarily in the hiding spot), it may be safer to hide in a different place for the next hunt, as the ghost may wander around that area for a while before moving on, and incidentally may potentially find you hiding there. Players are then safe to return to that hiding spot in following hunts as the ghost's memory only lasts for one hunt. This also does not apply if you smudge the ghost with incense; the ghost does not have a chance to return to where it last saw you within the same hunt after a smudge. More likely, the ghost is already nearby, so the chance of it randomly wandering to you (or simply detecting you) is higher. Whether this is true between hunts has not been verified. In short, unless someone was seen at or near the spot in the immediate previous hunt, choosing to stay in the same spot across multiple hunts is no more dangerous than choosing to move. ===The ghost won't see me if I turn all the building lights off=== The ghost's vision is unaffected by darkness, and they can see players in the dark just as well as they can in the light. Conversely, ghosts do not actually "see" the light beam from a flashlight or any form of light-emitting equipment, instead simply sensing active electronic equipment in a fixed range. ===Using global chat during hunts could cause other players to die=== Unless the other player's microphone is picking up the sound from their own speaker, this is not the case. Using global chat during a hunt will attract the ghost to only the player who is pressing the button, if the ghost is within range. This was designed to prevent griefing in this manner where players attempt to kill other players. ==Ghosts== ===Lit firelights can affect the Hantu's speed=== Only the room's temperature (which can be read on a Thermometer) will affect its speed; firelights do not affect the room's temperature, and as such do not affect the Hantu's speed. Currently, the only source of flames that affect room temperatures is Camp Woodwind's campfire when lit. ===Jinns cannot interact with the fuse box door=== All ghosts, including the Jinn, are capable of interacting with the door covering the Fuse Box. The only thing the Jinn cannot do is directly touch the switch inside to turn the power off (and similarly, the Hantu cannot turn the switch on). ===Jinns will interact with electronics more often=== Jinns do not have a higher chance of interacting with electronics; they interact with electronic items in the same manner as other ghosts. ===Obakes can mimic player models=== Obakes cannot mimic player models. They can only briefly change into another ghost model on specific blinks during a hunt. This misconception may derive from a special ghost event that was scrapped early after pre-release where the ghost could mimic player models. ===The Onryo's ability to hunt after blowing out a third flame bypasses crucifixes, smudging and other lit flames=== This ability hunt can still be blocked by crucifixes, smudging, and other lit flames. Other ghost's ability hunts can also be blocked by normal hunt prevention methods. Only cursed hunts cannot be blocked (with the exception of a nearby fully intact Tier III crucifix). Note that there is a potential bug under investigation where ghosts wrongly determine their current room when above a basement, and this is speculated to result in a secondary bug such as the Onryo bypassing crucifixes, incense and flames for its ability hunt. ===Extinguishing firelights manually can cause an Onryo to hunt=== An Onryo's three-flame hunt only counts flames that the ghost itself blows out; players extinguishing flames have no effect whatsoever on an Onryo hunting, other than potentially letting it start a hunt when the lit flame would've prevented it. ===Raijus can drain power from any electronic source=== Only active electronic equipment brought in from the truck (e.g. flashlights, active sensors and projectors, active head gear, etc.) will power the Raiju's abilities. Other sources of electricity, like power sources that depend on the breaker (native lighting, alarm clock/radio, computers, TVs, etc.) do not boost the Raiju, so there is no need to turn these off beforehand. ===The Mimic's Ghost Orbs will follow the ghost/work differently from other ghosts=== The Mimic's Ghost Orbs function no differently from that of other ghosts'; they will stay in the favourite room, move around in a random direction like other ghosts' orbs, and swap rooms only when the favourite room changes. ===The Twins is two functional ghosts=== Code-wise, The Twins is just one ghost, however it has two separate interaction ranges: the normal range and an "extended" range, which allows it to interact with items that are very far away from it, giving off the illusion that there is another ghost roaming the building. When The Twins tries to hunt, there is a 50/50 chance that it will either hunt from where it is standing or near from where it last interacted with its extended range. ===Banshees will not hunt if their target is outside the investigation area=== A Banshee can hunt even if the target is outside (even though it will still only check the target's sanity), and will simply behave like any other ghost during a hunt, chasing any opportune player. ===Extremely low temperatures are a sign of a Hantu=== All ghosts which give Freezing Temperatures evidence are capable of reducing a room's temperature all the way to -10°C, and the Hantu is not known to reduce a room's temperature any more quickly than other ghosts. ==Journal text== ===If the ghost is a Phantom, the cursed possession is more likely to be a Ouija Board, and vice versa=== Phantoms and Ouija Boards are not related gameplay-wise in any way. ===If the ghost is a Deogen, the weather is more likely to be Fog, and vice versa=== The "endless fog" mentioned in the Deogen's journal is simply flavour text and has no gameplay effects whatsoever. ===Spirits are more common than other ghosts, and Hantus are rarer than other ghosts=== All ghosts have the same chance of being chosen, including Spirits and Hantus, contrary to their journal entry stating Spirits are "very common" while Hantus are "rare". These journal entries are merely brief decorative passages, and are in no way gameplay-significant. ===Yokais are more common in the suburban house maps=== Despite the mention of "family homes" in the Yokai's journal, these maps don't have a particularly higher chance of choosing a Yokai as the ghost. As aforementioned, each ghost has an equal chance of being chosen. ===Onryos will avoid lit firelights=== Firelights do not affect how much the Onryo roams or moves, and any open flames will only prevent the Onryo from initiating a hunt in a similar manner to crucifixes. ===Wraiths will avoid salt at all costs=== Wraiths are not "afraid" of salt, and placing salt near it will not affect how much it roams or moves, nor do they actively avoid salt via pathfinding around it; it will simply pass though salt piles without disturbing them, including during hunts, and have no further interactions with them. ===Wraiths can fly and walk through walls=== This references the Wraith's ability to walk through salt piles without disturbing them, and teleporting to players respectively; Wraiths cannot actually fly between floors, hover off the ground during hunts or manifestation events, or move through walls (only doors, which all other ghosts are also capable of doing). ===Moving far enough away from a Moroi can break its curse=== This does not happen in-game, even on the larger maps such as Sunny Meadows or Brownstone High School. The only way to break a Moroi's curse is to take Sanity Medication. Category:Guides fr:Guides/Idées reçues ru:Руководства/Распространённые заблуждения __NOTOC__
title: Guides/Common misconceptions

content: Ghost Orbs are a type of evidence used to help determine the type of ghost haunting the location. ==Mechanics== When a map is loaded in, Ghost Orbs will spawn in the favourite room and float within the room. They look like very small orbs that glide across the screen, generally one at a time. They can be seen through the screen on a Video Camera with night vision, or through any available video feed with night vision, but not through night vision goggles (Tier III Head Gear). Depending on the map and the location of the favourite room, Ghost Orbs can sometimes be seen via the map's CCTVs if the CCTV happens to be facing into the favourite room, though this is usually rare. Ghost Orbs will periodically shift position within the favourite room, forcing players to be more proactive in locating them. When the ghost room changes on difficulties where 'Changing favourite room' is not set to 'None' (such as on Professional, Nightmare, or Insanity), the Ghost Orbs will also move to the new favourite room. ===Rewards=== Filming a Ghost Orb will yield a Ghost Orbs video in the journal, rewarding up to $12 and 12 XP, depending on the tier of the video camera and whether there is a Unique stamp. == Possible ghosts== {| class="article-table" |+ |Banshee |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S Projector |Ultraviolet |- |Dayan |Ghost Orb |EMF Level 5 |Spirit Box |- |Hantu |Ghost Orb |Ultraviolet |Freezing Temperatures |- |Mare |Ghost Orb |Spirit Box |Ghost Writing |- |Obake |Ghost Orb |EMF Level 5 |Ultraviolet |- |Onryo |Ghost Orb |Freezing Temperatures |Spirit Box |- |Raiju |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S Projector |EMF Level 5 |- |Revenant |Ghost Orb |Freezing Temperatures |Ghost Writing |- |Thaye |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S Projector |Ghost Writing |- |Yokai |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S Projector |Spirit Box |- |Yurei |Ghost Orb |D.O.T.S Projector |Freezing Temperatures |} The Mimic induces Ghost Orbs as a "false flag" evidence. Since its main pieces of evidences are Spirit Box, Ultraviolet, and Freezing Temperatures, Ghost Orbs will be unaffected by the number of evidences set (such as on Custom difficulties or Nightmare difficulty), even when it is set to 0. ==Strategies== *Because of the periodical moving of Ghost Orbs, searching for them with a hand-held Video Camera is often better than relying on stationary cameras. In addition, this eliminates back-and-forth trips to the truck, especially on larger maps where sanity preservation is more important. *A player in the truck can view their teammates' Tier I head gear during the initial search for the ghost room to search for Ghost Orbs. *If viewing the camera feed from the truck, camera placement is key to detecting Ghost Orbs. A good strategy for detecting them is placing two video cameras in the corners of the room facing each other to maximize coverage, or using a Tier 2 or 3 tripod to rotate the camera. *Using video cameras to peer through exit doors, garage doors or windows may allow the player to find Ghost Orbs even before entering the investigation area. *Ghost Orbs tend to show up in regular intervals. If none are seen for a long time, try moving the video camera or switch to another one. *In outdoor areas such as on Maple Lodge Campsite, Ghost Orbs can be hard to see in bad weather conditions (primarily rain, snow, and fog). A hint to distinguishing them from snowflakes is that Ghost Orbs tend to float more horizontally and, sometimes, even upwards (compared to snowflakes always falling down). Additionally, snowflakes are generally dark, while orbs will be bright. *It is best to check for Ghost Orbs when the room's lights are off. When on, the brightness may hide the Orbs from sight. ==Gallery== <gallery caltionalign="center"> Mega Guide - Community Request - Phasmophobia.gif|An animation of the Ghost Orb moving pre-Exposition. GhostOrb.png|A pre-Exposition Ghost Orb circled in red. </gallery> ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !January 29, 2020 |Added Ghost Particle as an evidence type. |- !March 12, 2020 |Ghost Particles are now more visible on video cameras. |- !March 14, 2020 |Renamed Ghost Particle to Ghost Orb. |- !March 26, 2020 |Ghost Orbs are now brighter. |- !June 30, 2020 |Ghost Orb positions are now synced between players. |- !August 9, 2020 |Ghost Orbs positions are again no longer synced between players. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !September 26, 2020 |Ghost Orbs now spawn in the Ghost Room rather than moving with the Ghost itself. |- !September 28, 2020 |Ghost Orb positions are once again synced between players. |- !October 18, 2020 |Ghost Orbs will now spawn more towards the middle of the room. |- !0.3.1.0 |Ghost Orbs will now change position periodically within the room. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.4.0 |Ghost Orbs no longer require night vision to be seen in foggy weather. |- |Ghost Orbs can now also be seen via Photo Cameras if it is foggy. |- !0.4.1.0 |Ghost Orbs have been adjusted for better visiblity using night vision. |} Category:Evidence fr:Orbe fantomatique
title: Ghost Orb

content: The Revenant is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. It is widely considered one of the most dangerous ghosts in the game, due to its ability to quickly catch up to players during a hunt. == Behavior == === Hunt === Revenants have very noticeable speed change between roaming and chasing modes. When a Revenant is roaming, it will move at 1 m/s. However, as soon as it detects a player (either visually or through speech/electronics), it will begin to move at 3 m/s (nearly twice the base speed of most other ghosts) and sustains this speed until it reaches the spot where it last detected a player. If and when reverting to roaming mode, the Revenant's speed will slowly decrease over ~2.7 seconds (deceleration rate of 0.75 m/s²) back to its initial value of 1 m/s. Contrary to most other ghosts, the Revenant will not speed up with continuous line-of-sight. == Evidence == == Strengths and weaknesses == These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: A Revenant will travel at a significantly faster speed when hunting their prey. Weakness: Hiding from the Revenant will cause it to move very slowly. == Strategy == Due to the Revenant's power, it is critical to hide as soon as possible and the player must exercise extreme caution as to not give away their position during a hunt. A player will not be able to outrun a Revenant for long before it catches up to them. If you are caught running from a Revenant, items such as tier III Salt or Incense can slow it/ward it off for a few seconds, giving you enough time to create some distance between you and the ghost to hide from it. Tier III Sanity Medication is also a possibility, with the infinite sprint allowing you to match the Revenant's speed for 10 seconds to potentially run to safety. === Identification === While hiding, listen for the ghost's footsteps; if the footsteps are relatively few and far between while the ghost is nearby, then it is most likely a Revenant. Alternatively, if the player already has some sort of escape plan ready, simply letting the ghost detect the player and seeing if it gets a sudden, extremely significant speed boost is a simple way to figure out if it's a Revenant or not - just be mindful of confusing it for a Jinn, which will also speed up suddenly when it sees a player (though a Jinn and Revenant should be easy to distinguish from their roaming speeds). == Trivia == * The word "Revenant" comes from French, originally formed from the verb revenir ("to return"). * According to folklore, a Revenant is a corpse that has been revived from the dead to haunt the living. They originate across many regions and religions, including Old Irish Celtic and Norse mythology. * Many use the term "Revenant" interchangeably for "ghost" or "undead". * The Revenant is widely regarded as one of the most dangerous ghosts in the game, quite apart from its behaviour before 0.8.0 where it would only speed up when having a player in line-of-sight making them extremely easy to escape from by breaking line-of-sight, rather than speeding up to the player's last known location as well. ==History == {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !7 March 2020 |Added Revenant. |- !13 March 2020 |Revenant now requires Fingerprints instead of Bug as one of its evidences. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was EMF Level 5, Fingerprints, and Ghost Writing. |- !rowspan="3" |0.8.0 |Revenants now gain speed boost simply by detecting a player. |- |Revenants now sustain their chasing speed until they reach the last known player location. |- |Speed will now decrease at a rate of 0.75 m/s² after losing player instead of instantly. |} == References == ru:Ревенант fr:Revenant Category:Ghosts

The Obake is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. Described in the journal as a shapeshifter, their primary power is their ability to create unique fingerprints. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== Each time the Obake interacts with a valid surface, it has a 75% chance of leaving fingerprints, instead of the usual 100%. After stepping in salt, it also has a 75% chance each step, instead of 100%, of leaving a footprint, creating no footstep sound when the chance fails. In multiplayer, the missing footprints are not synchronized between players, which may lead to a different number of footprints and footstep sounds for each player. When creating handprints or fingerprints, there is a one-sixth (~16.7%) chance for the Obake to create a unique handprint/fingerprint pattern: *A six-fingered handprint instead of the usual five fingers *Two fingerprints instead of one on light switches, lamps, and TV remotes *Five fingerprints instead of four on keyboards and Prison cell doors When performing a fake hunt ghost event or a Music Box event, the Obake is the only ghost that will sometimes miss a footstep sound. This is very likely a bug. ===Ability=== The Obake occasionally triggers an ability to reduce the remaining time for all existing fingerprints on the map by half. For example, two fingerprints lingering on the map with 40 seconds and 70 seconds before timing out and disappearing are cut in half to 20 and 35 seconds remaining respectively. This ability can be triggered multiple times in quick succession, making it possible for an instance of fingerprints to last for mere seconds before vanishing. ===Hunt=== During a hunt, the Obake will occasionally shapeshift into a different ghost model of the same gender during a flicker. Dead players cannot see this shapeshift. A shapeshift will always occur on the 12th, 27th, 39th, 54th, 62nd, 80th, 105th, 120th, and 132nd flickers (starting with the first flicker-in) of a hunt. *This means that the first shapeshift will happen approximately 7 - 9 seconds after the grace period ends. *This also means that the Obake will not shapeshift at all if the hunt ends prematurely (after the ghost kills a player or when all players leave the investigation area), as it will not have the time to reach the 12th flicker. When shapeshifting, the Obake has an order of models it will use. The first shapeshift of the contract will always be using the first ghost model in the following list. The second shapeshift will then use the second model, the third one the third model, and so on with the list looping on itself. When the Obake reaches its own model in the list, it will shapeshift into itself with a more or less visible posture reset. {| class="fandom-table" style="text-align:center" !Male ghosts !Female ghosts |- | → → → → → → | → → → |}
Both the shapeshifting and the fingerprint duration's reduction will count as an ability in the post-game statistics. ==Evidence== On limited evidence (1/2 evidence) games, an Obake will always have Ultraviolet as one of its evidence types. This does not affect its ability to occasionally not leave fingerprints on a surface. ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: When interacting with the environment, an Obake will rarely leave a trace. Weakness: Sometimes this ghost will shapeshift, leaving behind unique evidence. ==Strategies== If the ghost touches a surface and leaves no fingerprints, then later leaves fingerprints on another surface, or vice versa, this usually points to the ghost being an Obake. If an Obake is suspected, checking a touched surface with a UV Light each time it interacts with a door or the like is prudent to spotting the Obake's special fingerprints, both to maximize the chances of spotting them and to note any instances of them rapidly disappearing. Note that getting normal fingerprints, even several times repeatedly, does not rule out an Obake outright. Although the Obake has a 75% chance to leave Ultraviolet evidence, due to probability, it is possible for the Obake to always leave fingerprints on surfaces that it touches much like any other ghost with Ultraviolet. It's also possible for an Obake to interact with nearby doors frequently enough that it can effectively "mask" an instance where it does not leave fingerprints during one interaction by instead providing them in a separate interaction moments later, as well as conceal its ability to quickly decay its fingerprints. If you are on a zero-evidence run, the Obake will never produce fingerprints nor footprints, and will mainly be identified by spotting its shapeshifting power during a hunt. In multiplayer, one player can stay in the investigation area and hide while other players can look through set-up Video Cameras in safety while the ghost is hunting; in singleplayer, strong looping skills are very favorable in order to maintain sight on it for extended periods of time to catch it changing models during a flicker. * Finding a proper looping spot is important; some spots such as the cars in some suburban houses do not allow the player to see the ghost when looping it, and trying to identify an Obake by looping there is pointless. * This tends to become much easier if the ghost is using the child or Patient 07 model, as those models can also be crawling (or bent backwards in the case of Patient 07), and will reset to the normal standing posture when it shifts, resulting in a sudden, extremely obvious posture change for a single blink. * Usage of Incense or Tier III Salt to hinder the ghost can make the task significantly easier. A Video Camera can also be a powerful tool even in singleplayer, especially if the player cannot see the ghost well due to poor lighting or other reasons; the Camera screen will visibly display "Ghost Shapeshift" if it is pointed at the ghost when it shifts, immediately giving an Obake away. Another way to identify the Obake is by spotting its missing footstep sounds either in a sequence of 3+ steps after it stepped in a single salt pile, or during fake hunt/Music Box events. Both of these methods also work on zero-evidence runs. Additionally, in multiplayer, if a player doesn't hear the same number of footstep sounds than another player for one sequence, then it is an Obake. Note that there are difficulty settings that can change the default chance of a fingerprint being left on a surface, as well as the decay timer. Keep this in mind when playing on such custom difficulties. ==Trivia== *In Japanese folklore, an Obake (お化け), or sometimes "Bakemono" (化け物), is said to be a type of Yokai. Literally, the terms mean a thing that changes, referring to a state of transformation or shapeshifting. These words are often translated as "ghost", but primarily they refer to living things or supernatural beings who have taken on a temporary transformation, and these bakemono are distinct from the spirits of the dead. However, as a secondary usage, the term obake can be a synonym for Yurei, the ghost of a deceased human being. **In English, the ghost is referred to as a general, non-specified type of an Obake. However, if the language is set to Japanese, this ghost type is actually written as 化け狐 (Bake Kitsune), making this ghost specifically a fox Obake. *In a custom difficulty, the Obake's ability to halve the fingerprints' remaining duration also affects "infinite" fingerprints, as their actual duration is not infinite but rather 2,147,483,647 seconds (the maximum value of a signed Int32 data type, used to store integers), or approximately 68 years. This makes it possible for "infinite" fingerprints to disappear if one waits long enough and the Obake uses this ability often enough (around 25 times). ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.4.0 |Added Obake. |- !0.4.1.0 |Increased the chance of the Obake leaving fingerprints from 50% to 75%. |- !0.8.0 |The Obake now has a 1/15 (~6.67%) chance to appear as a different ghost model per flicker during hunts; will happen at least once per hunt |- |} == References == ru:Обакэ fr:Obake Category:Ghosts

The Haunted Mirror is a cursed possession that can be used to locate the ghost's favorite room. ==Mechanics== A haunted mirror has a 1 in 7 chance per contract of being chosen as the cursed possession that will spawn on a default difficulty, with one specific spawn location per map. ===Activation and usage=== The mirror can be while inside the investigation area. It will be automatically deactivated when brought outside. When activated, the haunted mirror will show a view of the favorite room as a sweeping panorama from the center of the room, allowing players to locate the room by cross-reference. This view is a live feed of the room, so any lights turned on, items moved, and equipment or players present in the room will be visible. The only exception is the player's own model. The mirror also gives a faint glow to see into the favorite room, which all players, including the user, can see, even outside of the mirror. This can help confirm rooms, as well as help other players know where the favorite room is. Each usage of the haunted mirror, which includes the animation of raising but not of lowering the mirror, will decrease sanity at a rate of 7.5% per second, or by 20%, whichever is higher. This means that using the mirror for less than ~2.67 seconds will still drain at least 20% sanity. The mirror will crack visually and audibly, triggering a cursed hunt if: *The user's sanity reaches 0% while looking into the mirror *A player activates the mirror while below 20% sanity Once broken, the mirror automatically lowers and cannot be used for the rest of the investigation. ===Rewards=== Taking a photo of a haunted mirror, cracked or not, will yield a photo labelled as Haunted Mirror, and reward up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the tier of the Photo Camera. ==Tips== *On maps such as Brownstone High School where many rooms look very similar, it may be hard to confirm the favorite room; players can place some equipment in the room they suspect to be the favorite room, and see if said equipment is visible in the mirror. Alternatively, players can also memorize small details such as the position and placement of windows, or the tile color, before searching that room. *If the "Eye Adaption" option is on, the player's vision will be significantly darkened for a short while after lowering down the mirror. Turn this option off if it becomes troublesome. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.5.0 |Added Haunted Mirror as a cursed possession. |- !0.5.0.2 |The mirror's view into the favourite room will now keep rotating instead of resetting on every use. |- !0.8.0.3 |The mirror now drains at least 20% sanity per use. |- !0.9.5.0 |The Haunted Mirror will now correctly break straight away if you do not have enough sanity (20%). |}
