content: The Poltergeist is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. It is known for its constant disturbance of the environment around it, throwing items around with great force. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== In general, the Poltergeist is more likely to throw items. During a hunt, the Poltergeist will always throw an item every 0.5 seconds, instead of only having a 50% chance to do so. The Poltergeist's throwing power is of 2 - 6 horizontally and 3 - 6 vertically, while it respectively of 1 - 3 and 1 - 5 for other ghosts. ===Ability=== The Poltergeist will occasionally use an ability that allows it to throw multiple nearby items at once, creating an EMF level 2 reading (the thrown items themselves generate EMF 3). This will decrease the sanity of all nearby players in line-of-sight with the EMF 2 location by 2% per item thrown. The Poltergeist can use this ability even while the lights in its current room are on. <center><gallery> File:Poltergeist Throw 1.gif|Direct throw variant File:Poltergeist Throw 2.gif|Levitation then throw variant File:Poltergeist Throw 3.gif|Levitation then drop variant File:Poltergeist Throw 4.gif|Levitation then throw towards player variant </gallery></center> If there are no items near a Poltergeist, it is unable to use its ability. This does not influence its behaviour towards initiating a hunt. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Poltergeists can throw multiple objects at once, and with great force. Weakness: With nothing to throw, Poltergeists become powerless. ==Strategies== ===Identification=== Taking advantage of the Poltergeist's abilities, one can scatter multiple objects around in its room. If one object is seen being flung with force across the room, or multiple objects are thrown at once, then it is probably a Poltergeist. Note that there is some overlap of how hard regular ghosts can throw and how hard a Poltergeist can throw; this trait is harder to discern in small rooms. *It is generally better to build multiple small piles spread out rather than one large pile; if the Poltergeist is not near the pile, it will not affect the pile at all. It's important to be prudent when suspecting a Poltergeist, and not simply immediately guess it from inconclusive behavior; while it is generally quite active in regards to constantly throwing items, the largely random nature of interactions can cause other ghosts to toss items frequently, matching the activity levels of the Poltergeist at times, especially with more active ghost types like the Oni and Thaye. Likewise, low activity should also not discount the possibility of a Poltergeist. *Remember to turn off the lights to increase activity if attempting to identify it from its normal item throws. *Conversely, turning on lights may help with noticing its ability, as a Poltergeist can use it to throw items even when lights are on, while other ghosts cannot throw items in lit rooms; noticing items getting thrown in lit rooms, especially multiple at once, is a strong indicator of a Poltergeist. With that being said however, certain factors may cause red herrings when observing for this phenomenon, especially if only one object is affected : **Due to the range-based mechanic of ghost interactions, ghosts are technically capable of throwing objects through walls. This means that any ghost in a dark room can throw an item in an adjacent lit room if it is within its interaction range. Players should consider this and verify the ghost's current location before jumping to conclusions. **Make sure that the affected object came from a lit room, and was not thrown in from a neighboring unlit room. This is particularly important in rooms with no clear physical boundaries, such as the exterior areas of Camp Woodwind. The Poltergeist can also be identified during a hunt. By scattering multiple objects in the investigation area, one can witness the ghost's throwing strength and frequency. Witnessing a throw every 0.5 seconds may indicate a Poltergeist, and it will also throw items with a much stronger force, usually throwing items at high speeds across entire rooms or even between rooms; in Camp Woodwind for example, it is capable of throwing items near the entrance directly into the truck! ==Trivia== *A poltergeist is a type of ghost known for causing physical disturbances, such as loud noises and objects being moved or destroyed. Although claims of supernaturally-caused disturbances date back to the 1st century, references to poltergeists specifically became more common in the early 1600s. The word poltergeist comes from the German language words poltern ("to make sound" and "to rumble") and Geist ("ghost" and "spirit"), and the term itself translates as "noisy ghost", "rumble-ghost" or a "loud spirit". A synonym coined by René Sudre is thorybism, from Greek thorybein ("to make noise or uproar; throw into confusion"). *The Poltergeist's ability can drain sanity from dead players, making them having less sanity than before their death if they get revived. ==History== {| class="wikitable" |+ ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !13 March 2020 |Replaced Bug evidence with Ghost Particle. |- !14 April 2020 |Poltergeists now have a chance to throw objects with more force than other ghost types. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was Spirit Box, Fingerprints, and Ghost Orb. |- !0.5.2.0 |Poltergeist’s ability will now reduce the sanity of all nearby players instead of just one player. |- !rowspan = "2"|0.7.0 |The Oni's throw ability has been moved to the Poltergeist. |- |The Poltergeist now has an increased rate of interacting with objects during a hunt. |- !0.9.4.0 |Ghost writing books can no longer be thrown by a poltergeist ability |} ==References== ru:Полтергейст fr:Poltergeist Category:Ghosts
title: Poltergeist

Players are assigned (optional) objectives during their investigations. Each contract has 4 objectives, one of which is always "Find the correct ghost type", and the other three are randomly chosen. Objectives are displayed on the objective board and in the journal (except for "Find the correct ghost type"). The objectives provided are entirely optional, even ignored altogether (forfeiting experience and cash rewards from them), and can be done in any order. Some of them cannot be completed with only starter equipment. ==List of objectives== {| class="article-table" !Objective description!!Condition for completion!!Recommended strategy!!Notes!!Reward (both $ and XP) |- |Find the correct ghost type |The correct ghost type is selected in the journal at the end of the contract. |See Guides/Identifying ghosts | *This is the default objective and is always present. *This will only complete once the contract ends. *Completion of this objective is not shared; the player must select the correct ghost for themselves for the objective to count. |100 (small map)
150 (medium map)
200 (large map) |- |Capture a Photo of any successful reading on an EMF Reader |Capture a photo of the EMF Reader while it is at level 2 or higher. |After finding the ghost's general area, wait for it to interact with or throw an object, then check for an EMF reading on the object using the reader and capture a photo of the reader. | *The EMF Reader malfunctioning during hunts or ghost events also counts. This might be a bug. |25 |- |Capture a photo of the ghost |A photo of the ghost is taken with a Photo Camera when it manifests during ghost events or hunts, or as a D.O.T.S. silhouette. |Take a photo of the ghost during a ghost event, which can be easily forced with the Monkey Paw, the Music Box, or the Summoning Circle. | *During a hunt, the ghost will flicker in and out of view, making it more difficult to take a picture of versus a manifestation. *There is an occasional issue with ghost photos not registering during hunts even when the ghost is clearly in the picture; this is especially true on stairs. *It is not possible to complete this objective if the journal's photo slots are full. *This will stay completed even if the photo is then deleted. |25 |- |Capture a video of a Ghost |Record a video of the ghost with a Video Camera when it manifests during ghost events or hunts, or as a D.O.T.S. silhouette. This can be via a handheld camera or the video feed in the truck. The video should save to the journal for it to count. |Since any activity video-recorded will automatically be saved to the journal, doing this during a hunt is considerably easier compared to capturing a photo, though still risky. | *It is currently possible to complete this objective even if the journal's video slots are full. The Oni is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. It is much more active when players are grouped together, and has also been described as being extremely strong. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== The Oni is more active, interacting with objects more often, when there is at least one player in the same room as it. When performing a ghost event, the Oni: *Cannot perform the mist form event, which involves a physical ball of fog moving towards the player, usually disappearing with a hiss sound upon collision. Note that chasing events can similarly cause a hiss. *Will prefer showing in its full form during a manifestation event as opposed to a shadowy or translucent form. *Will have double the sanity drain of other ghosts when colliding with the target player in a ghost event (so 20% instead of 10%). {| class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed fandom-table" !colspan="2"|Advanced mechanics |- !colspan="2"|WARNING: This data is based on testing and not officially verified. |- !Ghost event chances |The Oni will perform chasing/fake hunt events more frequently than other types of ghost events to replace its inability to perform mist form events. |} ===Hunt===
This image has flashing lights.
During a hunt, the Oni flickers and is on average invisible for shorter and visible for longer compared to most other ghosts: {| class="fandom-table" !Ghost !Visibility length (s) !Invisibility length (s) !Total per-flicker length (s) |- |Oni* |0.02? - 0.50 |0.01? - 0.50? |0.30? - 1.00? |- |Standard ghost |0.08 - 0.30 |0.10 - 0.92 |0.30 - 1.00 |}*Note: values for Oni are measured values and may not be accurate. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Oni are more active whilst people are nearby and will drain their sanity faster when manifesting. Weakness: Oni disappear less often while hunting their prey. ==Strategies== With increased activity in general, the Oni may more readily give up evidence to players, which can make for generous and swift investigations if an Oni is quick to reveal the necessary evidence. Since the Oni cannot perform the mist form ghost event, an Oni can be ruled out if the ghost performs such an event. It must be emphasised that the Oni can hiss as part of a chasing event. A way to differentiate the chasing event is that you will hear the (random) ghost vocalisation and footsteps, and doors in the room will usually close (if any). Also, there are four hiss sounds that a mist form event cannot do; only one hiss sound is shared by mist form and chasing events. While not a particularly aggressive ghost, as the Oni is more likely to trigger ghost events against hunters, it may more rapidly bring the team down to hunt sanity threshold, especially when factoring in its doubled sanity reduction when colliding with players during ghost events. Depending on the circumstances, Sanity Medication can be used to counteract this loss, or defensive items like Incense can be brought in sooner. ==Trivia== *In Japanese folklore, an Oni (鬼) is a kind of demonic ogre or troll, and can be seen as a type of Yokai. They are usually portrayed as hulking figures with horns on their heads, sharp claws and tusks, an odd skin tone such as red, green, or blue, and carrying large iron clubs. In Phasmophobia, Oni do not reflect these depictions or their Japanese origin, and simply uses possible form of American ghost in both appearance and name due to sharing models and a naming pool with other ghost types. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !August 5, 2020
(Part 2) |Added Oni. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was EMF Level 5, Spirit Box, and Ghost Writing. |- !rowspan="3" |0.5.0 |Oni can no longer perform "ghost mist" ghost events. |- |Increased the average activity rate for Oni. |- |Oni now have a higher chance of showing in a full form if it manifests. |- !0.6.2.0 |The bugged airball that appears on certain maps will no longer appear if the ghost is an Oni. |- !rowspan="3"|0.7.0 |The Oni's throw ability has been moved to the Poltergeist. |- |Onis will now double the sanity drain of normal ghosts during ghost events. |- |Increased the duration for the Oni to be visible during hunts. |} ==Notes== Category:Ghosts fr:Oni ru:Они

content: The Obambo is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. Its unique ability revolves around switching between a "calm" state in which it is less aggressive and slower during hunts and an "aggressive" state in which it is more aggressive and faster during hunts. ==Behavior== ===Activity=== The Obambo has two states: "calm" and "aggressive". It always starts in the calm state at the beginning of a contract before switching to the other state 1 minute after an exit door is opened for the first time, then every 2 minutes. The state switch can happen during a hunt. Depending on its state, the Obambo will either have very high activity or low activity, respectively when calm and aggressive. ===Hunt=== The Obambo has a hunt sanity threshold of 10% while in its calm state, and of 65% in its aggressive state. The Obambo will travel at a base speed of 1.445 m/s in its calm state and at a base speed of 1.955 m/s in its aggressive state. The hunt duration will be 20% shorter if the Obambo starts the hunt in the aggressive state. This will apply even if the ghost switches to the calm state mid-hunt. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: While aggressive, the Obambo is quicker to start hunting. Weakness: While calm, the Obambo is slower to start hunting and easier to track. ==Strategies== The Obambo can easily be mistaken for The Twins if one tries to identify the ghost only by its hunt speed, as they both have similar base speeds. A conclusive way to identify the Obambo is to time the duration of a hunt. If the ghost is faster than the standard speed at the beginning of the hunt and the hunt lasts 20% less time than expected, then it is an Obambo. It can also switch states (and thus its base speed) during a hunt, so if the ghost snaps from a slower speed to a faster speed (or vice versa) during a hunt, seemingly for no reason, then it is very likely an Obambo. ==Trivia== *An Obambo, also known as an Obambou, is a supernatural entity belonging to tribes of Central Africa. It is depicted as evil, possessing the power to do evil and good, if it chooses to, having the ability to possess and cause sickness. In some African tribes, an Obambou is referred to as a devil, or as the spirit of someone who was not buried correctly. The Commi tribe believed that when someone is severely ill, an Obambou is a likely culprit which can be determined by a doctor or shaman. The Obambo will reside in the bowels of humans until family, friends, and neighbors surround the possessed person and make noise however they can to drive out the Obambo, by singing, dancing, yelling, or banging things together. *With line-of-sight (LOS) acceleration, the Obambo can achieve a top speed of 3.23 m/s in its aggressive state, making it the joint second fastest ghost in the game behind the Moroi (3.71 m/s) and tied with the Gallu. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.15.1.0 |Added Obambo. |} fr:Obambo Category:Ghosts

content: The 0.4.0 update, also known as the Nightmare update, is a major update to the game released on 25 October 2021. This update adds four new ghosts, a new campsite map, as well as a rework of the difficulty system. A hotfix carrying the same version was later released to fix some issues. == Additions == === Difficulty === ;General *Doors may now start open *Some hiding spaces may be blocked *Sanity Pills now restore different amounts of sanity depending on difficulty ;Nightmare difficulty *Ghosts will not reveal one type of evidence *Ghost room may change *Kills extend the current hunt's duration *Sanity monitor and activity level monitor will be damaged === Gameplay === *When crouching, the player collider now shrinks to match the player model *Ghosts will now disrupt electronic equipment whenever they are visible *Showers and certain furniture can now be interacted with by ghosts *The interactive map monitor now has new player icons *New modifiers to ghost events ===Ghosts=== ;General *New jelly-like/semi-transparent form when manifesting or hunting ;Obake *When interacting with the environment, an Obake will rarely leave a trace *Sometimes this ghost will shapeshift, leaving behind unique evidence *Requires EMF 5, Fingerprints and Ghost Orb as evidence ;Onryo *Extinguishing a flame will make it more likely to attack *Threatening the ghost will make it less likely to attack * Requires Spirit Box, Ghost Orb and Freezing Temperatures as evidence ;Raiju *A Raiju can siphon power from nearby electrical devices, making it move faster *Raiju are constantly disrupting electronic equipment, making it easier to track when attacking *Requires EMF 5, Ghost Orb and D.O.T.S. Projector as evidence ;The Twins * First and only ghost to come in a pair *Either Twin can be angered and initiate an attack on their prey *Will often interact with the environment at the same time *Requires EMF 5, Spirit Box and Freezing Temperatures as evidence ===Hunts=== ;Global chat * Using global chat will now attract the ghost during hunts * Will now only play static sounds when used near the ghost ===Maps === ;Maple Lodge Campsite *First outdoor map *Features more detailed visuals and objects *Features new detailed interactive map in the truck ;Weather *Each contract will now have one of six types of different weather: Clear Skies, Fog, Light Rain, Heavy Rain, Strong Wind, Light Snow *Will affect default temperature ===General=== ==Changes== ===Equipment=== ;Candle * Can now be blown out while the room lights are turned on *Will now extinguish in heavy rain and when thrown ;Fuse Box *Now has two separate light indicators for its on/off state ;Lighter *Can now be blown out by ghosts *Will now extinguish in heavy rain and when thrown *Will now turn off when swapped into inventory ;Ouija Board *Sanity deduction rebalanced **Non-response will now deduct less sanity **A response will now deduct more sanity ;Parabolic Microphone *Will now detect window knocks ;Sanity Pills *Now restore different amounts of sanity depending on difficulty ;Sound Sensor and Motion Sensor *Can now be placed on the floor ===Evidence and ghost traces=== ;Bone *Can now be a random bone from the human body, with new visuals ;Fingerprints *Will now disappear after 60 seconds *New visuals ;Footprints *Will no longer generate if the ghost is not moving *New visuals ;Freezing Temperatures *Now may require a lower reading on the thermometer **Changed to take into account the map weather ===Gameplay=== *The displayed average sanity will now be based on the displayed individual sanities *Several rooms have been renamed * Several photo frames have had their photos replaced *Heartbeat sound volumes are now proximity-based ===Ghosts === ;General *Attic and basement ghosts now roam less often *Footsteps can now only be heard when the ghost is moving *Ghost sounds will now fade out instead of abruptly stopping ;Ghost events * Will now last for at least 1 second * Will now disrupt electronic equipment and global chat, similar to hunts ;Demon *Successful questions will now deduct 40% of sanity as its weakness ===Hunts === *Ghosts now have a slightly faster base and acceleration speed *Hunt duration has been lowered on small and medium maps ===General=== ;Contract selection *All contracts can now be selected at all times *Difficulty will now default to previously played difficulty *Contracts now show a difficulty description instead of a map description *Number of floors is now displayed ;Settings *Changing screen resolution in the journal now offers confirmation ==Bug Fixes == ===From versions released before 0.4.0=== *Fixed grammar and punctuation for English, in the journal, on several pages *Fixed a bug where ghosts would not always do their walking animation for ghost events *Fixed a bug where only the host could turn the car alarm off *Salt placement highlight is no longer visible on walls after looking at the floor *Salt can no longer be placed on the prison staircase inside the wall *“No code in clipboard” and “None” now have translations *Footstep sounds no longer continue after you have stopped moving *The hunt will now end if the host left during the hunt *Having multiple monitors with different resolution scale no longer crashes *Fixed a bug where the ghost could get stuck on the generator *Fixed a bug where the ghost could swap room from the basement to the top floor in professional and nightmare on Ridgeview *Several The Phantom is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. It is known to drain the sanity of those that have sight of it during a manifestation. ==Behavior== ===Activity=== When capturing a photo/video of a Phantom, whether it be in its full form, translucent form, shadow form, or D.O.T.S state, the ghost will physically disappear (but remain in its previous state, e.g. a ghost event) once the capture is successful, and the resulting media will contain no visible ghost and no interference. *If the photo/video was taken during a ghost event, electronic equipment will also cease to malfunction and the player's heartbeats will stop playing. *If the photo/video was taken during a hunt, the ghost will briefly disappear before continuing to physically flash in and out. Being within 10 metres of a Phantom while in pseudo line-of-sight (where heartbeats play) reduces the player's sanity by 0.5%/s. This only applies during ghost events and hunts, and is separate from passive sanity drain. This does not apply during ghost events if the Phantom was made invisible by taking a picture. ===Ability=== The Phantom has an ability where it will choose a random player and travel to a spot within 5 metres of their location (as opposed to a regular roam). This will create an EMF Level 2 reading at the location where the roam ended, at the level of the targeted player's head when uncrouched. This behavior is somewhat similar to that of the Banshee and the Wraith; unlike Banshees, Phantoms do not select a player to target until they die or leave the game, and do not do this as often; and unlike Wraiths, the Phantom physically walks to that point rather than teleporting, and will set off Motion Sensors and disturb Salt on the way to it. ===Hunt=== During a hunt, the Phantom flickers and is on average visible for shorter and invisible for longer compared to most other ghosts: {| class="fandom-table" !Ghost !Visibility length (s) !Invisibility length (s) !Total per-flicker length (s) |- |Phantom |0.08 - 0.30 |0.70 - 1.92 |1.00 - 2.00 |- |Standard ghost |0.08 - 0.30 |0.10 - 0.92 |0.30 - 1.00 |} ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Looking at a Phantom will drop your sanity considerably faster. Weakness: Taking a photo of the Phantom will make it temporarily disappear. ==Strategies== ===Identification=== A good way to identify a Phantom is to observe whether the ghost is invisible for longer intervals on average during hunts (more than 1 second); this will usually indicate a Phantom. Taking a photo of a Phantom is also a fair indicator; the Phantom will not be visible in the photo, and there will be no interference pattern on the photo. If the photo was taken during D.O.T.S or a ghost event, the ghost will also disappear from view. This can be done when the ghost appears in D.O.T.S, when it manifests during a ghost event, or during a hunt; Generally D.O.T.S will be the most reliable, as the ghost is visible less frequently during hunts making photos difficult (and observing its blinking behavior is already enough to identify a Phantom anyways), and ghost events can be quite rare. However, note that on reduced evidence difficulties, a Phantom is not guaranteed to have D.O.T.S as one of its evidence. *Note that occasionally, desync may cause the same effect if the picture is taken right at the end of the ghost event, even if the ghost is not a Phantom. This may make this semi-unreliable; checking with other players about whether the photo is completely clear may help you to arrive at a conclusion (though it is not definite). *This could also happen at the very end of a hunt. *This is better to do with a Summoning Circle or Music Box, since the "ghost event grace period" is generally fixed or predictable. *Taking photos of any ghost from a different floor will not produce interference, though for all other ghosts the ghost will still be visible. *Taking a photo of a Goryo during its D.O.T.S state will also produce no interference, and the ghost to be invisible on the picture. The Phantom's sanity-draining ability could be used to identify it, though this is rarely the main strategy used, as its sanity drain is gradual and not as dramatic as e.g. a Moroi or Jinn's sanity drain, and the player must discern normal sanity drain due to darkness/other factors, from the actual sanity drain caused by a Phantom. If activity (interactions or hunts) is noted in a room far away from its existing favourite room, and a player has recently been in that far-away room, then the ghosts could be narrowed down to a few ghosts, one of these being the Phantom. Note that some ghost events or custom difficulty settings make it normal for any ghost to move far away in this manner. On the other hand, this is more reliable on big maps, since ghost activity for a generic ghost is more likely to be confined to a small area relative to the map size. When it roams to a player, it will leave an EMF level 2 reading where the roam ended, and if the player notices such a reading appearing out of nowhere when there has been no interactions and/or the player is far from the ghost room, then it could be a Phantom. Keep in mind that Wraiths also exhibit this behavior; confirm that it is not a Wraith by placing Salt nearby or by checking whether the EMF reading is located at head level or at ground level using a Tier 3 EMF Reader. ===Survival=== Since the Phantom is visible much less frequently during hunts, it will be harder to track, and players may die as a result of not knowing exactly where it is in time. Specifically, it will be much harder (and not recommended) to loop the ghost, while blinding it using Incense must be treated with caution: stand at the end of a suitably long hallway, and smudge slightly earlier than one would normally do to avoid being caught off guard. Tracking the ghost by its hunting noises is also a considerable strategy when dealing with a Phantom. ==Trivia== *Etymology-wise, Phantom pulls from as early as Greece with the word φάντασμα, or phantasma, which stands for an apparition or a ghost. It could also be translated to something that is not real in general, like a dream or an illusion. As such, phantoms in most tales typically elaborate more on the concept of being an illusion version of something that already exists. The Phantom could be said to be a dream ghost. *Contrary to the journal's description, the Ouija Board is not related to the Phantom in any way gameplay-wise; contracts where the cursed possession is Ouija Board do not have a higher chance of the ghost being a Phantom and vice versa, and it has no relation to a Phantom's ability to wander to players. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !6 March 2020 |Increased the amount of time during which Phantoms are invisible during hunts. |- !7 August 2020 |Visible Phantoms now drain sanity if the player is within line-of-sight nearby. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was EMF Level 5, Ghost Orb, and Freezing Temperatures. |} ==References== ==Notes== ru:Фантом fr:Fantôme Category:Ghosts

Sanity is a value which determines a number of things during gameplay. Sanity usually begins at 100% at the start of a game and decreases as the game progresses. The lower the average sanity, the more likely a ghost is to perform certain actions. ==Mechanics== There are two main readings of sanity in the game: the individual sanity of each player, and the average team sanity of all players. These values can be read at any time on the truck's sanity monitor in all difficulty modes except Nightmare and Insanity, where the screen will be damaged and sanity readings do not function. Each player's displayed individual sanity fluctuate by up to ±2%, while the displayed average sanity has a larger fluctuation depending on the number of players. This fluctuation is only applied to the numbers shown on the screen in the truck, and the actual value used for the game's calculations does not have this fluctuation applied. For example, if a 3-player game has an actual average sanity of 65%, the displayed average sanity will fluctuate between 59% to 71%. At the start of the contract, once an exit door has been opened, players' sanities will begin to be able to drop. Sanity affects things like interactions, ghost events, hunts, and flickering lights; lower average sanity results in increasing relative frequency of such paranormal activity, though as there is a high degree of randomness in these occurrences to begin with, this may not always be readily apparent over the course of an investigation. Individual sanities are not taken into account for these effects in most cases, meaning that a player with a high sanity level going inside may still face more aggressive behavior from the ghost if their partners staying outside all have near zero sanity. Dead players' sanities are not included when calculating the average team sanity. All ghosts have a specific hunt sanity threshold below which they will be able to attempt a hunt. The Banshee is the only ghost which uses its target's sanity to decide whether to hunt, while other effects still use average sanity. When a player reaches 0% sanity, nothing noteworthy occurs, save for the completion of the "Reach 0 sanity" Daily Task if available and not yet completed that day. Sanity cannot go into the negatives. ===Passive drain=== Whether passive sanity drain is applied depends on the status of the lights in the room. In most rooms, sanity drain will be prevented by turning on all of their "main lights", these generally being ceiling light sources controlled by wall switches, rather than lamps or televisions, of which will still provide visibility when turned on but will not block sanity drain. In larger rooms with multiple dark spots (e.g. most hallways in Sunny Meadows Mental Institution), sanity drain will not be blocked entirely even with the lights on, but will instead be reduced to 80% of the normal rate. Additionally, being near a firelight will reduce sanity drain by a variable percentage based on the tier of the item, even if the room's lights are off. Examples of situations that will not prevent passive sanity drain include: *Holding a lit flashlight of any type *Standing in front of an active computer, even though it technically counts as a light source *Turning up the game's brightness Protections against passive sanity drain do not apply to other types of drains. ====Drain rates==== The table below lists the drain rates when the "main lights" are off: {| class="fandom-table" !Map size !Drain during Setup Phase (%/s) !Normal drain (%/s) |- !Small |0.09 |0.12 |- !Medium |0.05 |0.08 |- !Large |0.03 |0.05 |}
The values above are multiplied depending on the difficulty: *1x rate of decay for Amateur. *1.5x rate of decay for Intermediate. *2x rate of decay for Professional, Nightmare, and Insanity. *0x - 2x rate of decay for Custom. The multipliers above are increased by 1 if playing with Blood Moon weather. Playing solo will further halve the rate of sanity drain. ===Ghost-related drains=== *When a player dies, all other living players will lose 15% sanity. Ghosts can drain the player's sanity in several ways: *For all ghosts, if the target for most ghost events (not to be confused with a Banshee target) collides with the ghost or smoke ball, causing it to disappear, that player loses 10% of their sanity. **If the Banshee performs a singing event on its hunt target and they collide with the ghost in this manner, they lose 15% sanity instead. **Colliding with the Oni during any form of ghost event deducts 20% sanity instead. *The Jinn will occasionally use an ability that drains the sanity of a nearby player by 25%, which can only be used if the breaker is turned on. *The Yurei will occasionally use an ability that closes a door in its room and drains the sanity of all nearby players by 15%, which can only be used if there is at least one opened door in its room. *Being cursed by the Moroi, caused by a response on the parabolic microphone or Spirit Box, causes the player to double their passive sanity drain, and lights will not negate this sanity drain nor will Firelights lower it. *Being within 10 metres of a manifested Phantom while in pseudo line-of-sight (where heartbeats play) further drops the player's sanity at a rate of approximately 0.5%/s. *When the Poltergeist uses its ability to throw multiple items, the sanity of nearby players will decrease by 2% times the number of objects thrown. ===Equipment sanity gain/loss=== Sanity can be directly gained or lost through certain equipment: *Sanity Pills: Restores between 0% to 100% of individual sanity depending on the difficulty over a period of time. *Haunted Mirror: Each usage costs 20% sanity or 7.5% per second, whichever is higher. *Monkey Paw: Using I wish to be sane sets all players' sanities to 50%, and increases the passive sanity drain rate by 50%. Using any weather wish reduces sanity by 25%. *Music Box: Being within 2.5 metres of an active music box drains sanity by 2.5% per second. *Ouija Board: Each question asked deducts a certain amount of sanity from the player, depending on the type of question. *Summoning Circle: Each candle lit deducts 16% sanity from nearby players. *Tarot Cards: Drawing the card The Sun restores the player's sanity to 100%, while drawing the card The Moon drains the player's sanity completely, setting it at 0%. In addition, The Wheel of Fortune, can either add 25% sanity (if the card burns green), or deduct 25% (if the card burns red). *Voodoo Doll: Each pin deducts 5% sanity, except for the heart pin which deducts 10%. ===Protections=== *During the Setup Phase, sanity cannot go below 50%, regardless of the source of sanity drain. ==Objectives== *Get an average sanity below 25% ==Tasks== *Reach 0 sanity ($50/50 XP) ==Related difficulty settings== *Starting sanity: Each member's starting sanity *Sanity pill restoration (%): The amount of sanity restored per 'Sanity Pills' *Sanity drain speed (%): The rate your sanity decreases while standing in the dark ==Trivia== *Previously, witnessing a ghost manifestation, humming, or whispering increased sanity by 25%. This was a known bug which was fixed in Post Launch Update #3. *Internally, insanity is used for some mechanics, instead of looking directly at sanity. Insanity is simply 100% - sanity. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !30 January 2020 |Decreased the rate of passive sanity drain. |- !4 February 2020 |More fake ghost sounds will play the lower the sanity an individual player has. |- !6 Februrary 2020 |Increased the rate of passive sanity drain. |- !10 March 2020 |Sanity sounds can no longer be heard by dead players. |- !23 March 2020 |Decreased the rate of passive sanity drain again. |- !11 April 2020 |Sanity no longer decays before any exit door is opened. |- !7 July 2020 |Sanity no longer decays outside the building. |- !21 August 2020 |Decreased the rate of passive sanity drain in medium and large maps. |- !25 August 2020 |Further decreased the rate of passive sanity drain in medium and large maps. |- !11 September 2020 |Removed fake ghost sounds caused by low sanity. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !19 September 2020
(Part 3) |Playing on singleplayer now halves passive sanity drain. |- !0.174 |Lights will now flicker for individual players at lower sanity. |- ! rowspan="3" |0.9.0.9 |Sanity drain from darkness has been reworked; the drain is now based on the status of the lights in the room rather than the amount of light surrounding the player. This improves performance, but reduces accuracy in some cases. |- |Sanity will no longer be drained if a “main” light is on in the room. |- |Large rooms with a lot of dark areas, e.g. the hallways of Sunny Meadows, will instead drain sanity at 80% of the normal rate. |- !0.10.0 |Turning on several light switches in a room, but not all, will now drain sanity at a reduced rate, instead of the full 'sanity drain speed' |} Category:Gameplay fr:Santé mentale ru:Рассудок

content: The Sanity Monitor is a screen in the truck labelled "Team Sanity". It reads both the sanity of individual players as well as the average sanity of the team, both expressed as a percentage. The Sanity Monitor is not perfectly accurate, as it will oscillate by +/-2% in order for sanity to be perceived as more organic. Despite this inherent inaccuracy, it is still critical to gleaming player sanity levels, and by that extent seeing how aggressive the ghost will be; as average sanity decreases, hunts will occur with increasing frequency. The player will always view themselves as the first person listed on the monitor, followed by any other players in the order that they loaded into the map. Players who are yet to load into the map show up on the Sanity Monitor with their name shown as "Loading...", and a hyphen in place of their sanity. Dead players will have their sanity value replaced with a "?" instead. Players who have left the game will disappear from the sanity monitor entirely. In Nightmare and Insanity difficulties, the Sanity Monitor is damaged, and will give random readings, becoming essentially useless. Use of an Ouija Board, if available, is thus the only feasible way to get a good estimate of one's current sanity. Category:Truck Equipment fr:Moniteur de Santé mentale ru:Монитор рассудка

Salt is a purchasable item used to place salt piles. Ghosts can step in the salt pile, which can be used to check for Ultraviolet evidence. ==Usage== A salt container can be used to salt piles on the floor. Each salt container can be used 2-3 times, allowing a maximum of 6-9 salt piles to be placed per game with 3 salt containers. Salt piles can be stacked in the same spot. When a ghost walks over a salt pile, it will leave an indent in the pile. This can happen any time, regardless of the ghost being invisible or not. Within the next few seconds after the salt has been stepped in, when the ghost moves, it will create audible footsteps (similar to footsteps during a hunt), and if it has Ultraviolet evidence, it will also leave temporary footprints visible under UV light where it chooses to roam. Wraiths and enraged Gallus will never leave any imprint on salt piles, walking over them as if they do not exist. Players cannot leave an imprint in salt piles or generate footprints. ===Tier I=== The Tier I salt shaker has two uses, and places a small, circular pile of white salt on the ground. A sole-like imprint will be left in the pile once a ghost steps over it. ===Tier II=== The Tier II salt jar has three uses, and places a long pile of pink salt, making it easier for the ghost to step on. The middle of the salt pile will disappear when the ghost steps on it. ===Tier III=== The Tier III salt jar has three uses, and places a long pile of black salt, identical in size to Tier II salt. If the ghost steps on a black salt pile during a hunt, its speed will be reduced by 50% for 2 seconds. If it steps on another black salt pile before the 2 seconds are over, the timer will be reset but the ghost will not be further slowed down. If the ghost steps on the salt pile outside of a hunt, it will turn around and go back the way it came briefly. It has no effect during ghost events. As Wraiths and enraged Gallus ignore salt entirely, none of these effects will apply to them even if they physically pass through it. ===Rewards=== Filming a salt pile being disturbed will yield a Disturbed Salt video, rewarding up to $12 and 12 XP depending on the tier of the Video Camera and whether there is a Unique stamp. ==Tips== *If placed strategically, salt can be used to track exactly where the ghost is walking after it has been located, potentially to the players' advantage. *Placing salt close to external corners in wide hallways or rooms with acute angles will maximize the chances of the ghost stepping in the salt. This is because the ghost is programmed to take the shortest route to its next waypoint when wandering, therefore it is more likely to navigate by hugging corners and other turns. *Dropping a UV Light near the salt pile will illuminate any footprints present without having to hold the UV light. *Using tier III salt can help in taking ghost photos during hunts as it slows down the ghost. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !? | Added salt. |- !25 March 2020 |Salt can now be placed on the ground. |- !1 April 2020 |Changed the salt pile model to 3D, which will flatten when a ghost walks in it. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !22 September 2020 |Wraiths no longer interact with salt during hunts. |- !? |Ghosts can no longer disturb salt during hunts. |- !0.3.0 |Changed the salt pile and salt shaker models. |- !0.6.2.0 |Increased the limit of salt shakers per contract from 2 to 3. |- !0.8.0 |Wraiths no longer interact with salt at all. |- ! rowspan="3" |0.9.0 |Salt now has 3 tiers. |- |Salt will now only reveal footprints if the ghost has Ultraviolet evidence. |- |Ghosts can now disturb salt piles during hunts. |}

The Onryo is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. The Onryo is noted to be wary of fire; however, when the fires go out, beware its vengeance, for an Onryo may decide to hunt once there are no flames keeping it at bay. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== The Onryo's flame blowing frequency increases the more dead players there are: {| class="fandom-table" !Number of dead players !Chance of blowing out the flame !Chance of blowing out the tier II firelight !Cooldown before the Onryo can attempt to blow out the flame after lighting (not first lighting) |- |0 |66.67% |96.3% |20 - 80 seconds |- |1 |75% |98.43% |20 - 60 seconds |- |2 |80% |99.2% |20 - 40 seconds |- |3 |83.33% |99.54% |20 seconds |}
The Onryo cannot light any fire sources (fireplaces, campfires, and candles) naturally, but can be forced into doing so with a Voodoo Doll. Contrary to the journal's description, flames do not make the Onryo more likely to leave a room. ===Ability=== Counterintuitively, flames can both prevent hunts and cause a hunt: *If the Onryo attempts a hunt within 4 metres of any type of flame (e.g. firelight, igniter, campfire, etc.), it will blow out the flame instead, and the hunt will fail. This does not restart the hunt cooldown timer, unlike a crucifix. If both a crucifix and a flame are within range, the flame will take priority over the crucifix for preventing the hunt. **The Onryo's hunt attempts also override a flame's individual cooldowns, making it capable of blowing out a firelight within 30 seconds of its first lighting, or within 20 seconds of its subsequent lightings. Note that a tier III firelight's current cooldown is paused if it is turned off by the player or an Onryo's hunt attempt. *Every third flame that the Onryo blows out will cause it to attempt to initiate a hunt, regardless of current average sanity. This hunt can be blocked by normal prevention methods (e.g. a crucifix) or another flame. **Note that there can be a delay of up to 6 seconds before the hunt actually initiates. **A flame preventing a hunt or blown out during a hunt will count towards the three-flame rule. **Whether it was the same item being blown out does not matter; it can be the same firelight blown out 3 times, 3 firelights each blown out 1 time, or any other combination. **If the third flame is blown out during a hunt or an Incense's cleansing effect, the hunt attempt will be canceled. However, if the third flame is blown out during a hunt cooldown or a ghost event, the Onryo will use its ability at the end of the cooldown or the event. Consequently, there are several situations (non-exhaustive) which might occur: *One firelight and one crucifix is within range of the Onryo, and it blows out the firelight as its third flame. The ability is triggered, but the crucifix will prevent the hunt, losing one charge. *One firelight and one lit igniter is within range of the Onryo, and it blows out the firelight as the third flame. The igniter will prevent the hunt and be blown out. *One firelight is within range of the Onryo, and it attempts to hunt naturally. The firelight prevents the hunt and is blown out. ===Hunt=== The Onryo has a hunt sanity threshold of 60% by default. When it is near a flame, this threshold is decreased to 40%. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Extinguishing a flame can cause an Onryo to attack. Weakness: When threatened, this ghost will be less likely to hunt. ==Strategies== The Onryo's aversion to fire, while a powerful tool against it, does come with risks of its own. However, with sufficient firelights and diligent relighting of them whenever they're extinguished, the Onryo may be kept from hunting indefinitely, which may also serve as identification for the ghost on reduced evidences difficulties. On the other hand, only having one lit firelight within range of it increases the risk of it hunting as a result of blowing it out if said firelight is being re-lit, or other flame sources are being activated nearby. The latter is even riskier if one or more players have died, as the Onryo will blow out firelights in increasing frequency. Players should consider whether having flames lit near the ghost is worth it to prevent hunts, or if they should be disregarded outright and simply play around the Onryo's heightened hunt threshold. ===Identification=== The Onryo can be tested using several ways, by looking for flame priority, preventing hunts with flames, or the three-flame rule: *Place one crucifix in the ghost's area, then a firelight directly on top. **Note that this is less reliable with Tier II or III crucifixes as they have a range that is greater than or equal to the flame range. *Place two crucifixes in the ghost's area, then multiple firelights spread out and covering the crucifixes' ranges. When sanity is deemed low enough, keep the firelights lit in a timely manner. *If the crucifix is activated without the firelights going out first, then it is not an Onryo. *If the ghost seems to not hunt with multiple firelights active, or hunts in an area where no firelights are lit, then it may be an Onryo. Due to the Onryo's hunt prevention mechanics, having a flame blown out within 30 seconds of its first lighting, or within 20 seconds of its subsequent lightings (or an igniter's first lighting), confirms an Onryo. This also makes the Onryo the only ghost that can blow out a tier I igniter's match, which only lasts 10 seconds. Keep in mind that tier III firelights pause the current cooldown if they are turned off by a player or an Onryo's hunt attempt. The third method is to keep track of the number of flames the ghost blows out, and observe whether the ghost tries to hunt every third flame. In Sunny Meadows, several lit candles can be found in the chapel, which ghosts can blow out. If the ghost is located there and hunts very early (and is otherwise not a Demon), then it may be an Onryo. The Onryo can be ruled out if the ghost lights up a fire source such as a fireplace, a campfire, or a candle. The Onryo is one of two ghosts (the other being the Hantu) for which you can collect all three pieces of evidence without excluding The Mimic. Therefore, before concluding you're dealing with an Onryo, confirm it using the methods mentioned above and/or check whether the ghost leaves Ultraviolet evidence. If it does, you have The Mimic instead. ==Trivia== *In Japanese mythology Onryō (怨霊, meaning 'vengeful spirit') are the spirits of people who died bearing some form of hatred for the living. Unlike the game version, they could cause fires and had no specific weakness to it. *Onryō have been popularised in modern times by the J-Horror genre with TV, films, and books series such as Ju-On (The Grudge) and Ringu (Ring). *Goryō are normally catagorised under Onryō in most Japanese texts since they are spirits that seek some form of vengence against the living. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.4.0 |Added Onryo. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.9.4.1 |Smudge Sticks now block the Onryo's hunt ability |- |If the Onryo is hunting and blows out a third candle, it will now cancel the Onryo hunt ability and no longer start a hunt after that hunt ends |} ==References== ru:Онрё fr:Onryo Category:Ghosts

10 Ridgeview Court (or simply Ridgeview) is a small map in Phasmophobia. A two-story, four-bedroom house with a garage and basement, Ridgeview presents a spacious living area, giving way to more congested linear hallways. However, the presence of closets and multiple sub-rooms to dive into provides plenty of safety during a hunt. ==Structure== Ridgeview has four bedrooms, four toilets, a garage and a basement, among other rooms. ===Layout tips=== *The "Master Bedroom" consists of the bedroom itself, the attached bathroom, and the closet that can be accessed through said bathroom. *The small hallway leading to "Master Bedroom" is considered part of "Kitchen". *The Upstairs Hallway includes both the main hallway that turns a corner and leads to "Boys Bedroom" and "Bathroom" and the straight hallway partially separated by a wall that leads to "Teen Boys Bedroom", "Girls Bedroom", and "Upstairs Toilet". *In order to fully prevent passive sanity drain in the Foyer, the light switch that turns on the lamp outside at the entrance door has to be turned on as well. *There is a bug where the computer in Hallway needs to be turned on to prevent passive sanity drain in that room. See Third-party tools for a list of detailed map viewers that players may use. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 10 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Ridgeview: *Living Room, behind stacked storage crates in corner by fireplace *Garage, lockers near entrance door *Garage, lockers along far wall *Basement, lockers directly across from door *Basement, behind stacked storage crates in corner (after entering and turning left twice) *Master Bedroom, behind storage crates in walk-in closet *Upstairs Hallway, closet at top of stairs *Upstairs Hallway, closet between boy's bedroom and bathroom *Upstairs Hallway, closet between girl's bedroom and teen boy's bedroom *Boy's Bedroom, closet across from bed Depending on the difficulty, a number of these hiding spots will be randomly blocked by bulky items or have the concealing elements removed, preventing players from hiding in them: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 5 *Professional: 7 *Nightmare/Insanity: 8 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None Several more unofficial furniture-based hiding spots are available such as: *Kitchen, behind the fridge *Hallway, behind the piano or the computer Looping the ghost may be performed around the dining table. The ghost can also be looped around multiple shelves in the Basement (the collection of shelves on the right side opposite one of the Fuse Box locations is the easiest spot). ==Bone locations== Bones spawn randomly, but will only spawn in areas that a ghost can also walk on. ;Examples

"The most common way of accidentally summoning a ghost is with a Ouija Board, so you may come across these during your investigations. Be careful if you choose to use it as they have been known to lower your sanity. To use one, activate it and then ask a question with your voice." The Ouija Board is a cursed possession in Phasmophobia. It can be used to communicate with the ghost at the cost of sanity. ==Mechanics== A Ouija Board has a 1 in 7 chance per contract of being chosen as the cursed possession that will spawn, with one specific spawn location per map. A Ouija Board can be with an empty hand. Swapping to another item will cause the Ouija Board to drop from the inventory. ===Activation=== The Ouija Board can be activated by with it if the player is not holding it, or it directly while holding the board. The planchette will drop down onto the board, signifying that the board has been activated. There is currently a bug where an ongoing setup phase will only be canceled if a valid phrase has been recognized and not upon activation of the board. ===Questioning=== Players can choose to either use voice chat or a text-based UI to ask questions. *If using voice chat, once activated, the Ouija Board will respond to voice input within 5 meters of it. *If using the text-based UI, the UI will appear upon activation. Players can then click to select one of 3 categories, then select a category-specific question, or say goodbye. The player cannot exit the UI without saying goodbye or the board breaking, but the board can be thrown out while holding it. The player asking the question must be within the investigation area to ask questions, but does not have to be in the ghost room (nor the ghost's current room). If the question is recognized, the planchette will move to answer the question, and an EMF Level 2 reading will be generated around the Ouija Board. If the ghost has EMF Level 5 as evidence, there is a 33% chance for it to appear per question asked. Whether a ghost is "shy" or not does not affect its ability to respond through the Ouija Board. If the Ouija Board is asked a question but nothing happens, then either the board is not activated or the phrase was not recognized. There is a cooldown of ~2.5 seconds for clicking via text-based UI, while there is no cooldown time for voice chat, aside from any voice recognition limitations. ===Deactivation=== To deactivate the Ouija Board, any nearby player must say "Goodbye", which will make the planchette disappear. The Ouija Board can then be left alone safely. The Ouija Board will also deactivate automatically if the player holds the board and exits the investigation area. The Ouija board will burn and break apart, initiating a cursed hunt, if: *There is no player within 5 meters of a still-active board (leaving this range applies) *The player currently asking questions has less sanity than required to "pay" for the question *The phrase "hide and seek" (or similar) is said (see Questions) ===Rewards=== Using a Photo Camera to take a photo of the Ouija Board will yield a photo labelled as Ouija Board, and reward up to $7 and 7 XP. When the ghost answers a question by moving the planchette, a Ouija Board video and a Ouija Board sound can be captured using a Video Camera and a Sound Recorder. Each of these pieces of media will reward up to $7 and 7 XP. ==Questions== There are at least 13 different types of questions (including two jokes) that can be asked: *Location *Proximity *Age *Death *Room count *Sanity *Method of death *Bone location *Hide and seek *Feeling *Purpose *Joke *Shyness Note that if a question does not get a response, it is not considered a valid question. A few example questions: *"Are you from [Country/State Name]?" *"Are you [single/married]?" *"What is your name?" {| class="fandom-table" |+List of questions. This list is not exhaustive. !Category !Description !Questions !Answers !Sanity drain !Has text option |- |Location |Responds with the room that the ghost is currently in. This does not answer the favorite room, unless ghost is currently there. | *"Where are you?" *"What is your favorite room?" *"Where is your room?" *"What is your room?" |The room's name |50% |Yes |- |Proximity |Instead of providing the ghost's current room, this simply says whether the ghost is in the same room as the person asking the question. | *"Are you here?" *"Are you close?" |Yes/No |20% |No |- |Bone location |Responds with the name of the room where the bone is located will be given.

The Prison is a medium map in Phasmophobia, the second of its size type to be added to the game. The Prison bears a dilapidated, spartan environment, with long corridors subdivided with metal bars that make encounters with ghosts unnerving. ==Structure== Prison contains a variety of rooms, including two prison blocks containing all the jail cells, offices of various types, an infirmary room, visitation rooms, and more. Though slightly smaller than Brownstone High School, the Prison can be just as dangerous: a safe location during a hunt may be a great distance away, demanding a long run, compounded with the ghost's favourite room being able to be located in many areas that have only one or two routes of escape, including congested catwalks and entire cell block floors. Incense may be essential for survival in these situations, especially against ghosts with a speed advantage. Many parts of the building have light switches located in nearby separate rooms, requiring players to head away from them to manipulate the location's lighting. This can occasionally cause confusion with the ghost manipulating switches that illuminate other rooms. ===Layout tips=== *There are exit doors at the end of both prison blocks that lead into an outdoor courtyard, providing an alternative access route. This outside area also prevents passive sanity drain. *Each cell block consists of 5 distinct rooms. The first floor consists of three rooms: the left row of prison cells, the right row of prison cells including the small control room, and the open area in between, which includes the area up to the inner steel gates. The second floor consists of two rooms, split evenly down the middle with each row of cells in one room. *The computer keyboards in the cell block control rooms control the lights for the entire cell block. *The two upstairs rooms with hospital beds (separated by a single door) are considered by the game as one room called "Infirmary". *The upstairs room named "Infirmary Hallway" consists of 4 smaller "sub-rooms", including the small hallway leading to "Cafeteria Security" and the small room that may spawn a fuse box. *The rooms called Main Hallway and Office Hallway cannot be chosen as a ghost room. *The light switch for the Main Hallway is found in the Central Control room. *The following rooms count as dark rooms and hence will drain sanity with 80% of the rate, even with all room lights being on: **Entrance, Main Hallway, Cafeteria and Office Hallway. See Third-party tools for a list of detailed map viewers that players may use. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 4 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Prison: *Entrance, lockers at the far back of the room *Cafeteria, behind multiple garbage cans on the left (only if there are 4 garbage cans) *Infirmary, lockers at the far right end of the first room *Cafeteria Security, on the balcony area, behind two garbage cans, directly on the right when coming from the inside area Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots may be blocked by the presence of bulky items or their concealing elements removed: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 1 *Professional: 2 *Nightmare/Insanity: 3 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None ==Tips for surviving hunts== See also: Guides/Surviving a hunt *Due to the extremely limited hiding spots especially relative to the map's huge size, players should have an escape route ready, and be on the lookout and ready to run as soon as a hunt starts; if escaping from their current position isn't feasible e.g. in the Cafeteria which is nearly impossible to escape before the grace period ends, players should have Incense handy to protect themselves. *If the player is near the cell blocks when a hunt begins, the cells are actually relatively safe despite looking like awful hiding spots on paper, as the ghost cannot see through cell walls (though if one is unlucky, the ghost can still randomly wander into a cell and kill the player there); this even allows the player to observe the ghost's hunt behavior freely to try and identify it. *Due to the map's large size, a true hiding spot might not even be needed, and oftentimes it is simply enough to sit in a room far away from the ghost, as it's extremely unlikely the ghost will wander to your location just by chance if it hasn't detected you; a tier III Parabolic Microphone can be used to keep track of the ghost's location to ensure this doesn't happen (or give you ample warning to run if it does happen). *While not as secure as official hiding spots, there are some unofficial hiding spots that can work decently well, especially since these spots are always available unlike official hiding spots which may be blocked off; some examples include: **Behind some lockers in the Infirmary Hallway, near a possible fuse box location **Behind the large chair in the Warden's Office **Behind the large chair in the Chief Security Office **In a corner behind a table in the Main Office **Inside stalls in the Office Toilet **Behind some lockers in Inspection **Behind some lockers in Visitation Security ==Bone locations== Every contract, one bone will spawn randomly in the ghost's navmesh (where the ghost is able to walk). ;Examples
Bone prison visitationsecurity.jpg|A bone in Visitation Security. Bone in Prison, First Floor, Cafeteria 1.jpg|On the cafeteria floor. Bone in Prison, Second Floor, Warden's Office. On the ground next to the desk..jpg|On the ground next to the desk in the warden's office.
==Cursed possession locations== All cursed possessions will spawn in the entrance hallway. File:Prison-Mirror.png|The Haunted Mirror spawns under a row of chairs. File:Prison-Circle .png|The Summoning Circle spawns at the end of the hallway. File:Prison-Cards.png|The Tarot Cards spawn in the blue crate. File:Prison-Music .png|The Music Box spawns in the black crate. File:Prison-Doll.png|The Voodoo Doll spawns on the table between the crates. File:Prison-Board.png|The Ouija Board spawns on the floor behind the table with the crates. Monkeypaw prison.jpg|The Monkey Paw spawns besides the blue crate on the table. ==Trivia== *The prison's name is "N. E. More Penitentiary" as indicated on a sign above the front door and a notice sign in Entrance. *Prison has the second least amount of official hiding spots in the game, totaling only four across the entire map (the map with the least being Brownstone High School). However, like Brownstone High School, some rooms have usable unofficial hiding spots (e. g. behind shelves, tables or in cells/toilet stalls). *The assets for this map can be found here. *The light switch in the control room located on the bottom right of each cell block counts as a main room light (for sanity drain prevention) for the hallway of that cell block, and not for the row of cells. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.2 |Prison was added to the game. For the next several updates, it would always appear in the contract selection. |- !0.28.6.5 |Optimisations to significantly improve load times and fps |- !0.29.6 |Truck map has been flipped to make them less confusing to navigate |- !0.4.1.0 |Weather can now come through the grated ceilings in the cell blocks |- !0.5.1.0 |Light control computers now change their colour to green when lights are on, and red when off |- !0.6.1.0 |Added 4 additional hiding spots, including 2 in Cafeteria/upstairs deck, and 2 additional lockers in Entrance and Infirmary |}
