content: The Moroi is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. Its ability to "curse" players to lower their Sanity, combined with its increased speed at low sanity levels, can cause it to become the fastest ghost in the game. ==Behaviour== ===Ability=== The Moroi has an ability to "curse" a target through the following ways: *By successfully obtaining a response from the Spirit Box; this will curse the person who "caused" the response, either by asking questions or triggering the failsafe. *By hearing paranormal sounds through the Parabolic Microphone. *By successfully recording any sound with the Sound Recorder. When a player is cursed, their passive sanity drain is doubled and being in a lit area will no longer prevent sanity drain (i.e. the player is considered in the dark at all times). Leaving the investigation area will still pause the sanity drain, and firelights will still mitigate the sanity drain. Consuming Sanity Medication removes the curse for that player. Players that have been cursed before in the contract can be cursed again. Multiple players can be cursed at the same time, but curses do not stack on a single player. ===Hunt=== The Moroi's speed is dependent on the average sanity, and will change during a hunt according to the current average sanity. The base speed increases by an average of 0.083 m/s for every 5% average sanity below its average hunt threshold of 50%. The list below shows each possible base speed for the Moroi: {| class="article-table" |+ !Average sanity % !Base ghost speed |- |≥ 45% |1.5 m/s |- |40% - 45% |1.583 m/s |- |35% - 40% |1.66 m/s |- |30% - 35% |1.749 m/s |- |25% - 30% |1.832 m/s |- |20% - 25% |1.915 m/s |- |15% - 20% |1.998 m/s |- |10% - 15% |2.081 m/s |- |5% - 10% |2.164 m/s |- |0% - 5% |2.25 m/s |} When using an Incense during a hunt, the duration where the Moroi cannot see nor kill players is 7.5 seconds instead of 5. ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: The weaker their victims, the stronger the Moroi becomes. Weakness: Moroi suffer from hyperosmia, weakening them for longer periods. ==Evidence== On limited evidence (1/2 evidence) games, the Moroi will always have Spirit Box as one of its evidence types. ==Strategies== Given the Moroi's ability to drain sanity after responding through the Spirit Box, it is recommended to refrain from utilizing the Spirit Box after obtaining the first response. If necessary, only the player who previously asked questions should use the Spirit Box again. Usage of Parabolic Microphones should also be limited, and if required for an objective, should also be done by the player that previously used the Spirit Box. The Moroi only curses the player through a Sound Recorder if the paranormal sound is recorded, not if you hear it; it's possible to avoid getting cursed by stopping the recording prematurely or turning off the Sound Recorder before the sound is recorded, if one wishes to preserve their sanity. Due to the Moroi's ever increasing speed the lower the player's sanity drops, managing sanity levels is more important than ever; Sanity Medication should be used as soon as possible after a player finds out they have been cursed, lights should be kept on where possible, and in dark rooms (where lights don't stop sanity drain completely), or if the player cannot turn on lights due to any reason (limited by the fuse box, lights broken by ghost event etc), Firelights should be used judiciously to slow down sanity drain. ===Identification=== The easiest way to identify a Moroi is by paying attention to the ghost's speed: *Listen for the ghost's speed both over multiple hunts and during a given hunt, as average sanity lowers; a ghost that speeds up over the course of multiple hunts as average sanity lowers, or gradually speeds up during wandering when all players are hiding, could be a Moroi. Remember to take into account line-of-sight acceleration, if applicable. Note that the Hantu will increase in speed if the fuse box is left off as the temperature in the map decreases, but it does not speed up through line-of-sight; either keep the fuse box turned on to avoid misidentification, or make sure that the ghost does not have the Hantu's signature freezing breath during a chase with the power off. *As an alternate strategy, methods to quickly manipulate sanity can be utilized during a hunt. As the Moroi's roaming speed changes in real time as average sanity changes, a significant change of it (via Sanity Medication, or some cursed possessions which can quickly drop sanity) while it's hunting will cause the Moroi to abruptly speed up or slow down, potentially identifying it in the span of a single hunt. All players should be hidden (or, most optimally, having been hidden from the start) to avoid the speed change being confused for some other natural speed changes e.g. a ghost's acceleration/deceleration from line-of-sight or the Revenant's losing track of players, and to wait a few seconds in order to get a read on its roaming speed before using the cursed possession/Sanity Medication afterwards. **Additionally, a marked degree of coordination in multiplayer is required, as a single player's sanity changing will not affect the average sanity as much; players will have to e.g. use Sanity Medication at the same time, or take turns asking questions to a Ouija Board, in order to change average sanity enough to cause the Moroi to exhibit a definitive speed change. **A few other ghosts may change speeds even without seeing a player (Raiju when near electronics, Hantu roaming between different-temperature rooms); make sure the ghost isn't changing speeds on its own before performing the test. *If starting a cursed hunt early during the contract, especially with cursed possessions that can cause cursed hunts without draining sanity, it is extremely likely that the average sanity will be above 45% and the Moroi's roaming speed will be its minimum 1.5 m/s, noticeably slower than most ghosts. Keep in mind The Twins will have a base speed of 1.5 m/s when starting a hunt at its present location, which is indistinguishable from a Moroi's speed when above 45% sanity. Another way to identify the Moroi is by smudging it during a hunt. The Moroi will be blinded for 7.5 seconds instead of 5; noticing a blinding time longer than usual can indicate a Moroi. This will be more easily noticeable with Tier II and Tier III Incense as they affect the ghost's speed, causing a change in its footsteps during the blinding effect. When the sanity monitor is available, one can also identify a Moroi based on its ability: if your sanity has drained much more than normal after a Spirit Box response, a paranormal sound on the parabolic microphone, or a sound record with the sound recorder, especially if you've been in fully lit rooms and/or holding a Firelight for extended periods of time, then you have most likely been cursed by a Moroi. Take into account sanity drain from ghost events, if any, as well as if you have used any cursed possessions throughout the mission. ==Trivia== *The moroi (plural idem) are a type of vampires in Romanian folklore who practiced vampirism while being still alive (as opposed to strigoi who became vampires after death). In modern usage, moroi simply means "ghost" in Romanian. *Unlike most other ghosts with speed bonuses, the Moroi accelerates with continuous line-of-sight of a player. Below 5% average sanity, the maximum speed of a Moroi is 3.71 m/s, making it the fastest ghost in the game. *The Moroi is the ghost with the fastest potential speed in the game, reaching a staggering 6.4 m/s speed under the following conditions: **The ghost speed is set to 150% **The weather is Blood Moon **Average sanity is 0-5% **Continuous LoS for at least 13 seconds ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.6.2.0 |Added Moroi. |- !0.8.0.6 |The Moroi's speed now changes when the average sanity moves into a different bracket. |- !0.9.0 |Incense will now have an extra 50% duration against Moroi. |} ==References== ==Notes== Category:Ghosts fr:Moroï ru:Морой
title: Moroi

content: The Shade is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. Noted as being shy ghosts, a Shade will lower its activity in the presence of multiple players. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== On average, the Shade is less likely to perform interactions than other ghosts. The Shade is less likely to perform ghost events at high sanity. At 100% average sanity, it has a 0% chance of successfully performing an event. This success rate increases by 2% per percentage of average sanity lost; at an average sanity of 50%, an attempted ghost event will always succeed. When it performs a ghost event, the Shade has a higher chance of appearing as a shadow. If the ghost is made to appear using a Summoning Circle, a Music Box, or a Monkey Paw, it has a 50% chance of appearing as a black shadow rather than in its full form while in the ghost event stage. It will return to a fully visible form when the hunt begins. {| class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed fandom-table" !colspan="2"|Advanced mechanics |- !colspan="2"|WARNING: This data is based on testing and not officially verified. |- !Ghost event chances |The Shade cannot perform singing events. Instead, it has a 60% chance to perform a mist form event overall. The other event mechanics (stated above) remain true at the same time. |} ===(In)abilities=== If at least one person is in the same room as a Shade, it will be unable to perform interactions (including the fuse box and when players try to force an interaction through the Voodoo Doll), ghost events, or initiate hunts, regardless of average sanity. It may still perform these actions if it happens to wander into a room without players. Since interactions occur in a range, the Shade can still "reach" into the player's room from another room to interact with objects. {| class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed fandom-table" !colspan="2"|Advanced mechanics |- !colspan="2"|WARNING: This data is based on testing and not officially verified. |- !Object throws |When performing an object throw, the Shade cannot use the variant where the object levitates before being thrown towards a player. This also applies during hunts. |- !Interactions during hunts |When the Shade is in the same room as a player during a hunt, though it can interact with doors normally like any other ghost, it is unable to blow out flames. |} ===Hunt=== The Shade can only hunt below an average sanity of 35%, lower than most other ghosts. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Shades are much harder to find. Weakness: The ghost will not enter a hunt if there are people nearby. ==Strategies== Due to the Shade's aforementioned shyness, the lack of interactions may give it away, or players may become frustrated at the ghost not producing evidence, though this also makes them one of the safer ghosts to encounter, as their shyness also extends to hunts. Try keeping everyone out of the ghost room, as well as using Incense or specific cursed possessions that will increase the chance of the ghost interacting with the environment. Turning off the lights in the ghost's room may also help. Given the Shade's inability to hunt in a room with players, one can be tested for in Nightmare/Insanity difficulty simply by lowering the average sanity close to zero, and having players stand in the ghost's current room and rooms directly adjacent. If it refuses to hunt or hunts only from a room without players, then it may be a Shade; players should identify nearby escape routes and/or prepare Incense before testing this, as the ghost may hunt in the same room as a player if it's actually not a Shade, which can be very dangerous, especially since a Shade shares two evidence types with a Jinn which is extremely difficult to escape from if the fuse box is on, and a Revenant which is almost certain death if it hunts in the same room as a player. In singleplayer on Nightmare or Insanity difficulty, one way to identify a Shade is to drop the average sanity to zero, before using two Sanity Medications to restore the player's sanity to 50%, then allowing a small drop of sanity for a few seconds within the investigation area before stopping it via room lights (ideally hiding far away or on a different floor to prevent witnessing ghost events that may drain sanity). A ghost that refuses to hunt at this sanity may indicate that the ghost is a Shade. If trying to identify a Shade by its hunt sanity threshold, keep in mind a Deogen and aged Thaye will also have low hunting sanity thresholds, though a Deogen is extremely easily distinguishable from its hunting behavior, and a Thaye will initially have a much higher sanity threshold, and be very active in stark contrast to a Shade; a Mare will also have a similarly low sanity threshold when the lights in its ghost room are on; turn it off to raise its sanity threshold and prevent mistaking it for a Shade. The Shade appearing as a shadow when manifested by cursed possessions is not guaranteed, so seeing a full-body manifestation with them does not rule out a Shade. A common misconception surrounds the technicality on Shades performing interactions or ghost events in the same room as the player: *All ghosts have a range in which they can interact. Simply put, the Shade can "interact through walls". More precisely, if the Shade is in a room with no players, but its interaction range extends into a room with players, then the Shade can still interact with items inside the room with players provided that they are covered by the interaction range. **In general, this logic also applies for ghosts not being able to throw items in a lit room. *Additionally, a ghost event will always occur in the same room as a player, but the ghost does not have to be in that room to initiate it; for physical events, the ghost will teleport to the chosen player's room once the event is triggered, while no teleportation occurs for mist form events. This remains true for the Shade. See Ghost Event for more information on ghost events. ==Trivia== *Shade (lat. umbra, gr. σκιά) - in the mythology of many peoples, the ghost or spirit of the dead human, who is in the afterlife. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !24 March 2020 |Added Shade. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was EMF Level 5, Ghost Orb, and Ghost Writing. |- ! rowspan="4" |0.5.0 |Reduced the number of players required in the Shade's current room to prevent hunts from 2 to 1. |- |Being in the same room as the Shade will now prevent EMF 3 interactions. |- |The Shade now prefers shadow form if manifesting during a ghost event. |- |Reduced the Shade's hunt sanity threshold from 50% to 35%. |- !0.5.2.0 |Shades now have a chance to fail ghost events at higher sanities. |- !? |Shades can no longer perform interactions when a player is in its current room. |- !0.10.0 |Shades can no longer blow out fire sources and write in Ghost Writing Books if there are any players in the same room. |} ==References== ru:Тень fr:Ombre Category:Ghosts

The Parabolic Microphone, sometimes referred to as a "paramic", is a piece of equipment in Phasmophobia. It can detect sounds through walls and at a great distance, serving almost as a handheld version of the sound sensor. ==Mechanics== The parabolic microphone allows the player to hear an idle ghost's normally inaudible paranormal sounds (voices, growls, etc.), as well as amplifying any other sounds like object interactions. The parabolic microphone must be inside the building to detect sounds. When activated, the player will distinctively hear the sounds produced in front of the microphone with an angle of 110° horizontally, whether they are made by the ghost, another player, active equipment, or ambient noises, while all other sounds will be significantly muffled. The Tier I and Tier II parabolic microphones will only detect sounds on the same floor as the player. ===Ghost Sound Traits=== *Mylings make paranormal sounds more often than other ghosts. *Banshees have a certain chance of using a unique paranormal sound. *Moroi will curse players who hear their paranormal sounds, resulting in an increased passive sanity drain. ===Tier I=== The Tier I Parabolic Microphone has a range of 20 meters forward. It has a red light that will flicker when it detects sound. ===Tier II=== The Tier II Parabolic Microphone has a range of 30 meters forward and has an additional screen which will display three sets of numbers: * The largest number display (000.0) measures the total sum of sound (in decibels) from all detected sources. * The Min and Peak values display the quietest and loudest individual sound levels picked up, respectively. ** For example, if a 16 dB sound, a 17 dB sound, and a 19 dB sound are picked up, Min will display 16 dB and Peak will display 19 dB, and the sum will be 52 dB. During a hunt, the display will rapidly flash random numbers. ===Tier III=== The Tier III Parabolic Microphone is similar to the Tier II Parabolic Microphone, but it includes a sonar function, allowing its screen to display the position and the volume of each individual sound. It can also detect sounds one floor above or below the user. ==Tips == *The player should remain aware of other noises, such as interactions from players. Coordinate with others and communicate to know whether a sound might have originated from a player or the ghost. *Although generally disregarded for smaller maps, it may come in handy on larger ones (such as Brownstone High School and Sunny Meadows Mental Institution) for locating the ghost by pointing players in its general direction; this becomes even more effective in a team, where two players can use a Parabolic Microphone at different locations, and pinpoint the ghost's location quite accurately. *On large maps where a hunt might start without players even knowing, a Parabolic Microphone is a good way to provide advance warning from a far distance that a hunt has started/is in progress, and warn players to stay away from that direction. ==Objectives== {| class="article-table" ! Objective ! Actual requirements |- | Detect a paranormal sound with a Parabolic Microphone | Detect the ghost's whispers, or the Banshee's scream |} ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !15 August 2020
(Part 2) |Added parabolic microphone. |- ! 16 August 2020
(Part 2) |The parabolic microphone now detects door sounds. |- ! 24 August 2020

Nell's Diner is a small map in Phasmophobia. It is similar in size to 6 Tanglewood Drive and is unlocked at level 5. ==Structure== Nell's Diner is a one-story diner with a spacious dining area, three bathrooms, rooms for the staff, a kitchen, and a cold room. ===Layout tips=== *The fuse box cools the Cooler Room down to at a rate of 0.1°C (0.18°F) per second instead of heating it. *The Cooler Room has a dynamic temperature cap that prevents temperatures from going above a certain value. The cap starts at the weather's ambient temperature or at its lowest value, respectively when the fuse box is off or on at start. If off at start, turning the fuse box on will progressively lower the cap at a rate of 0.1°C (0.18°F) per second to a lowest of: ** for Sunrise ** for Clear, Fog, and Blood Moon ** for Windy, Light Rain, and Heavy Rain ** for Snow *The Foyer cannot be chosen as a favourite room. *The Foyer doesn't have any light to prevent passive sanity drain. See Third-party tools for a list of detailed map viewers that players may use. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 4 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Nell's Diner: *Storage, behind food cart *Cooler Room, behind food cart *Hallway, behind blue vending machine *Break Room, lockers Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots may be blocked by the presence of bulky items or their concealing elements removed: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: None *Professional: 1 *Nightmare/Insanity: 2 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None Looping the ghost may be performed around the kitchen island, the dining area, or the counter. ==Bone locations== Bones spawn randomly, but will only spawn in areas that a ghost can also walk on. ;Examples ==Cursed possession locations== NellsDiner-Circle.png|The Summoning Circle spawns in the Men's Bathroom. NellsDiner-Ouija.png|The Ouija Board spawns in the Janitors Closet. NellsDiner-Box.png|The Music Box spawns in the Manager's Office. NellsDiner-Mirror.png|The Haunted Mirror spawns in the Break Room. NellsDiner-Tarot.png|The Tarot Cards spawn in the Counter Area. NellsDiner-Voodoo.png|The Voodoo Doll spawns in the Dining Area. NellsDiner-Paw.png|The Monkey Paw spawns in the Kitchen. ==Easter Egg: Ghost in the Machine== Nell's Diner contains an easter egg that gives the "Ghost in the Machine" ID Card after leaving through the truck when triggered. The easter egg is triggered by completing the following steps on any difficulty: #Shine a UV light on the reminder post-it note in the Manager's Office. This will give you three arrows: Down, Up, Right. #Find the code outside, in three locations, each corresponding to an arrow (4 is in the Dining Area on the wall to the left upon first entry. It is being pointed to by the road sign angling down. 1 is underneath the neon sign by the road, pointed to by an upwards arrow. 5 can be found in the dumpster area, pointed to by a graffiti arrow pointing right). #Open the safe in the Manager's Office, under the desk, with the code. #Take the debit card inside to the ATM in Hallway and it in the card slot. #Pick up the dollar bill and buy a soda from the red Mr. Sprinkle vending machine to the left of the ATM by placing it in the insert slot. #Pick up the coin that drops from the machine upon buying a drink. #Place the coin in the Lair of the Unliving arcade machine, located in the Break Room. Only one player in a game has to complete this as everyone in the lobby will receive the reward, regardless of who actually completed it. ==Trivia== *Lore-wise, Nell's Diner is located in Tucson, Arizona. *There are tumbleweeds that roll along the road outside the diner periodically every 50 seconds. *The Nell's Diner sign flickers the word "Die". *There is a movie poster titled Demon Dog, which is in reference to a pre-release concept of the game. **The feature consisted of a demon dog chasing you after death, which if you succeeded in out-running resulted in the player being revived. *There are several ghost name references hidden throughout the map. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.15.0 |Added Nell's Diner. |- !0.15.1.0 |Nell's Diner now unlocks for players at Level 5. |}

content: The player is the main character being controlled in Phasmophobia. ==Carrying items== Non-VR players can carry up to 4 pieces of equipment, including one special slot for igniters. VR players have a toolbelt which carries a walkie-talkie and the journal by default. In total, VR players can carry up to 5 pieces of equipment, including one in each hand and two more on the toolbelt (excluding the walkie-talkie and journal), as well as a special slot for an igniter. VR players cannot open doors while holding items in both hands. ==Movement== By default, the player at 1.6 m/s, and can at 3 m/s for a maximum of 3 seconds. The sprint stamina regenerates at the same frequency as its depletion 2 seconds after the player stops sprinting. If the sprint stamina is completely depleted, the player must wait 5 seconds before being able to sprint again. Sprinting and player speed can be customised via custom difficulty settings. VR players also have the option of a "teleport circle" (point-and-trigger) which allows for moving a short distance at a time. ==Death== A player dies presumably if their collision box collides with the ghost (or a "kill area"), while there is line-of-sight. Once dead, they can only pick up items that are not considered equipment, and will see the world covered in a grey fog. Dead players can sprint infinitely. ==Player model== On the player, there are six points, three on the head and three on the legs, that are used to determine whether the ghost has line-of-sight with the player during a hunt. These are anchored to the player's point-of-view, and not the actual model that is visible. If the ghost can see either all three points on the head or all three points on the legs, the ghost is considered to have line-of-sight with the player. There are currently eight player models that are available; players can switch between any of them while in a lobby by clicking the character portrait on their own ID Card. Multiple players can select the same model in the same lobby. The player collision box is shorter while crouching. ==Related difficulty settings== *Sprinting: The ability to sprint *Player speed (%): How quickly players move ==Trivia== *The current player character models come from the pre-made characters collection of the Adobe Fuse character creation software. Being royalty-free, derivatives from those same character models can be found in many other Unity-based games. *If the player plays the game for the first time, their default character will be the black-haired African female one. ==Gallery== <gallery captionalign="center" widths="185"> Schnucki.jpg|A blond haired Caucasian male character wearing a bluish shirt Lookie.png|A brown-haired Hispanic female character wearing a dark shirt Measurie.jpg|A dark-haired Caucasian female character wearing a white shirt Talkie.jpg|A brown-haired Caucasian male character wearing a tan shirt Shortie.jpg|A black-haired Asian female character wearing a grey shirt Oldie.png|A brown-haired Caucasian male character wearing a brown sweater and dark shirt Luminari.png|A black-haired African female character wearing a dark shirt Bookie.png|A black-haired African male character wearing a dark sweater and white shirt </gallery> ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" | Early Access |- ! rowspan="2" |0.3.0 |Increased the walking and sprint speed to 1.6 m/s and 3 m/s respectively. |- |Players can now sprint for only 3 seconds at a time. |- !0.4.0 |The player collision box now shortens when crouching. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.6.0 |Dead players can now sprint infinitely. |- |Added eyelashes to the player model. |} Category:Gameplay fr:Joueur ru:Игрок
title: Player

content: The music box is a cursed possession that can be used to pinpoint the location of the ghost, though one is at considerable risk if one is careless with it. ==Mechanics== A music box has a 1 in 7 chance per contract of being chosen as the cursed possession that will spawn, with one specific spawn location per map. ===Activation and usage=== When picked up, the music box will open (this does not mean it has been activated). The music box can then be activated using the key. Doing so will end the setup phase early if it is ongoing. The music box cannot be activated during a hunt, and can only be used once. Once activated, if the ghost is within 20 metres of the music box, it will sing along, broadcasting its current location while remaining invisible. If the music box is within 5 metres of the ghost, it will trigger a ghost event where the ghost manifests and begins to walk towards the box. The music box can be handheld or on the floor, the latter being the only safe way to discard the box without triggering a cursed hunt before the ghost event. In all cases, the box will close once it stops playing. ===Cursed hunt=== While using the music box, a cursed hunt will be initiated if one of the following occurs: *The ghost is within a short distance of the player holding the box *The ghost walks during the box-triggered ghost event for more than 5 seconds *The box is thrown while the tune is playing *The player reaches or is already at 0% sanity By avoiding all of the above, it is possible to use the music box without causing any hunt: *Ensuring that no one is inside the investigation area when the above occurs (future hunts will be extended if the breaking method would have caused a cursed hunt) *When the music ends without the ghost ever being near enough, the music box will automatically close *If the player brings the music box near the ghost only just before the music stops playing, the ghost will simply disappear when the music ends. Note that while the music box is playing, the ghost can still initiate a hunt on its own due to meeting normal hunt conditions rather than the box itself; this results in a standard hunt instead of a cursed hunt. ===Other effects=== Being within 3 metres of an actively functioning music box drains the player's sanity at a rate of 2.6%/s, totalling 77% if the entire song is listened to. This applies to all players within the range, regardless of who activated the music box. As long as the box-triggered ghost event has not occurred, an active music box will not prevent regular ghost activity, which means that the ghost can continue to roam, interact with objects, use its abilities, or even perform regular ghost events and hunts. While the ghost will not actively walk towards the music box if it is out of range, it can happen to roam close enough to trigger the ghost event. If the music box is brought outside, the box will close. If the music is also playing, the sanity drain will pause, but the music will technically continue. It will reopen and function normally once the music box is brought inside again. ===Ghosts=== *The Shade has a chance of appearing as a black shadow rather than in its full form while walking towards the box. *Compared to other ghosts, the Yokai must be closer to the player holding the box (within 2.5 metres) to trigger the ghost event. ===Rewards=== Taking a photo of a music box, used or not, will yield a photo labelled as Music Box. Recording the sound of the box while it is active will yield a sound labelled as Music Box. Each of these pieces of media can reward up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the equipment tier and whether there is a Unique stamp. ==Strategies and tips== The music box can be broken down into two primary uses: 1) utilize the triggered ghost event and following hunt to complete relevant objectives and/or to identify the ghost type, or 2) get the ghost to broadcast its current position to narrow down and locate its favourite room. The music box is an easy way to obtain a ghost photo/video, but beware that switching to another item while holding the music box will automatically throw it and immediately cause a hunt; it should be placed down before switching. In multiplayer games, one way is to have the player who records media carry the smudge stick while another player activates the music box. The player holding the music box should refill their sanity to a comfortable level to avoid a 0% sanity-triggered hunt. If the player wants to trigger a hunt, it is advised to do so by throwing the box while at a safe location rather than walking to the ghost to trigger the event and subsequent hunt, as the latter method puts the player in close proximity to the ghost when it begins hunting which is quite dangerous and can lead to death especially against ghosts such as a Revenant. On smaller maps such as the suburban houses, it can be quite difficult to avoid getting too close and triggering the event and subsequent cursed hunt especially if the player is not sure where the ghost is, so caution should be advised when using it, and the player should also take some precautions in case this happens: *Carrying along a tier III Crucifix can come in handy to prevent the cursed hunt entirely; if the ghost event is triggered, quickly place down the box and swap to the Crucifix, which will block the hunt when the event ends. *Bringing Incense, tier III Salt and tier III Sanity Medication can all help with escaping the ghost as with all hunts. *If the event does trigger, immediately place down the box and run away from the ghost to put some distance between the player and the ghost before the cursed hunt begins. Players should be especially careful when using a Music Box if the ghost is a Wraith, as it can teleport to the player holding the box, and instantly start a cursed hunt at their location, leading to an almost-guaranteed death. ==Gallery== <gallery> File:Music Box.png|Music box in the lobby showcase File:Musicbox woodwind.jpg|Music box in Camp Woodwind File:Musicbox ridgeview girlsbedroom.png|Music box in 10 Ridgeview Court File:Musicbox edgefield livingroom.png|Music box in 42 Edgefield Road File:Bleasdale-Music Box.jpg|Music box in Bleasdale Farmhouse File:Willow-MusicBox.jpg|Music box in 13 Willow Street </gallery> ==Trivia== *When players interact with a piano's keyboard, it will play 1-2 notes from the Music Box's song, with the whole song playing when repeatedly interacting with the piano. *The tune of the music box was composed by Lavender, one of the game's developers, and is titled "Adrift". **The name and sheet music for the song can be seen inside the Music Box's top lid and above Bleasdale Farmhouse's piano. **A full piano version is available on Spotify. *The Music Box is available as official merchandise on The Music Box Store. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.5.0 |Added the music box. |} ==Notes== Category:Item fr:Boîte à musique ru:Музыкальная шкатулка
title: Music Box

The Monkey Paw is a cursed possession that can be used to grant the player wishes. ==Mechanics== A Monkey Paw has a 1 in 7 chance per contract of being chosen as the cursed possession that will spawn on a default difficulty (except Insanity), with one specific spawn location per map. The Monkey Paw grants up to a certain number of wishes depending on the difficulty reward multiplier: *0x – 1x: 5 wishes *1.01x – 2x: 4 wishes *2.01x or higher: 3 wishes The Monkey Paw can only be used within the investigation area, and players can choose to either use voice chat or a text-based UI to make wishes. *If using voice chat, the Monkey Paw will grant any recognized wish made by the player. *If using the text-based UI, the UI will appear upon pressing the button. Players can then click to select one of 3 categories, then select a category-specific wish, or exit the UI by pressing the button again. Every wish will come with a negative side effect, with the severity depending on the wish. If the Monkey Paw recognizes a valid phrase, regardless if it is a valid wish or not, or when entering/exiting the investigation area, its fingers will twitch. When a wish is being granted, one of its fingers will bend. When all fingers are bent, the Monkey Paw cannot be used anymore. Most wishes can be found on tags scattered in Sunny Meadows, these tags look the same as the one found on a Monkey Paw. Picking a tag up (except for "I wish for [weather]" and "I wish for anything" tags, as well as the Monkey Paw's own tag) will record the wish in the journal. There is no need to find the wishes to use the Monkey Paw. Each wish can only be used once per contract, regardless of the wisher. ===Wishes=== {| class="fandom-table" !Category !Wish !Effects !Sunny Meadows wish tag location |- ! rowspan="3" |Ghost | *I wish to see the ghost |Triggers a summoning ghost event at the ghost's current location, locking all exit doors immediately. After 5 seconds, the ghost will begin a cursed hunt, and the wisher's vision is obscured with a dark fog. Their vision will return to normal once the hunt ends. |Manager Office |- | *I wish for activity *I wish the ghost would do something |Doubles all ghost activity for 2 minutes (roaming, interactions, abilities, ghost events). The fuse box will break permanently, and all exit doors will be locked for 2 minutes. |Chapel |- | *I wish the ghost was trapped *I wish to trap the ghost |Applies the cleansing effect from Incense on the ghost and teleports it to its favorite room and locks all doors connected to it for 1 minute. During this period, the ghost cannot hunt, roam, or use abilities. This will also lock all doors connected to the wisher's current room for 1 minute. After this period, all doors will unlock and the ghost will start a standard hunt. There is a 25% chance for doors to unlock only after the grace period. |Female Dorm Room |- ! rowspan="3" |Player | *I wish for sanity *I wish to be sane |Sets every player to 50% sanity. Passive sanity drain will be multiplied by 1.5 for the rest of the contract, and the ghost's favorite room will be set to a new random room (overriding a Goryo's inability to change favorite rooms). |Kitchen |- | *I wish to be safe |Unblocks the nearest blocked hiding spot. The lights in the wisher's current room will shatter, and for the rest of the contract the ghost will be able to hear the wisher and sense their active electronics at any distance (including from different floors). |Matron Office 1 |- | *I wish to leave |Unlocks all exit doors at any time, including during hunts. The wisher's speed will be reduced before slowly returning over 5 seconds. Their vision will also be reduced for this duration. |Hospital Wing |- ! rowspan="4" | Other | *I wish for life *I wish to revive my friend |Revives the first deceased player in the lobby list (established by the order the players joined the lobby), with a 50% chance of causing the wisher's death.
This wish cannot be used if no player is dead. |Classroom |- | *I wish for knowledge |Eliminates one incorrect piece of evidence and its associated ghost types from the wisher's journal. The ghost then teleports near the wisher and initiates a cursed hunt. The wisher's vision will be covered in a dark fog, and their hearing will be muffled until either their death or the end of the contract. |Restricted Area |- |I wish for [weather] *Clear Sky *Fog *Rain *Snow *Sunrise |Changes the weather as desired. All players will be temporary blinded while the weather changes and the wisher will lose 25% sanity. Wishing for rain will grant either light or heavy rain, each having an equal 50% chance.
This wish cannot be used if the wisher has less than 25% sanity. |Morgue |- |ㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤ *I wish for anything |Randomly grants one of the (unused) wishes above. |Waiting Room |} ====Miscellaneous==== Due to the game's voice recognition system, some sentences may be interpreted as valid wishes, including silly wishes. Examples include "I wish for infinite wishes" which may be misheard as "I wish for sun". Sometimes the wishes "I wish to be sane" and "I wish to be safe" can be misheard as the other wish. ===Rewards=== Taking a photo of a Monkey Paw, regardless of the number of uses, will yield a photo labelled as Monkey Paw, and reward up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the tier of the Photo Camera. ==Tips== *The Monkey Paw is one of the most versatile cursed possessions in the game, and can assist players in the completion of most objectives. The various wishes can be called upon on command at any time, meaning that players can control when and where to employ their effects to maximize the benefits and minimize the downsides. **In multiplayer, the Monkey Paw becomes even more powerful than it already is in singleplayer, as a lot of wish downsides only affect the wisher. *One of the safety wish's downsides, allowing the ghost to detect the wisher from any distance, while significant on paper, can actually be used to the wisher's benefit to bait the ghost to wherever the wisher is, whether to save a teammate, or to lead it to a favourable looping spot for hunt identification and/or photos. *The knowledge wish becomes slightly more useful in reduced-evidence difficulties, as this wish always eliminates an incorrect evidence type and never a hidden evidence type, making it the only method to guarantee that an evidence type is incorrect. Its harsh downsides, however, make this wish a last resort and should only ever be used near the end of a contract. *The weather wish can be used if the current weather (such as Blood Moon) is not desired, or to change the ambient temperature to aid in getting Freezing Temperatures or slowing a Hantu down, which is especially useful if the fuse box is broken or the map is an outdoors map. *If not using the text UI, the Monkey Paw is always active when held. Be careful when speaking while holding it as you may accidentally call upon a wish. **This is especially notable when using push-to-talk, as there are bugs that make the Monkey Paw listen to the player even if no voice chat button is being pressed. *The vision loss from certain wishes is very significant, making it near impossible for a player afflicted by it to see more than a meter or so in front of them. While this can be partially circumvented by setting game brightness to a very high value, the affected player will be more or less rendered helpless and will need to be guarded accordingly. Thus, it is recommended for the wisher to use these wishes while in a hiding spot. ==Trivia== *The Monkey Paw was available as official merchandise for a limited time, until 3 July 2024 (UK time). *When wishing for sanity, the ghost doesn't teleport immediately to the new ghost room, but will have to enter the "Favourite room" state to walk to its new room, which usually happens shortly after wishing. Tier III salt can be used to deter this. *The idea of a "Monkey's Paw" being used to grant wishes is very likely inspired by the short story The Monkey's Paw by W. W. Jacobs. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.8.1.0 |Added Monkey Paw. |- !0.9.0 |“I wish to see the ghost” will no longer teleport the ghost in front of you, instead it will reveal it where the ghost is, in its current position. |- !0.10.0 |"I wish to see the ghost" will now limit the user's vision after the ghost event instead of before. |- !? |Lowered the number of wishes for difficulties between 1x and 3x. |} ==Notes== Category:Item fr:Patte de singe ru:Обезьянья лапа
title: Monkey Paw

content: The Objective Board can be found in the truck, between the computer and the Site Activity Monitor and Sound Monitor. ==Usage== When in a contract, the objective board will display the following information: *The case number *The ghost's name *Whether the ghost responds to everyone or only people that are alone (this information is not provided on Professional, Nightmare, and Insanity difficulties) *3 objectives *5 video slots, 5 photo slots, and 3 sound slots that can be filled ==Trivia== *Before 0.174, completed tasks were crossed out, instead of greyed out. ==See also== *Evidence *Media Category:Truck Equipment fr:Tableau d'objectifs ru:Список задач
title: Objective Board

content: The motion sensor is a piece of equipment that can help in tracking the movement of the ghost. ==Usage== A motion sensor can used by it. After being placed, it can be turned off by with it. ===Tier I=== The Tier I Motion Sensor can either be placed on the wall or on the floor. When placed, the sensor will emit a red laser beam, indicating its effective detection distance. If it is placed on a wall, it will also display on the Site Map in the truck as a red bar. When a player (even if they are dead and spectating), the ghost, the mist form, or an object passes through its laser beam, the motion sensor will emit a bright light for 2 seconds. The bar on the site map will also turn green for 6 seconds, and an audible beep will play from the monitor. Motion sensors that are not displayed will still play the beep. ===Tier II=== The Tier II Motion Sensor is similar to the Tier I Motion Sensor and adds a conical mode which can be switched to by with it. The conical mode allows the sensor to have a second laser beam that can help players track the ghost's movement more accurately, as its lights will be emitted from left to right, or from right to left, depending on the direction of the movement. Additionally, the Tier II Motion Sensor will directly emit an audible beep when it detects movement. ===Tier III=== The Tier III Motion Sensor can only be placed on the floor and has a 1.5-metre spherical range that is displayed as a red circle on the site map in the truck. When the ghost enters this range, the sensor will quickly rotate to the location it detected the ghost, and will emit a small light and an audible beep. On the site map, the red circle will turn green for 6 seconds. When the ghost exits the range, the sensor will only rotate to the location it detected the ghost and emit a light, without beeping. Only the ghost can trigger this sensor. ===Rewards=== Filming a motion sensor being triggered by the ghost will yield a Motion Sensed video, rewarding up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the tier of the Video Camera and whether there is a Unique stamp. ==Tips== *Placing motion sensors at corners or room boundaries can help to track where the ghost is. ==Gallery== <gallery> File:Motion sensor t3 tanglewood.jpg|Tier III motion sensor's range shown on map as a red circle. File:Motion Sensor Triggered.jpg|The Motion Sensor when triggered. </gallery> ==Objectives== {| class="fandom-table" !Objective !Actual requirements |- |Detect a ghost presence with a motion sensor |Have the ghost walk past the motion sensor, triggering it |} ==Trivia== *The motion sensor is the most expensive item in the game, costing $100. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !29 January 2020 |Motion sensors no longer have a sound indicator in the van. |- !12 March 2020 |The 5th and 6th motion sensor icons have been removed from the monitor in the van. |- !13 March 2020 |Motion sensors no longer detect entities through walls. |- !20 March 2020 |Motion sensors now have an outline to indicate where it will be placed. |- !21 March 2020 |VR players can now place motion sensors from a greater distance. |- !19 May 2020 |The motion sensor monitor in the van has been replaced with a map of the building for Tanglewood, Ridgeview and Edgefield maps. Motion sensors will show their detections on the map. |- ! rowspan="2" |20 May 2020 |Motion sensors will now stay activated on the map for 6 seconds, up from 2 seconds. |- |The width of the bar on the motion sensor has been doubled to improve visiblity. |- !19 June 2020 |Motion sensors are now level-locked. |- !27 June 2020 |Motion sensors can now only be unlocked at level 6. |- ! rowspan="2" |12 August 2020 |Motion sensors can now be picked up after they have already been placed on a wall. |- |The cost of motion sensors has been increased from $70 to $100. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !29 September 2020 |The motion sensor bar on the map monitor now shows up as red instead of pink. |- ! rowspan="2" |0.3.0 |Changed the motion sensor model. |- |The function of the Infrared Light Sensor has been merged into the motion sensor; motion sensors now emit light when an entity walks past it. |- !0.4.0 |Motion sensors can now be placed on the floor. |- !0.9.0 |Added Tier II and III Motion Sensors. |- !0.13.0 |The mist form can no longer trigger motion sensors. |} Category:Equipment fr:Détecteur de mouvement ru:Датчик движения
title: Motion Sensor

content: Since the beginning of development, some features have been removed from the game, having been replaced or deemed unsuitable for the game at its current state. Most of these features were removed before Early Access release on Steam. ==Ghosts== ;General ]] *For around a week after the game's early access Steam release, one type of ghost event was to mimic player models who were either alive but outside the building or dead, and walk towards a particular player before vanishing. Phantoms performing this event would also show putrefied skin on the player model. This type of ghost event was likely removed in version 0.165 initially to fix a bug, but has never been re-implemented for unknown reasons. *For some time, ghosts could stare at the targeted player during a ghost event. ;Jinn *Jinns were able to affect the weather. This was replaced by a chasing speed that depended on whether the player was running, which itself was later replaced with its current ability of having a higher speed if its target is further away. ;Mare *Mares had the ability to cause hallucinations, which would drop a player's sanity, and could be stopped by toggling one's flashlight. This was replaced with the current light-based hunt sanity threshold. **The old journal description of this ability was once accidentally added in 0.3.1.0, and reverted in a same-version hotfix. ==Evidence== *Bile: replaced with Ghost Particles, which are now known as Ghost Orbs. *Blood: replaced with EMF Level 5. *Bug (insects): replaced with various other evidences. **In the Phasmophobia Official Announcement Trailer, a cockroach can be seen in the living room. *Dirty Water: replaced with Ghost Writing, but still exists as a photo reward. *Ectoplasm: replaced with Spirit Box. *Handprints: originally found on walls, instead of certain objects that the ghost interacted with. Replaced with Fingerprints. *Wall Scratches *Fingerprints: Replaced with Ultraviolet. Fingerprints only included finger or handprints left by the ghost when interacting with applicable surfaces or items, such as doors, keyboards, and light switches (though these evidences still count as Ultraviolet). Footprints were not an evidence but a photo reward, and every ghost except the Wraith could create them. **Prior to 0.9.0, Fingerprints and Footprints did not need to be illuminated with a UV light to be photographed; this meant that fingerprints could be found without a UV light by photographing the touched surface and look if the photo was labelled as "Fingerprints". *Prior to 0.9.0, D.O.T.S silhouettes used to be a duplicate of the ghost that would be generated when the real ghost interacted with the D.O.T.S Projector. This meant that a D.O.T.S silhouette could appear while the real ghost was already manifesting, such as during a hunt or a ghost event. D.O.T.S silhouettes are now the real ghost becoming temporarily visible under the light of a Projector. *Prior to the introduction of sound and video recording in 0.13.0, bonus evidence could only be collected as photos. Ephemeral events (such as doors moving or objects being thrown) could be recorded by taking a photo of the affected object while the EMF signature was still active. The value of a photo was determined using a 3-star rating system. The number of stars was determined according to the distance from the subject, and how close it was to the center of the frame. Furthermore, certain subjects could only be photographed once for a reward (such as the Ghost or Cursed Posessions); duplicate photos were worthless and could waste precious space in the Journal. Subjects that could be photographed multiple time (such as ultraviolet evidence or disturbed salt piles) provided normal rewards every new instance. **The rating and subject priority system (which determined what subject to record if multiple were detected within the frame) was notoriously finicky and prone to bugs, as it could potentially ruin high-value shots (one peculiarly common instance were piles of salt incorrectly taking priority over the ghost). Because of this, the rating system was simplified so that the value of a photo is determined by whether or not it is unique or a duplicate, the latter providing a reduced reward (including previous multi-instance subjects like salt piles). ==Hunts== *A ghost was able to teleport if it could not find a target during hunts. Currently, there is no ghost that can teleport during a hunt, though the Wraith can teleport randomly to a player outside of hunts, and certain phases (e.g. manifestation ghost event, end of a hunt) require the ghost to teleport. *Prior to 0.26.8.1, ghosts completely lacked object permanence, which meant that it would forget its target as soon as it left its field of vision and resume wandering immediately. They also did not accelerate with line of sight until 0.28.6.5, allowing players to outrun most chasing ghosts so long they remained in constant motion. With hunts being fairly easy to survive, the developers decided to make gameplay more engaging by making the ghost's AI able to follow players around corners and accelerate when they saw a player to prevent them from simply outpacing the ghost. **Additionally, furniture could not break line of sight; only doors or walls could block the ghost's vision. This was also changed in line with the new hunting behaviors. *Prior to 0.3.0, hunts would cause map lights, flashlights and the global chat to malfunction everywhere on the map, including outside. Because using electronics at the time also did not attract the ghost, it was very easy to check for the beginning or the end of a hunt simply by observing the flashlight beam or by occasionally pressing the global chat key to check for static. To make hunts less predictable, electronics and the global chat now only malfunction when the ghost is near enough, and will also attract the ghost if toggled nearby. *Up until 0.5.0, when the ghost hunted, it could randomly appear either in its fully physical form, its shadowy form, or its translucent, jelly-like form. It was changed to only use its physical form to make tracking the ghost much more consistent during a hunt, as its other forms often made it unnecessarily difficult to see, especially in scenarios where overlapping light maps would make it essentially disappear. ==Gameplay== *On some maps, garage and basement doors required keys that could be found within the map. The ghost could also occasionally lock these doors. The door locking feature was removed before the game's initial release on Steam, while these keys were removed later on. Only three keys currently exist: one for unlocking the (main) entrance door, one for turning off the car alarm on certain maps, and one for the cabin in Maple Lodge Campsite (the ghost cannot lock this door). *Until 0.4.0, a random assortment of three to five maps would be given to the host of the lobby to select from for the next mission. If the maps given by the system were undesirable, either one of the maps would have to be loaded then immediately left; or in multiplayer the host would have to leave the lobby, thereby promoting another player in the lobby as host to see which range of maps they were given. **For a short time after release, the difficulty of these contracts were also random, further necessitating such measures to try and play the desired maps and/or difficulties. *Until 0.3.0.4, it was possible to interact with equipment that was held by other players. This was removed to prevent trolling during hunts as electronic equipment held by players now attracted the ghost. *Footsteps from an idling ghost could be periodically heard without the aid of any equipment, which could be reliably used to narrow down its location. Since 0.3.0, ghost footsteps can only be heard when using a Parabolic Microphone or when the ghost has walked through Salt. *Players used to have to search for the ghost's name around the map instead of being already provided with it. This feature was removed early on in development as it was deemed too difficult on larger maps. The toggleable computer monitor found on 6 Tanglewood Drive displaying "Thomas Wilson", as well as the name "Nancy" above the crib in the Nursery, are remnants of this feature. *Players with low sanity would start to hear auditory hallucinations that would increase in frequency as their sanity decayed. This was removed shortly before the early access release of the game. *Prior to 0.9.0, seeing freezing breath was a conclusive indicator of Freezing Temperatures without having to use a Thermometer. *Prior to 0.9.0, training took place at 6 Tanglewood Drive as a modified Amateur contract with no secondary objectives or rewards. A ghost was haunting the location, its type was randomly selected, it provided evidence as normal, but it could not hunt. A short slideshow displayed on the TV in the living room detailed each evidence and how to spot them. *Prior to 0.9.0.9 the passive sanity drain was determined by calculating the level of ambient light around the player's head (whether it be from on-site lights or firelights). This complex system was notably resource-intensive, and was also in practice peculiarly finicky. Due to this, it was replaced by the current system, where the passive sanity drain depends on whether all main light sources in a room are on or off, regardless of the player's physical position in relation to light sources within the room. *Decorative candles found on certain maps could be grabbed and could mitigate passive sanity drain just like purchased candles. This is no longer the case as of 0.9.0; they can no longer be grabbed or moved and do not affect sanity drain. They can still be lit to provide a non-electric light source however. *Until 0.10.0.1, Phasmophobia had support for BHaptics haptic feedback apparel to provide simulated physical sensations, chiefly for VR players. Support was removed due to very low usage and it causing performance issues among VR players. ==Equipment== *Infrared Light Sensors emitted light when a player or ghost walked past. It did not complete any motion sensor-related challenges when triggered by the ghost. This feature was merged into the current Motion Sensor. *Strong Flashlights were a separate item, with their own store tab and spot in the truck, that acted as a direct upgrade to the regular Flashlight, bearing a brighter, more powerful light. Its model and overall functionality would be reused for the Tier II Flashlight. **Similarly, Glowsticks were a separate item from UV Lights, even though they had the same purpose. It became the Tier I, and then later the Tier II UV Light. ==Maps== *6 Tanglewood Drive used to have skeletons scattered around the house which could only be seen by dead players. This was removed shortly after the Steam Early Access release of the game. *Prior to 0.4.0, 6 Tanglewood Drive had permanent rainy weather. This at the time was purely cosmetic and did not influence the investigation other than producing a mild noise disturbance. **The thunder sound effect that was initially used on Tanglewood became notable for unintentionally featuring a faint scream at the end. It was replaced with a new, clean sound effect in v.0.26.6. *Asylum was the first large map added to the game. This map was notable for both its immense size, with over 200 distinct rooms, as well as its confusing maze-like layout, earning a reputation of being a notoriously difficult and frustrating map even for the most seasoned of players. This map was replaced with the smaller and much more intuitive Sunny Meadows Mental Institution. *Before the introduction of Cursed Possessions, the Ouija Board was a special standalone item which had a 50% chance per contract of spawning at one of several set locations on a given map. Moreover, questions asked to the Ouija Board had a chance to fail and would induce a severe sanity loss. It would go through several changes before becoming part of the Cursed Possessions collection. *The original versions of both Farmhouses (Grafton and Bleasdale), as well as 13 Willow Street, had a few decorative voodoo doll props scattered around the location, which could be photographed for a photo reward. These voodoo dolls had no additional functionality nor effect on the ghost, though there were many rumours abound that throwing them could force the ghost to perform an interaction or that they would always point towards the ghost room when they landed on the ground. These voodoo doll props were removed with the introduction of the Voodoo Doll and the other Cursed Possessions in 0.5.0, although their old spawn locations were reused for the cursed possessions' spawn locations. *Maple Lodge Campsite was originally released with an entirely different layout. The initial iteration was significantly more open, featuring very large outdoor spaces and scant hiding spots. The vast open spaces notably caused performance issues with line-of-sight calculation, and made it difficult for players to escape a chasing ghost. The map was almost entirely changed with the 0.9.1.0 update for optimization and balance; the only unchanged sections of the original map are the Cabin and the Pier. *The game was initially released with largely different versions of the Farmhouse maps (Bleasdale and Grafton). Being added in the relatively early stages of development, both houses were created entierly using the Vintage House pre-made asset pack, and thus were largely similar in appearance and ambience. They were eventually replaced by much more detailed and unique versions, each featuring its own theme and dedicated assets. Bleasdale was replaced by the current version in the 0.12.0.1 update, while Grafton was replaced in the 0.14.0 version. ==References== Category:Development fr:Fonctionnalités retirées
title: Removed Features

content: The Raiju is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. The Raiju siphons the power from electronic equipment to both increase its aggression and boost its speed during a hunt. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== When a Raiju manifests during a ghost event or a hunt, it will interfere with electronics that are up to 15 metres away on the same floor, instead of the usual 10 metres. This also applies to global chat. ===Hunt=== When the Raiju is within a certain distance of at least one piece of active electronic equipment on the same floor (that can also be located outside the investigation area), its hunt sanity threshold is increased to 65%, and it will move at a fixed speed of 2.5 m/s during hunts: *Small map: 6m *Medium map: 8m *Large map: 10m Otherwise, it will have the standard threshold of 50% and will follow standard ghost speeds with one particularity: if the Raiju has line-of-sight with a player while near active electronic equipment, the speed increase from continuous line-of-sight adds in the background, and will only be applied once it is no longer near any electronics. All effects listed above apply to most electronic equipment, whether they are placed, held in the hand, or dropped on the floor. The following do not count towards the speed boost or the hunt sanity threshold: *Global chat *Video cameras and Photo Cameras that are thrown on the ground *Motion sensors, sound sensors, and D.O.T.S. Projectors that are thrown on the ground or held (excluding T1 D.O.T.S., which also needs to be turned off) *Objects in the inventory (except flashlights that are turned on) *Any other electrical equipment not brought in from the truck (building lights, fuse box, CCTV, fans, etc.) ===Miscellaneous=== The player's heartbeats can be heard within 15 metres of the Raiju, instead of within 10 metres like with other ghosts, making the heartbeats much louder with the Raiju compared to other ghosts. This is likely a bug. ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: A Raiju can siphon power from nearby electrical devices, making it move faster. Weakness: Raiju are constantly disrupting electronic equipment when attacking, making it easier to track. ==Evidence== ==Strategies== In order to mitigate the risk of an early hunt, it is best to turn off and/or remove any unneeded electronic equipment from the ghost room; this also prevents the Raiju from harnessing this equipment to empower itself while hunting. Lazily discarding such equipment is a surefire way to make a Raiju extremely dangerous. Additionally, players often have the reflex of discarding electronic items behind them when a hunt starts to not attract the ghost's attention to them; this should be avoided with Raijus to not leave a trail of electronic equipment to power its speed ability. Instead, players should either switch to a non-electronic item or turn off their electronic item. The Raiju may be readily-identified by being mindful of its speed during a hunt, particularly on small maps, so long as there are active electronic items nearby. If the ghost suddenly and significantly speeds up when roaming (and not chasing particular players), then it is most likely a Raiju, though be mindful of mistaking this with a Hantu speeding up as it moves from a warm room to a cold room; the only evidence they share is Ghost Orbs so getting any other evidence can confirm whether the ghost is a Raiju or Hantu. A safe way to check for this is to turn off all other nearby active electronics, drop an active electronic in the player's hiding spot, and during a hunt, check if the ghost's footsteps suddenly speed up when nearby. ==Trivia== *In Japanese mythology, Raijus (雷獣, or "thunder beasts") are divine creatures most commonly depicted as a canine animal surrounded by lightning. Raijus are thought to be living in the sky, descending onto earth during thunderstorms by riding a lightning bolt to cause mayhem and destruction. As such, lightning strikes were often interpreted as the passage of a Raiju or divine punishment in ancient Japan. In-game, Raijus do not actually appear in animal forms, and simply draws from the regular pool of Ghost Models. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.4.0 |Added Raiju.<!-- |- !0.12.0.1 |Increased the heartbeat sound range from 10 to 15 metres.--> |} ==Notes== ru:Райдзю fr:Raiju Category:Ghosts
title: Raiju

content: The setup phase is the starting phase of a game. During this phase, players can explore the location, collect and set up equipments, and locate the ghost before it can initiate a hunt. == Mechanics == The duration of the setup phase depends on the difficulty: {|class="article-table" |+ !Difficulty !Time |- |Amateur |5 minutes |- |Intermediate |2 minutes |- |Professional |rowspan="3"|None |- |Nightmare |- |Insanity |} Countdown of the setup phase is shown on the timer in the truck above the computer, and will only begin when any entryway to the building is opened. During the setup phase, sanity decay due to being in darkness is reduced by roughly 30%, and sanity cannot go below 50%. Additionally, the ghost cannot initiate a hunt on its own, regardless of its hunt sanity threshold or any abilities it may have. Other than these conditions, the setup phase does not affect the ghost's behaviour or other game mechanics. When the time runs out, the ghost will be allowed to initiate a hunt, depending on the ghost type and the players' average sanity, and the sanity drain rate will increase to normal. The setup phase can be ended early by activating or using any cursed possession. There is currently a bug where the Ouija Board cancels the setup phase only if it recognizes a valid phrase instead of upon activation. == Tips == *The setup time is valuable for newer players in setting up equipment, looking for evidence, and scouting hiding spots before the ghost is permitted to hunt. *Having the setup phase end does not mean that the ghost will immediately begin hunting, as whether ghosts can hunt is generally dependent on whether the average team sanity is below a certain threshold. Most of the time, this threshold will not have been met by the time the setup phase ends. == Related difficulty settings == *Setup time (s): How long before the ghost can start a hunt Category:Gameplay fr:Phase de préparation
title: Setup Phase

content: The Mimic is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. They are known for mimicking the traits of other ghosts. ==Behaviour== ===Ability=== The Mimic is able to imitate any type of ghost, and inherit all of its features and abilities: *Interaction and ghost event rates and preferences *Hunt thresholds *Hunt movement speeds *Various forms of special abilities (e.g. Poltergeist multi-throw, Demon ability hunt) When imitating a type of ghost, The Mimic will not copy its types of evidence, and will not necessarily provide its guaranteed type of evidence on reduced-evidence difficulties such as Insanity, but can copy features related to evidence. For example, it is able to copy the Obake's six-fingered handprints or the Deogen's breathing, as The Mimic has Ultraviolet and Spirit Box as evidence, but it cannot copy the Goryo's trait of only appearing on a Video Camera when interacting with a D.O.T.S Projector, as The Mimic does not have D.O.T.S Projector as one of its types of evidence. The Mimic will always start in the "blank" state (in which it essentially mimics itself) at the beginning of a contract. When this is the case, it will act as a default ghost and have no special abilities. It will attempt to change 1 minute after an exit door has been opened for the first time, then every 30 seconds to 2 minutes, but cannot change during hunts and ghost events. Additionally, The Mimic cannot imitate the Banshee or the Dayan if it is male. If The Mimic is affected by Incense, it will not be able to hunt for the duration associated with the ghost it was imitating at that moment, even if it imitates another ghost before its end. The Mimic, when imitating some specific ghost types, will have some specific behaviours, listed below: *If The Mimic imitates a Thaye, a fixed age between 0 and 10 is randomly selected, and it will imitate another ghost using its own timer instead of the Thaye's ageing timer. *If The Mimic imitates a Moroi, and curses the player through the Spirit Box, the Parabolic Microphone, or the Sound Recorder, the curse will remain even if The Mimic switches to another ghost type. *If The Mimic imitates a Banshee, initially, it has no target. Once the first non-cursed hunt is attempted, a target is chosen randomly. The Mimic provides "evidence" of Ghost Orbs in addition to its three main evidence types, which also appear on difficulties with reduced evidence, including zero evidence. These Ghost Orbs, along with the other types of evidence if none are hidden due to the difficulty, will always exist regardless of the type of ghost that The Mimic chooses to imitate, and will behave in exactly the same way as those produced by other ghost types and will only levitate in the ghost room. ==Evidence== Though Ghost Orbs are always present, this is not considered by the Journal when inputting evidence. Whether Ghost Orbs is selected does not affect your payout even if the ghost is blanked out when selecting the ghost. ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: We're unsure what this ghost is capable of. Be careful. Weakness: Several reports have noted ghost orb sightings near mimics. ==Strategies== The Mimic's fundamental nature means that it is extremely unpredictable; it might mimic a Shade and be scared to hunt the whole contract, or it could mimic a Moroi and rapidly drain everyone's sanity then turn into a Revenant and wreak havoc with a surprise early hunt. It can theoretically have the powers of almost any ghost type at any time, most notably ghost abilities that could enable early hunts. In theory, the absolute safest way to handle a Mimic is to treat it as if it had every potential modifier that could increase its aggression/drain player sanity faster than usual, and utilize all tactics that would be used to dissuade attacks from other ghost types: *Aggression-related: **Try to minimize speaking when near the ghost (Yokai) **Turn off electronics that are no longer needed (Raiju) **Make sure to have active sources of flame in the Ghost Room (Onryo) **In general, be prepared for the possibility of early hunts (Demon/Thaye) *Sanity-related: **Avoid colliding with the ghost during an event (Oni) **Turn the breaker off (Jinn) **Avoid being in pseudo line-of-sight of the ghost (when the player hears their own heartbeat) (Phantom) **Remove items from the ghost room (Poltergeist) **Close doors in the ghost room (Yurei) In practice, however, it is oftentimes overkill and a great annoyance to perform all of these at once, with some even conflicting with each other, and most of the time it's simpler to just bring in Crucifixes early to stop any surprise hunts and/or take Sanity Medication to refill sanity as needed. Additionally, it is prudent to have Incense handy, as The Mimic may imitate fast ghosts such as the Revenant or Thaye, catch players by surprise by starting a hunt from an unexpected location if it imitates The Twins or a stalking ghost (Wraith, Phantom and Banshee), or most dangerously imitate the Deogen and require players to completely change up their strategy from hiding to looping between hunts, potentially after everyone is already situated at a hiding spot. As The Mimic always produces Ghost Orbs and appears to go over the difficulty's maximum amount of given types of evidence, players have to take care when trying to identify the ghost through evidence. However, this can also cause The Mimic to be very simple to identify, as players only need to confirm an additional type of evidence compared to the difficulty. On difficulties with all three types of evidence, identifying Ultraviolet, Spirit Box and Ghost Orbs also definitively indicates a Mimic, as no other ghost has this evidence combination. Ghost behaviour is also a relatively easy, if somewhat luck-dependent way to identify The Mimic; if the player spots conflicting ghost behaviour throughout the contract that seems to indicate different ghosts at different times, it is most likely The Mimic changing between different ghost types. Similarly, identifying the behaviour of a specific ghost type, but then getting types of evidence that it does not have, gives The Mimic away. For example, if the player hears a Banshee's scream on the Parabolic Microphone, but also gets a Spirit Box response which Banshees do not have, then it's guaranteed to be a Mimic. ==Trivia== *The Mimic is the only ghost that can leave handprints on the Exit Door: it must be mimicking a Yurei, it must use the door-closing ability on the exit door, and the Ultraviolet evidence is not hidden. Hence, this occurrence is very rare. *It is impossible to get the Doom Slayed achievement against a Mimic due to it remaining in its "blank" state for 1 minute at the beginning of the contract and therefore cannot use the Demon's ability in the required timespan. *Since the new alphabetical sorting, the Mimic is sorted under 'the' before The Twins, rather than being listed before Moroi. This may throw people off when looking for the name. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.5.0 |Added The Mimic. |} ==References== ==Notes== Category:Ghosts fr:Le Mimic
title: The Mimic

content:
The photo camera is a piece of equipment in Phasmophobia. It is a digital camera that can be used to take pictures of objects in-game. While it is not used for gathering evidence, its main use is to gather photo evidence, as well as being necessary for certain objectives and tasks. ==Usage== The photo camera automatically turns on while held outside the truck. For the Tier II and III cameras, an additional display shows a preview of what the camera will capture at the moment it is used, and helps players frame the photo subject. Each photo camera can take an unlimited number of photos, but only the first 5 pictures taken will count towards earning rewards and completing objectives. Upon taking a picture, the flash will go off, and a photo preview will show up on the camera for Tier II and III cameras. Any pictures taken of a reflective surface will show the lens flash in the picture, such as a television, or the axe that one of the possible ghost models wields. The cooldown between photo depends on the Tier of the photo camera (3 seconds for Tier I, 2 seconds for Tier II, and 1 second for Tier III). Note that while the camera is cooling down, the player cannot switch to and use another item; they can, however, use items placed down/dropped on the floor. When a ghost manifests during a ghost event or a hunt, the photo camera's display will be distorted, as well as any pictures taken. Pictures taken in this state will still be labeled in the journal if a valid subject is detected. Holding a Tier II or III photo camera within 7.5 metres of a ghost (2.5 metres for the Yokai) during a hunt on the same floor will attract the ghost. The Tier I photo camera will only attract the ghost when a picture is taken. ===Rewards=== The first 5 labeled pictures recorded in the journal will reward the player with money and experience. Like other media evidence, the value of photos is determined by its Unique or Duplicate tag. While the first photo of a subject will grant full reward, additional photos of the same subject taken during the same contract will provide only 20% of the normal reward. If there are no available slots for photos inside the journal (which can hold 5 photos for the whole team), any further shots will not net any gains. If a shot is missed or judged unsatisfactory, players have the option to delete up to three pieces of media from the journal. In multiplayer, a majority vote from the players is required to delete a photo, signaled by a red icon on the Media tab of the Journal. ==Objectives== {| class="fandom-table" !Objective !Actual requirements |- |Capture a photo of the ghost | - |} ==Gallery==
Journal photo 0.5.1.0.png|Photos of various objects in the journal.
==Trivia== *Captured photos are intentionally not synced over with other players, and are instead taken and rendered individually on each client to improve performance. This can cause confusion, as this often leads to the photo angle being different and causing objects to be in frame for one person but not so for another. *The real-life camera models for each tier are: **Tier I: Polaroid OneStep 600 Flash (Polaroid "rebranded" as Polteroid) **Tier II: Sony W800 compact camera (Sony "rebranded" as Bony) **Tier III: Sony a7RV mirrorless camera body + Sony SEL2470GM2 lens (Sony "rebranded" as Bony) ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.3.0 |Changed the photo camera model. |- !0.6.0 |Reduced the cooldown between taking pictures from 3 seconds to 1 second. |- ! rowspan="3" |0.9.0 |The Photo Camera now has 3 tiers. |- |The photo camera is no longer starter equipment. It unlocks at level 3. |- |Removed the 5-photo limit on photo cameras. |}
