content: The 0.6.0 update, also known as the VR Overhaul update, is a major update to the game released on 7 April 2022. This update includes reworks to the VR player experience, an upgrade to the Unity version, and a rework of the Sound Sensor. == Additions == === Gameplay === ;VR *VR system moved from SteamVR to OpenXR, offering better performance and stability **Support for "all major headsets" **All OpenXR runtimes now supported *Cursor now avaible for when hovering over equipment *Two options for grabbing objects **Toggle: Press once to grab, press again to release **Hold: Keep button pressed down to keep hold of the object *Equipment belt and head camera slots in the truck now highlight when attempting to slot something into them *New VR Seated and Left Handed modes *New height calibration options *New hand poses and animations for different actions *Players can now swap objects between both hands by grabbing *New simulated crouch by pressing right thumbstick/trackpad *Snap turn can now be done by pressing down, when enabled *Walkie-talkie and journal now placed on belt for easier use *Improved VR throwing physics *New smooth camera mode for recording and streaming *New models and textures for VR belt *New left-handed mode for equipment to be toggleable in left hand *Known issues: **Scrollbars in the main menu are hard to use **Objects will need to be grabbed twice if the VR player was not the last to grab them **Applying settings whilst crouched resets player height **Some cabinet doors can't be grabbed ;General *New sound effects, including to lockers == Changes == === Equipment === ;Parabolic Microphone *Will now update every 1 second instead of 2 seconds *No longer reads noise from players talking or using walkie-talkie ;Sound Sensor *Updated model *Now covers spherical area instead of a cube, with increased range *Now placed in same way as candles and cameras *Sounds now displayed more accurately when shown on the monitor in the truck *No longer reads noise from players talking or using walkie-talkie ;Sanity Pills *Price reduced to $20 **Changed to accomodate a bug where sanity pills were not removed from inventory when used or the player died ;Truck screens *Updated design === Evidence === ;Fingerprints *New designs for singular fingerprints (as opposed to handprints) *Ridgeview Road House and Tanglewood Street House: fingerprints can now be left on patio doors *Will now be on the light switch instead of on the paneling next to it ===Gameplay=== ;Journal *Ghosts can now be crossed off individually *Improved scrolling with scroll wheel ;Hiding spots *Hiding spots which are made infeasible will now have furniture removed instead of blocking them *All maps now have at least one (or more) hiding spots depending on difficulty **Amateur: All spots available **Intermediate: ≥3 hiding spots **Professional: ≥2 hiding spots **Nightmare: ≥1 hiding spot *Doors, objects, and walls have been added or moved to remove several unintended safe spots *Maple Lodge Campsite: New door flaps for small tents *Willow Street House: Significant changes to make hiding spots much more consistent *New slots in locker doors for the player to see through ;Map adjustments *Audio adjustments to improve distinction between different floors *Assets have been moved for better alignment with environment *Improved sink tap effects **New sink tap audio *Light switches in several maps have been moved for more consistency *Several floors have had their materials changed *Spotlights in several houses changed to also illuminate ceiling *Plug sockets changed from EU-style (220v) to US-style (110v) *Edgefield Street House: new light switch and ceiling light in basement *Maple Lodge Campsite: new light switch to cleaning closet *Ridgeview Road House, Edgefield Street House and Tanglewood Street House: Lighting adjustments to improve performance *Tanglewood Street House: Computer is now turned on with keyboard instead of screen *Optimised polygon count of blue beds in some house maps by 119,000 polys ;Other *Dead players can now sprint infinitely *New eyelashes for player models *Many new first and last names for ghosts *House maps: ghosts can now interact with keyboards to turn on desktop computers *Previous photos showcased in the lobby are now easier to see *Improved thunder sound effects during heavy rain *Placement holograms no longer cast or receive shadows ;Voice chat *Three options now available: Voice activation, Push-to-talk, or an On/Off toggle ===Ghosts=== ;Obake *Now leaves special evidence on more surfaces **Double fingerprints on light switches **Five fingerprints on prison doors and keyboards === General === *Soft Shadows setting now applies to all lights instead of only equipment lights *Updated Unity engine *Volumetric Lighting setting temporarily removed, to be re-added with Foggy weather in a later update == Bug fixes == *Fixed a bug where some ghost events didn’t play ghost sounds *Fixed a bug where you could sometimes grab a tent door that was not visible (e.g., behind you) *Fixed a bug where some lights in the farmhouses wouldn’t stop your sanity draining *Fixed a bug where the Onryo wouldn’t interact correctly if you didn’t get the Summoning Circle Cursed Possession *Fixed a bug where the ghost event objective would complete when there was no ghost event *Fixed a safe spot in the Ridgeview garage *Fixed a bug where sprint stamina wasn’t re-generating if you had your journal open *Fixed a bug where the journal brightness setting was higher than the main menu setting *Fixed a bug where after a hunt; the ghosts audio would fade out and back in briefly *Fixed a bug where Sanity Pills were not being removed from your inventory if used or if you died *Fixed a bug where the mist ghost event wasnt working correctly *Fixed a bug where the ghost would not walk towards you during some ghost events ==References== Category:Development fr:0.6.0

Incense is a purchasable item that can be used to temporarily deter the ghost from hunting or blind the ghost during a hunt when ignited. ==Usage== To light incense, have an igniter in the inventory, hold the incense, then press the key. Incense thrown on the ground can also be lit by aiming at it while holding an igniter or firelight, then pressing . Once lit, the incense will emit smoke for a certain amount of time depending on the tier level: *Tier I: 5 seconds *Tier II: 6 seconds *Tier III: 7 seconds While burning, the incense attempts multiple times per second to successfully apply its effect(s), but can only apply the effect(s) once. When the incense is used up, the smoke will stop being emitted and the model will finish burning to a stub. There is no explicit indication of whether the incense was used effectively or not. Used incense can still be handheld, but since there's nothing to use, it is normally discarded. ===Effects=== The incense has a range in which the ghost must be for its effects to be successfully applied. This range depends on the tier level: *Tier I: 3 metres *Tier II: 4 metres *Tier III: 5 metres ====Regular "cleansing"==== When the ghost is within the incense's range while it is burning, the following will occur: *Ghost activity will be increased marginally *The ghost will be unable to initiate a hunt on its own for a certain duration: **Demon: 60 seconds **Spirit: 180 seconds **All other ghosts: 90 seconds *If the ghost is a Gallu, it will switch to its "enraged" state if it was in a "normal" state, or to its "normal" state if it was in a "weakened" state. *If the ghost is a Yurei, it will also return to its favorite room and cannot roam out for 90 seconds. This will not prevent ghost events from happening outside the room. Lighting incense will not prevent cursed hunts nor stop an already ongoing hunt, but doing this during a hunt will prevent further attempts to initiate regular hunts for the specified duration starting from when the incense effect is applied. If another incense is used while this effect from a previous incense is ongoing, this effect will not be re-applied and the timer will not be reset. Due to a quirk in how incense works, ghosts which are standing on stairs will not be affected by the "cleansing" property of incense, though they will be affected by the "blinding" ability described below. ====Blinding during hunts====
This image has flashing lights.
Incense can be used to "blind" the ghost during a hunt. For this effect to apply, the ghost must be within the incense's range. When the effect is successfully applied, the ghost will: *Be forced into its "wandering phase", walking in a random direction *Be unable to detect or kill players; one can walk through it without dying *Temporarily lose its accumulated speed from line-of-sight *The Tier II incense additionally slows the ghost down to 50% of its speed. *The Tier III incense additionally stops the ghost from moving entirely. This effect lasts for 5 seconds for most ghosts, 4 seconds for an enraged Gallu, 6 seconds for a weakened Gallu, and 7.5 seconds for a Moroi. After this period, the ghost will return to its regular hunting behaviour, and be able to see and kill players again. Multiple incenses can be used for the same purpose during the same hunt with no diminishing returns, to blind the ghost for up to 20 seconds (30 for a Moroi) consecutively. If another incense is used while this effect from a previous incense is ongoing, this effect will be re-applied and the timer will be reset. ==Tips== *When lighting incense near a ghost during a hunt, the ghost may coincidentally take the same path as a player, especially in tight hallways. It does not mean that the ghost can still see the player. If possible, light the incense near (but not in) a hiding spot, so that you can reach it before the ghost is no longer blind. *If you are not the host, and especially if there is some latency between you and the server, the game may register the ghost killing the player before the incense effect actually applies. To avoid this, try lighting the incense earlier. *In some scenarios, it may be beneficial to use a lower-tier incense, for example if the ghost detects a player in a hiding spot and corners them, and an incense is used to protect the player; using a Tier III incense will freeze the ghost in place, possibly in a location where they can still see the player in the hiding spot and force them to switch to another hiding spot, while a Tier I or Tier II incense will cause the ghost to move away and allow the player to stay in said hiding spot. Using a lower-tier incense is also beneficial if the ghost is significantly faster than the player e.g. against a naturally fast ghost such as a young Thaye, or in custom difficulties where the ghost is faster and/or the player is slower; a Tier I incense will allow the ghost to stay relatively fast while blind, potentially moving the ghost much further away and putting a much larger distance between the player and the ghost compared to a Tier II or Tier III incense. ==Gallery== Smudge sticks.png|Pre-Exposition model being held in the player's hand. ==Objectives== {| class="article-table" !Objective !Actual requirements |- |Cleanse the area near the ghost using Incense |Light Incense within range of the ghost |- |Repel the Ghost with Incense while it's chasing someone |Smudge a hunting ghost while it has line-of-sight with a player, making it wander |} ==Trivia== *Before 0.9.0, Incense was referred to as "Smudge Sticks". Despite being referred to as "smudging", the smudge sticks are used more akin to "smoke cleansing". Smudging is a spiritual and religious practice found in various Native American cultures, many of which use white sage, a plant native to North America. Smudging is typically used for personal spiritual cleansing, prayer, and ceremonial occasions, the technique varying from tribe to tribe. Smoke cleansing, on the other hand, is used predominantly to ward off negative energy and evil spirits, and is used by wafting the smoke of sage or herbs around an area, sometimes accompanied by prayer, chanting, or incantations. Smoke cleansing is a practice commonly found in modern-day Wicca and witchcraft. *The original description for this item was as follows: "This has always been one of the main ways to weaken the more common ghosts. To do this you will need to grab some Smudge Sticks and burn it near the Ghost." ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !6 February 2020 |Increased the effective distance of White Sage. |- !28 March 2020 |Renamed White Sage to Smudge Sticks. |- ! rowspan="2" |15 July 2020 |The ghost no longer has a chance to change rooms after Smudge Sticks are used. |- |Using Smudge Sticks near the ghost now temporarily increases its activity. |- !10 September 2020 |Smudge Sticks now stop active hunts if lit near the ghost. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !26 September 2020 |The Smudge Sticks smoke is now more noticeable. |- !28 September 2020 |Smudge Sticks no longer stop active hunts, and instead prevent the ghost from killing players for a short time while making it wander. |- !0.29.6 |Smudge Sticks now smoke for 6 seconds instead of 15 seconds. |- !0.3.0 |Changed the Smudge Sticks model. |- !? |The smudge effects can now apply while burning instead of at the start or end of burning. |- !0.6.2.3 |The player can no longer light other players' smudge sticks. |- ! rowspan="7" |0.9.0 |Renamed to Incense. |- |The Incense now has 3 tiers. |- |The interval in which the ghost checks if an Incense is active, is now much smaller, making repelling the ghost much more consistent. |- |Using Incense during another Incense's blinding effect will now reset the blinding timer instead of doing nothing. |- |Now a "consumable" item; tiers I and II will be consumed when used on contracts. |- |Incense will now have an extra 50% duration (per Tier) against Moroi. |- |You can no longer repel the ghost for another player with an unlimited range (e.g. lighting a smudge in the truck). |- !0.13.0 |Incense will now temporarily disable a ghost's accumulated speed from line-of-sight. |}

The sound recorder is a device used to record sound evidence. ==Mechanics== The Sound Recorder can be on to begin scanning the area for any noise disturbance produced by the ghost. When it detects a valid noise, its sound meter will start to rise, indicating to the player how close they are to the source of the sound. To record a sound, the player must hold the button to start recording and get sufficiently close to the source (indicated by the meter lights turning green on Tier I, the graph going above the bar on Tier II, and the circle at the center of the radar turning solid on Tier III). The recording will stop automatically once a valid sound is captured. Up to 3 audio clips can be stored in the journal per contract. The recorder picks up ghost-related sounds such as whispers or ghost events, as well as evidence-related sounds such as Spirit Box responses, Ghost Writing, or EMF Level 5. The quality of the recording depends on the proximity to the sound and the tier of the recorder. The Tier III Sound Recorder has directional audio and visual indicators that can be helpful in locating the source of the sound. ===Ghost-related mechanics=== *The Banshee has a 33% chance to produce one of its unique shrieks instead of a regular paranormal sound. *The Moroi can curse a player who successfully records a sound. *The Myling produces paranormal sounds on the sound recorder more frequently. ==Tips== *Sound Recorders (especially the Tier III) can be used to locate the ghost by following the sound levels it picks up, much like the EMF reader with EMF signatures. Due to their relatively short range however, they are best used on smaller maps. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.13.0 |Added the Sound Recorder. |- !0.13.1.0 |An audio and visual cue will now signify the completion of recording Sounds. |}

The Sound Sensor is a piece of Equipment in Phasmophobia. It detects sounds in a large area around it, allowing the player to track potential ghost activity in combination with the Sound Monitor. ==Usage== A sound sensor can be on the ground or other flat surface. The detection area is highlighted as an orange circle on the Site Map in the truck. The sound sensor picks up most noises, except for players talking through local and global chat. Any noise picked up by a sensor will appear as a bar on the Sound Monitor, showing how loud the sound was and identifying which sensor picked up the sound. The screen will display the total volume of all sounds detected. The value displayed will update every second. By default, the sound sensor picks up sound in a 5-meter radius on the same floor, ignoring walls. This radius can be increased by clicking on the enlargement icon on the Sound Monitor in the truck. The sound sensor can also be muted by clicking on the speaker icon. The Tier III Sound Sensor has two additional modes which can be switched to by with it while it is placed, or directly while in hand. These modes can't be switched from the truck. ==Tips== *A Sound Sensor can be used to monitor Ghost Writing evidence as the Ghost Writing Book produces a distinctive scribbling sound when the ghost writes in it. *Placing sound sensors in a central area of several rooms is a good way to cover a lot of ground when looking for the ghost's location early on. ==Trivia== *Sound sensors detect the noise of the Haunted Mirror if it is in their range. *Some equipment are not picked up by the sound sensor such as the EMF Reader and the Spirit Box. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- ! rowspan="2" |24 March 2020
(Part 2) |Added a preview outline when placing a sound sensor. |- |More sounds can now be detected. |- !19 June 2020 |Sound sensors are now level-locked. |- !27 June 2020 |Sound sensors are now unlocked at level 7. |- ! rowspan="2" |13 August 2020 |Sound sensors can now be picked up after being placed. |- |Increased the cost from $60 to $80. |- !16 August 2020(Part 2) |Sound sensors now detect doors being shut. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.4.0 |Sound sensors can now be placed on the floor. |- ! rowspan="5" |0.6.0 |Changed the sound sensor model. |- |The range covered is now a spherical radius instead of a cube. |- |Placement now matches that of other equipment such as candles and video cameras. |- |Sounds on sound monitor in the van are now more accurately displayed. |- |Players talking or using the walkie-talkie (global chat) are no longer picked up. |- !0.7.0 |Sound sensors now show room name of the room it is physically in, instead of the room the player was standing in when they placed it. |- !0.9.0 |The Sound Sensor now has 3 tiers. |- !0.9.5.0 |You can now rotate the Sound Sensor III whilst placing it. |- !0.10.0 |Sound sensors can now be muted from the truck. |}

Training is a tutorial mission available in Phasmophobia, designed to help new players learn the essential aspects of the investigation process. It provides a basic overview of most in-game mechanics, including hunts and how to utilize evidence-based equipment to gather evidence. The Training mission uses a specially-built location simply called "Warehouse", which consists of a series of rooms that are divided into several stages for each lesson. On a technical level, there is not an actual active "ghost" in Training, and instead aspects of its behavior are emulated via scripted triggers. Tutorials are given by both text written on white boards and vocal instructions from the man over the radio used in many other parts of the game, and inform the player to complete a certain task to progress further in the tutorial. On most whiteboards, a series of colored post-it notes will list out the control scheme. It is possible to back-track to already-completed sections for review purposes. Once the mission is completed, the player goes back to the truck and returns to the main lobby. The Journal is accessible during training, but as there are no rewards, it is pointless to try to select the ghost type. == Structure ==
The Warehouse is a special small map created for Training, and is not otherwise playable. It is a linear series of rooms made up of raised drywall, plywood, planks, and doors located within a dark, spartan warehouse made of primarily concrete. There are no exit doors, though some sections will remain locked until their objectives are completed. The Warehouse is a winding, linear experience leading the player through a step-by-step lesson of the basic mechanics of the game. The training is divided in several "stages" separated by locked doors, in which the player must perform a specific action in order to proceed to the next one. There are a total of 11 stages, each introducing the player to a specific element of gameplay, including all evidence types. == Stages == === Stage 1: Essentials === The player gets an overview of the most basic mechanics: taking a Flashlight from the Truck, pressing the keypad to open the Truck's back door and lower the ramp, acquiring the Key, and opening doors to progress though a line of rooms, simply labeled Rooms One through Three. A "ghost" will occasionally throw items in Room Three as the player passes through. Although the player is told to take a Flashlight and the key to continue, they are technically optional, and the player can progress onwards without them. === Stage 2: Sanity === The player is introduced to the mechanic of Sanity and how to restore it. This stage features tier 1 Sanity Medication the player must drink in order to progress to the next stage. === Stage 3: Lights === The player is introduced to the mechanics related to lights, such as passive sanity drain and the fuse box. This room contains three light switches which each control one light. Turning all lights on will trip the fuse box and allow the player to proceed to the next stage. === Stage 4: EMF === The player is introduced to the EMF evidence. The player is offered a tier 1 EMF Reader and invited into a room with several items placed on tables. Eventually, an invisible force will throw the items around the room, creating EMF readings. The player must find an EMF 5 reading with the reader to proceed to the next stage. === Stage 5: Ultraviolet === The player is introduced to the Ultraviolet evidence. The player is provided with a tier 1 UV Light which they must use to reveal a handprint on the door and a footprint around the room leading to the next stage. === Stage 6: Freezing Temperatures === The player is introduced to the Freezing Temperatures evidence. Provided with a tier 1 Thermometer, the player must search several rooms and find which one has below-freezing temperatures to proceed to the next stage. === Stage 7: D.O.T.S Projector === The player is introduced to the D.O.T.S evidence. Provided with a tier 1 D.O.T.S Projector, the player must enter a dark room and reveal a group of ghost dummies with it to proceed to the next stage. === Stage 8: Ghost Orbs === The player is introduced to the Ghost Orbs evidence. Provided with a tier 1 Video Camera, the player has to search a dark room for Ghost Orbs. The stage completes after staring at the orb for 2 seconds while being near it. === Stage 9: Ghost Writing === The player is introduced to the Ghost Writing evidence. The player must place a tier 1 Ghost Writing Book in a neighboring room and wait for it to be signed in order to proceed to the next stage. === Stage 10: Spirit Box === The player is introduced to the Spirit Box evidence. Using a tier 1 Spirit Box, the player must attempt to obtain an answer to proceed to the next stage. The "ghost" will sometimes be in a neighboring room with a light that must be turned off in order to obtain an answer. === Stage 11: Hunts === The player is introduced to hunts and the Setup Timer. In this stage, the player must enter a room featuring several lockers and hiding spots where they will be confronted with the simulation of a hunt. When the player enters the room, all doors will lock and hunt effects (such as lights and electronics flickering) will occur. Only when the player has entered a hiding spot and turned off their electronics, a ghost will appear at the entry door and cross the room before disappearing. If the player is spotted by the ghost, they will be teleported back to the beginning of the stage. The stage concludes once the player remains hidden until the ghost disappears. == Trivia == *Internally, the Warehouse map is referred to as "TrainingV2". *The Truck at the end of Training is actually a separate vehicle, and not the same one the player started from. This can be easily noticed, as this separate Truck will not have any flashlights in it. *The "ghost" in Training provides six types of evidence: EMF Level 5, Ultraviolet, Freezing Temperatures, Ghost Orbs, Ghost Writing, and Spirit Box, which does not indicate an actual ghost that is in the game as ghosts only have three evidence types associated with them. *Prior to the Ascension update, the Training mission consisted of 6 Tanglewood Drive with a random ghost that could give evidence but could not hunt, similar to the "Friendly Ghost" custom difficulty option. It came with tips on the TV screen located in the Living Room that explained what each equipment did. As with the current iteration of Training, no rewards were given at the end of the mission. **Additionally, as this was a "regular" level, and before the Ouija Board became a cursed possession in 0.5.0, it could occasionally spawn in the map. This still could not get the ghost to hunt, as the Ouija Board could not break and trigger a cursed hunt during that time. *It is possible that the current Training mission—or at least the Warehouse map that it takes place in—was intended to be accessible from multiplayer lobbies by teams up to four players at once, however as of 0.9.0 the mission is only accessible from the main menu and can only be played by a single player. *In the early years of alpha, training was available as a lobby mission for co-op (probably to test out chat features, etc.); this has since been removed. == History == {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" | Early Access |- ! rowspan="2"| 0.9.0 | Changed the training map to be a Warehouse instead of 6 Tanglewood Drive. |- | The training now shows the player how to use each evidence equipments, and gives tips and tricks on how to play the game in a controlled environment. |- ! rowspan="4"|0.10.0 |Lowered the temperature of the training to make it easier to get Freezing Temperatures. |- |Reduced the amount of equipment to one in each room. |- |The player will now have to get EMF Level 5 to get past the EMF room. |- |Replaced the glowstick with the UV flashlight as of the tier change. |} Category:Gameplay fr:Entraînement

The video feed (also known as CCTV or Camera System) is a feature used to give players extra surveillance from inside the truck, with each map having a few angles covered by video cameras already present on the location. The video feed is accessible by using the computer. == Usage == Each map will have a specific number of CCTV cameras installed on-site. CCTV cameras are always enabled, regardless of whether the fuse box is turned on or not. CCTV cameras cannot be taken by players or disabled. The location of all CCTV cameras pre-installed will be visible on the Site Map. The CCTV camera currently displayed on the computer will also be indicated on the site map by a beam of light showing the camera's approximate facing. Video feed from video cameras will also be available on the computer, but these will not be shown on the site map. == Trivia == * It is possible (though uncommon) on some maps for players to see Ghost Orbs via the CCTV cameras, if the camera happens to be able to view into the ghost room. Ghost Orbs spawn before opening the exit door, so it will be helpful if spotted beforehand. Category:Gameplay fr:Flux vidéo

The summoning circle is a cursed possession that is used to summon the ghost. This can be used to get a ghost photo, as well as facilitate the completion of several Objectives. ==Mechanics== As a cursed possession, the summoning circle has a 1 in 7 chance of being the chosen item that will spawn on a map on preset difficulties, with one spawn location per map. ===Usage=== The summoning circle can be used by lighting all five red candles by aiming at them and by pressing the button with a lit igniter or a lit firelight. Each lit candle deducts 16% sanity from nearby players. Contrary to other fire sources, ghosts cannot light these candles up. Summoning circle candles can be blown out by the ghost, in the same way as regular firelights. However, they cannot self-extinguish except when lit while the player has less than 16% sanity. Relighting an extinguished candle will drain 16% sanity again for nearby players. Once all five candles are lit, the ghost is summoned and fully materialized, except a Shade, which has a chance of appearing as a transparent shadow. The summoned ghost stays motionless for 5 seconds, unable to kill players. This stationary period is considered a ghost event. However, the front door will lock immediately after lighting the last candle. After this event, the lights in the summoning circle's room will turn off and the ghost will immediately initiate a cursed hunt on the spot, without an additional 1-second grace period. Once the summoning circle is activated, it cannot be used again. If a candle is lit while below 16% individual sanity, there are two possibilities that might occur: *If it is not the last candle, the candle will extinguish itself after a short delay. *If it is the last candle, there will be no "ghost event" period, and the cursed hunt will immediately begin after a 1-second grace period. If the last candle is lit while a hunt is ongoing, the ghost will instead be teleported to the centre of the circle, possibly killing players on the spot; this does not reset the current hunt's timer, but will extend all future hunts as usual. ===Rewards=== Taking a photo of a summoning circle, used or not, will yield a photo labelled as Summoning Circle, and reward up to $7 and 7 XP, depending on the tier of the Photo Camera. ==Tips== *Using a Tier 3 crucifix in range of the Summoning Circle will prevent the cursed hunt triggered after summoning the ghost, virtually removing the risk of the Circle, though the massive sanity cost for using the Circle (16% per candle for a total of 80%) still poses a problem. *To prevent a hunt starting before the ghost can be summoned, use incense or place crucifixes near the ghost just before lighting the circle. *Where needed, most Optional Objectives can be completed directly or indirectly using the Summoning Circle. **As such, it is best saved for after the ghost has been identified to quickly complete them. ==Trivia== *Before 0.9.3.0, the border of the Summoning Circle used to repeat the English words "sacrifice your sanity" transliterated into a runic alphabet. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.5.0 |Added summoning circle. |- !0.5.0.2 |Summoning circles now deduct 16% sanity per candle instead of 20% for when the ghost materialises. |- !0.7.0 |The ghost will now hunt instantly if the player has less than 16% sanity when lighting the last candle. |- !0.8.1.0 |Lighting a Summoning Circle candle with no sanity will now extinguish it instantly.
Note: Lighting the 5th candle with no sanity will cause an instant hunt. |- !0.9.3.0 |Updated the textures, audio, and effects for the Summoning Circle |} ==Notes== Category:Item fr:Cercle d'invocation ru:Круг призыва
title: Summoning Circle

Sunny Meadows Mental Institution (or simply Sunny Meadows) is a map in Phasmophobia and the largest by number of rooms, succeeding the original Asylum map. It is a two-story decrepit psychiatric hospital that can either be played as a whole map or separated into five Restricted areas, one of which is randomly selected for the contract. ==Description== Sunny Meadows seems to once have been a Catholic parish/asylum as it features an old chapel and has several nods to it having once been a religious institution. Unlike most other maps, the building seems to be completely abandoned, and even somewhat in a hurry (for example, most of the "surgical" equipment in the morgue is still in place, as are some decaying corpses and human body parts). It is unclear what exactly made the asylum shut down and how long ago it happened. It is a run-down, cluttered environment, with every footstep reverberating through the halls. Take note of the ghost's scratching along the walls, and beware its wrath -- you may find yourself separated from your fellow investigators during a hunt as the wings' doors lock shut. While the derelict stone environment and profane Chapel are eerie enough, the true horrors lie within the location's bowels: blood-stained walls, rotting corpses, and piles of gore provide ample indication of the atrocities performed within. The screams of the poor souls tortured and slain within its dark confines can still be heard through the quiet blackness. ==Structure== Sunny Meadows contains 69 rooms, split into 5 wings and across 2 floors, as well as an outdoor courtyard. The wings are: *Courtyard Wing: Built around a large courtyard, this wing contains amenities for patients and visitors as well as staff facilities. *Male Wing: This wing contains several bedrooms, a dormitory, a common bathroom, as well as a day room for the male patients of the institution. *Female Wing: This wing contains several bedrooms, a dormitory, a common bathroom, as well as a day room for the female patients of the institution. *Hospital Wing: This wing contains several common hospital rooms as well as an operating room and a macabre morgue, still reeking with the remains of its past residents. *Restricted Wing: This wing was presumably where the most aggressive or unfortunate patients received their "treatments" under the form of brutal torture, containing several cells filled with blood and gore. ===Layout tips=== *A labeled map, albeit one that is weathered and altogether difficult to read, is provided in the Entrance Corridor. **The room names Servant Room 1 and Servant Room 2 are swapped on this map from what is actually defined in-game. *Certain rooms contain old bell-type alarm clocks and metronomes which the ghost might interact with. *The crosses found hanging on the walls in various parts of the building can be turned upside down by the ghost, which will emit a loud scratching sound. Finding a cross that has been turned upside down (except for the ones in the Chapel) is a strong sign that the ghost is nearby. Crosses cannot be flipped back upright once they have been interacted with. *In general, the main hallways are littered with props and obstructions; running in a straight line without bumping into something is generally not feasible. *The ghost cannot perform a ghost event on players that are standing in the following rooms: **Basement west corridor **Restricted area (the corridor, not the individual rooms) **Courtyard corridor **Female wing (the corridor, not the individual rooms) **Male wing (the corridor, not the individual rooms) *The favourite room cannot be any of the corridors and stairwells, barring the entrance corridor next to the chapel; either of the padded rooms; and the Foyer on the large version of the map (the Foyer can be the favourite room on the Restricted version, however). *There is currently a bug where if the ghost is in the Entrance Corridor, the Ouija Board might respond with its current location as Bake House instead. *The following rooms count as dark rooms and hence will drain sanity with 80 % of the rate, even with all room lights being on: **Connecting corridor, courtyard corridor, right entrance stairwell, left entrance stairwell, classroom, kitchen, male wing (hallway), female wing (hallway), hospital wing (hallway), basement west corridor, basement corridor, basement east corridor, restricted area (hallway), morgue, west stairwell and east stairwell *The chapel, courtyard, male room 5 and restricted room 2 have no main room lights and hence no means of sanity drain prevention (other than firelights). See Third-party tools for a list of detailed map viewers that players may use. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== *When a Hunt begins, the door to each wing will lock, forcing hunters to work with the area of the map that they find themselves in as the hunt begins, potentially separating players from one-another. As such, it is wise to check for hiding spots both near where investigation is taking place and in wings on the route to the favourite room, as running to known hiding spots may not be possible. Beware, the ghost can still pass through these doors during a hunt. *When running away from a ghost, make good use of the various props such as dividers and cabinets cluttering the hallways in order to repeatedly break line of sight and reach a hiding spot or even throw it off, as more often than not the hiding spots are located at the ends and beginnings of hallways. There are 28 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Sunny Meadows: *Manager's Office, behind a cupboard *Infirmary, lockers *Male Room 1, behind an upright standing bed (only if the bed is not against the back wall) *Male Wing, behind a gurney and a tilted shelf near door to Courtyard Corridor *Male Wing, behind a gurney and a tilted shelf in front of Male Room 5 *Male Wing, behind a bookshelf near Male Dorm Room *Male Day Room, behind a shelf on the right *Male Dorm Room, behind a tilted bed and a tilted coffee table *West Visitors' Room, behind a shelf on the left *Classroom, behind a shelf (only restricted version of the map can be selected independently of the main location, and is considered a medium map. In the Restricted version, only the immediate entrance area (including the Chapel where the Cursed possessions spawn) and one randomly-selected wing of the building will be able to be accessed, with the entrances to the others being blocked off. ===Layout tips=== *Contrary to the map's Large version, the Foyer in Sunny Meadows Restricted can be chosen as the favourite room. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 6 "sanctioned" hiding spots in this variation of Sunny Meadows Restricted: *Manager's Office, behind a cupboard *Infirmary, lockers *West Visitors' Room, behind a shelf on the left *Classroom, behind a shelf (only when there are two shelves) *Servants' Room 2, behind a cupboard *Utility Room, behind the racks at the far end (only when cardboard boxes are present) Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots may be blocked by the presence of bulky items or their concealing elements removed: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 2 *Professional: 3 *Nightmare/Insanity: 5 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None - Restricted Wing= ===Layout tips=== *Contrary to the map's Large version, the Foyer in Sunny Meadows Restricted can be chosen as the favourite room. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 5 "sanctioned" hiding spots in this variation of Sunny Meadows Restricted: *Manager's Office, behind a cupboard *Basement Corridor, behind a bookshelf near the possible fuse box location *Matron Office, behind a cupboard *Basement East Corridor, behind multiple privacy screens near door to Restricted Area *Restricted Area, behind multiple privacy screens in a U-shape next to Restricted Room 3 Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots may be blocked by their concealing elements being removed: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 2 *Professional: 3 *Nightmare/Insanity: 4 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overridden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None }} ==Bone locations== Bones spawn randomly, but will only spawn in areas that a ghost can also walk on. Due to the large size of the map when playing the regular variant, it is usually best left to chance for players to find the bone, or to make use of the Ouija Board if it spawns, instead of attempting to search every room for it. However, finding the bone on the Restricted variant without paranormal assistance is feasible, due to the smaller search area. As of version 0.14.0, due to a bug, the bone always spawns at the western edge of the Entrance Corridor, just to the left of the door to the Courtyard Corridor. ==Cursed possession locations== All the cursed possessions are located in the Chapel: the Monkey Paw at the foot of the large crucifix, and five other possessions arranged around the Summoning Circle in the middle. ==Fuse box locations== There are 5 locations where the fuse box can spawn: *In the foyer on the left wall *In the utility, the first room to the right that can be entered after the chapel *In the courtyard on the wall separating the chapel *In the boiler house *In the basement corridor next to the stairwell exit ==Apocalypse Challenge== The Apocalypse Challenge can only be completed in Sunny Meadows. This is indicated with a golden skull on the map polaroid of the map selection board when in Singleplayer. ==Trivia== *A number of tags each listing a possible wish for the Monkey Paw can be found in various rooms. *Ghosts can blow out some of the lit candles that are found in the Chapel. This may even result in an early Onryo hunt. *Despite being classified as a large map, Sunny Meadows is actually smaller than both Prison and Brownstone High School—both originally Medium maps—by floor area within the map (investigation area). *One can light brought-in firelights without an igniter by throwing them against the Chapel candles. By extension, the summoning circle can also be lit without an igniter. Tier III firelights are best suited for this, as they will never extinguish by themselves or by throwing them. *Sunny Meadows Restricted was originally a Small map, and was changed to Medium in 0.10.0, making it the second map to change size classes across versions of the game. *Female Day Room, Male Day Room, as well as West Visitors' Room each have a standing lamp that needs to be turned on in addition to the main room lights for full sanity drain prevention. *The stairs in Right Entrance Stairwell look to lead to a possible upper floor, however they are blocked up. ==Easter eggs== *The map contains various elements which seems to be telling the story of one of the ghost models, semi-officially named Patient 07. **In 0.6.0.1, the "pajama girl" ghost model was changed to wear white gowns with a barcode and a label saying "Patient 07". In the same update, on the former Asylum map, one of the patient rooms had tally marks counting up to 1080 on its walls which could be revealed using a UV flashlight or Glowstick, as well as the following writing:

I have to leave
Somewhere new
I don't belong here
I'll go soon
To get better, I hope
I found a new home
Sunny Meadows
Sounds nice, a place to heal

**In Padded Room 1 in the Hospital Wing, tally marks counting up to 7560 can be seen with a UV Flashlight or Glowstick, as well as bloody handprints covering the door. This suggests that it might have been Patient 07's room once she was transferred to Sunny Meadows, or at least was locked in there for a significant period of time (approximately 20.7 years if the marks are counted as days). **Finally, Patient 07's corpse can be found rotting in the Morgue. This means that Patient 07 died (most likely of poor treatment and brutal torture) in Sunny Meadows and that her tormented soul has since been condemned to haunt the world of the living. *If the player lights the Summoning Circle in Custom difficulty with at least six cursed possessions in the game, every lit candle will turn a crucifix in the room upside down. If the last candle is lit, the large cross in the Chapel will ignite. **The temperature of the ignited large cross is (the devil's number). **This easter egg is hinted at by many writings on the Chapel's walls. "Six Becomes One" is written multiple times both using Latin and runic alphabets. *A potato can be found in the Bake House, inside the 2nd oven from the left on the top row. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.7.0 |Added Sunny Meadows Mental Institution/Restricted. |- !0.7.1.0 |Added window-knocking sounds to windows. |- !0.7.1.2 |The boilers now have a burning loop sound. |- !0.7.1.4 |The ghost can no longer do ghost events in most hallways (basement west corridor, restricted area, courtyard corridor, female wing and male wing). |- !0.8.0 |Improved two hiding spots; one by the restricted area door and one in the restricted wing. |- !0.8.0.4 |Adjusted several hiding spots when they are blocked, moving and deleting props where necessary. |- ! rowspan="3" |0.8.0.6 |Ghosts and players can now move the large metal trays. |- |Coal now has new sounds when dropped or thrown. |- |Many assorted improvements to prop and map collision, as well as ghost pathing. |- !0.10.0 |Sunny Meadows Restricted is now categorized as a medium location |}

The video camera is a piece of electronic Starter Equipment used to detect Ghost Orbs and to record videos. ==Mechanics== When a video camera is , the flip screen will open automatically. The video camera can be used handheld with its built-in display or on a flat surface or a tripod. The video camera will automatically start streaming its video feed to the computer when held outside the truck or placed. Holding the placement key will show a translucent preview of the video camera and its facing direction, which can be adjusted while holding the placement key by moving the mouse left and right. Be aware that even though certain spots are shown as valid, the camera may tip over or fall due to the geometry or other objects placed on the surface. When the ghost manifests during a ghost event or a hunt, it will cause interference on all nearby video cameras and distort the image on both the built-in display and the video feed. Cameras of higher Tier with a better image quality will be significantly less impacted by ghost interference, aiding players in observing or tracking the ghost during a ghost event or a hunt. Ghosts may occasionally knock over placed down video cameras within a certain range, forcing players to actively tend to them. Placing a camera on a tripod will reduce the probability of the ghost knocking it over. The stability provided by the tripod will depend on its Tier. Night vision can be while holding the active video camera or via the computer keyboard. When night vision is turned on, any Ghost Orbs present can be seen through the video camera. Holding the button while holding the active video camera will start a video recording. If a valid subject is captured, it will be recorded in the Media tab in the journal. Video recording can also be started from the computer in the truck by clicking on the Rec button. ==Tips== *The video camera's night vision function can be very useful when using a D.O.T.S Projector as the ghost's silhouette may be easier to see with night vision. *The video camera can also be used to maintain surveillance on areas such as hallways, rooms, and the fuse box. This can allow for easy viewing of certain stationary evidence like Fingerprints, Ghost Writing, EMF Level 5, salt, or D.O.T.S Projector. However, the video feed becomes extremely distorted whenever the ghost manifests during a Ghost Event or a hunt, making observation very difficult. **Note that if the camera isn't positioned properly and/or is of a lower tier which has worse quality, it can be difficult to spot Ghost Writing and read EMF Level 5 off the EMF Reader; Players should still go in personally and check evidence every now and then to prevent missing any. *It is recommended to turn your flashlight (and room lights) off while using night vision to check for Ghost Orbs, as it makes the camera feed extremely bright, making it nearly impossible to see through the camera to spot any Orbs. ==Gallery== File:Ghost Orbs on the Go.jpg|A Tier II video camera being used handheld. File:Video Camera On Tripod New.jpg|A video camera on a tripod File:Video-camera-knocked-down_0.9.1.0.gif|A video camera being knocked down ==Trivia== *The real-life video camera models are: **Tier I: Sony DCR-TRV260 camcorder (Sony rebranded to Bony) **Tier II: Panasonic HC-VX1K camcorder (Panasonic rebranded to Parasonic) **Tier III: Sony Venice Digital Cinema Camera (Sony rebranded to Bony) *A video camera can be turned on in the truck if it is placed on a tripod that is not hanging on the wall. This is likely a bug. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !22 March 2020 |Video cameras are now a starter item. |- ! 2 April 2020 |Video cameras can now be rotated on non-VR. |- !3 April 2020 |A video camera preview is now shown when aiming at a tripod. |- !6 April 2020 |The hand now shows when holding a video camera. |- !14 May 2020 |Improved video camera rotation when held in VR. |- !15 August 2020
(Part 3) |Reduced the placement range of video cameras from 3 metres to 1.6 metres. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- ! rowspan="2" |0.3.0 |Changed the video camera model. |- |Video feed is now displayed on the video camera. |- !0.9.0 |The Video Camera now has 3 tiers. |- !0.13.0 |The Video Camera can now record video evidence. |}

content: The Site Activity Monitor is the fourth monitor on the wall of the Truck, which shows the current activity ranging from 0 to 10, roughly matching the readings of an EMF Reader. A low reading may indicate little to no recent activity, while a high reading may mean high levels of ghost activity. On Nightmare and Insanity difficulties, the Site Activity Monitor is damaged and gives random readings, causing it to be useless and preventing players from discerning ghost activity by using it. == Mechanics == The Site Activity Monitor shows an aggregate of all EMF spots ("strength") in the map over the last 60 seconds. The current strength is read at t = 0. For each interaction that results in an EMF reading, the level of activity shown on the monitor will increase by that corresponding level of EMF, plus an additional integer modifier between -2 and 0 per interaction. * For example, a single EMF Level 3 interaction that occurred 30 seconds ago, modified by -1 on the monitor, will show up as a horizontal line of strength 2 between 11 - 30 seconds. Higher levels usually indicate that more interactions or certain high-level activities recently took place. During a hunt, the activity level will always be 10. However, having an activity level of 10 does not necessarily indicate that a hunt is ongoing or is about to occur; the ghost could have manifested, or simply interacted with multiple objects at once or in quick succession. Though the Site Activity Monitor only goes up to 10, the actual total amount of EMF at any one time may exceed 10. Similarly, an activity level of 0 usually, but does not always mean no activity; the ghost could have performed an EMF 2 interaction that was adjusted to show as level 0 on the monitor. == Tips == Some observations from the activity monitor could help in identification of the ghost. * A jump of 4 or 5 levels on the monitor may mean, among other things, that an EMF Level 5 interaction has occurred. * The Twins's ability involves two interactions almost at the same time; usually 1 second apart. Seeing a negative slope (left-to-right, may or may not be differentiable) stretching across 2 seconds (width of 1 box) could indicate, among other things, this ability being used. It is important to note that such observations are only potential indicators, and not foolproof; other events may also cause the same observations and therefore look like the above has happened. It may be appropriate to treat its usage as science; multiple observances of such indicators could more strongly suggest (but not confirm) the conclusions. Some "false positives" could include: * A ghost event can show an activity increase of anywhere from +2 to +10 (including +4/+5), depending on the fluctuation applied and whether the event caused nearby doors to close. * Similarly, the Poltergeist's multi-throw ability can show up as any amount of activity, depending on the number of items thrown. * Using various cursed possessions to perform a ghost event or interaction could, other than showing up as any activity level, also cause a gradient that looks like a double interaction. * When a hunt ends, the activity level will drop, which can look the same as an EMF 5 or a double interaction due to the ghost interacting during the hunt. == History == Category:Truck Equipment fr:Moniteur d'activité ru:Монитор активности zh:活动强度显示屏
title: Site Activity Monitor

6 Tanglewood Drive (or simply Tanglewood) is a small map in Phasmophobia. It is a small single-story home. Tanglewood can often make for a swift investigation due to its small size, but the open floor plan and only three accessible coat-closets can cause it to be very dangerous during a hunt. ==Structure== Tanglewood has three bedrooms (including a nursery), two toilets, a garage, and a basement, among other rooms. ===Layout tips=== *The "Master Bedroom" consists of the room of the bedroom itself, the attached bathroom, and the attached closet. *The "Foyer" consists of both the hallway starting from the front door until the closet at the end of the hall leading into the living room, and the hallway parallel to it connecting "Boy Bedroom", "Nursery", and "Main Bathroom". *A maximum of 9 light switches can be turned on at once before tripping the breaker. ===Key hiding spots and strategies=== There are 6 "sanctioned" hiding spots in Tanglewood: *Foyer, closet between nursery and bathroom *Foyer, closet next to living room *Boy Bedroom, closet across from bed *Nursery, behind the crib *Garage, lockers along far wall *Basement, behind upright plywood Depending on the difficulty, some of these hiding spots will be filled with bulky items or missing their concealing elements, preventing players from hiding in them: *Amateur: None *Intermediate: 2 *Professional: 3 *Nightmare/Insanity: 4 *3-player game: +1 available hiding spot *4-player game: +2 available hiding spots Additional hiding spots on multiplayer is overriden when "Number of hiding places" is set to None Another decent, but unofficial hiding spot is in the nursery. It is opposite of the crib hiding spot, behind the changing table. Looping the ghost may be performed around the kitchen island, dining table, or the car in the garage. Where needed, the player may hide at the rear of the car, or crouch behind the kitchen island. ==Bone locations== Bones spawn randomly, but will only spawn in areas that a ghost can also walk on. ;Examples

File:Tanglewood-Doll.png|The Voodoo Doll spawns on the trash can in the Garage. File:Monkeypaw tanglewood.jpg|The Monkey Paw spawns in a cabinet in the Dining Room. ==Tips== *One can use video cameras to look for Ghost Orbs in Boy Bedroom through the window before the player even enters. ==Trivia== *Tanglewood Street House was the first map to be created. *A potato easter egg can be found in one of the kitchen cabinets; this is a reference to the popular content creator PsychoHypnotic. *When turned on, before 0.9.0, the computer in Boy Bedroom used to show the name "Thomas Wilson"; this was a reference to a previously implemented feature where the players were required to find the name of the ghost by searching the building instead of having it given to them from the start. This was later scrapped as it was deemed too hard for players to do so on larger maps. The name "Nancy" above the baby crib in the Nursery is also a reference to this mechanic. *The assets used for this map can be found here. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !19 September 2020

content: The Yurei is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. Although it does not have any implicit bonuses to its ability to hunt, its main distinction is its ability to quickly drain sanity: if players are careless, it may become aggressive quicker than anticipated. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== When Incense is used on the Yurei, in addition to preventing hunts and temporarily increasing activity, it will return to its favourite room and be trapped within it for 90 seconds, stopping it from roaming through the location. It can still leave that room by performing a ghost event, but it will return to it once the event ends. If the Yurei is affected by incense during a hunt, it will only be trapped in its favourite room after the hunt ends for the remaining time of the cleansing effect. Outside of its ability, the Yurei doesn't have an increased chance to interact with doors. When interacting with a door, the Yurei cannot slightly move it and can only either close it completely, or open it completely. This doesn't apply to hunts. {| class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed fandom-table" !colspan="2"|Advanced mechanics |- !colspan="2"|WARNING: This data is based on testing and not officially verified. |- !D.O.T.S state |The Yurei cannot enter a D.O.T.S state while it is affected by an Incense's cleansing effect. |} ===Ability=== When choosing to use its ability, the Yurei will first check if its current room has an opened door. Doors that count for this ability are mostly room doors, as well as exit doors, large tent doors on campsites, Dining Room cabinet doors and Living Room/Games Room fireplace doors on Point Hope, and washing machine doors and Morgue doors on Sunny Meadows. Hiding spot doors, however, do not count. If the check is successful, the following is caused: *All players within 7.5 metres of the ghost will have their sanity decreased by 15%. Players outside the investigation area will not be affected by the sanity drain. *The ghost will randomly select one opened door in the room and close it fully in a smooth way (as opposed to a strong slam) without any creaking sound. This in turn produces an EMF 2 interaction on that door. **Large tent doors will not fully close. ==Evidence== ==Strengths and weaknesses== These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Yureis have been known to have a stronger effect on people's sanity. Weakness: Smudging the Yurei's place of death will trap it temporarily, reducing how much it wanders. ==Strategies == Keeping doors open at a 45° angle near the ghost will help one to observe how it interacts with doors. Outside of hunts, a ghost not opening or closing a door fully will immediately rule out the Yurei. Alternatively, if the ghost shuts a door fully in a smooth way without any creaking sound and without a ghost event or a hunt, then it is a Yurei. This must not be confused with a door strongly slamming or a door closing with a creaking sound, which all ghosts can do, including the Yurei. If the Yurei refrains from using its ability, one can look out for its weakness with Incense once its favourite room is found: use it on the ghost, then set up Motion Sensors at the room's doorways. If the ghost passes through the sensors and exits the room within 90 seconds of it being affected by the Incense, and without having performed a ghost event to do so, then it is not a Yurei. ==Trivia== *Yūrei (meaning "dim spirit" or "faint spirit") is a general term for ghosts or spirits in Japanese. Yūrei can be motivated by a wide range of emotions relating to their death (or last thought when dying) that can range from benevolent (caring for children, handing out sweets, etc.) to malevolent (getting revenge, making others suffer, etc.). Yūrei contain a range of sub categories of ghosts including Onryō and Goryō. The appearance of a Yūrei can vary just as much as its purpose, some are indistinguishable from normal people while others can resemble horrific monsters. *The Yurei, though regarded as having a "stronger effect on people's sanity", does not increase the passive sanity drain of players, nor does it have an increased drain from pseudo-line of sight like with the Phantom. Furthermore, the Jinn's ability to drain 25% sanity rather than the Yurei's meager 15% while the Jinn has other abilities ironically makes the Yurei weak when juxtaposed to other ghosts. *The Yurei's ability can drain sanity from dead players, making them having less sanity than before their death if they get revived. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access Alpha |- !5 August 2020 |Added Yurei. |- ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.2.11.0 |Added the Yurei's ability to drain sanity of nearby players. |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was Ghost Orb, Ghost Writing, and Freezing Temperatures. |- !0.5.0 |Doors near the Yurei will now close when it uses its sanity drain ability. |- !0.5.1.0 |Only one door will now close instead of multiple when the sanity drain ability is used. |- !0.6.2.0 |Players outside the investigation area will no longer be affected by the Yurei's sanity ability. |- !0.8.0 |The Yurei can no longer use its ability if it is in a room that does not have a door. |} ==References== ==Notes== ru:Юрэй fr:Yurei Category:Ghosts
title: Yurei

content: Yokai is a type of ghost in Phasmophobia. It is sensitive to voices, and becomes more aggressive while players are speaking nearby, which allows it to start a hunt even at high sanity levels. At the same time, while it is hunting, the radius in which it can hear players is much smaller compared to the other ghost types. ==Behaviour== ===Activity=== Utilizing voice chat near the Yokai at any sanity will increase its rate of activity. When a Music Box is used, the Yokai must be closer to the box (within 2.5 metres instead of 5) for it to trigger the ghost event and eventual cursed hunt. ===Hunt=== When at least one player uses voice chat in the same room as the Yokai, its hunt sanity threshold is temporarily increased to 80%. Otherwise, it has the standard threshold of 50%. During hunts, a Yokai can only hear players or sense handheld active electronics that are within 2.5 meters of it. Its line-of-sight is unaffected. ==Evidence== == Strengths and weaknesses == These are the strengths and weaknesses as listed in the journal: Strength: Talking near a Yokai will anger it, increasing the chance of an attack. Weakness: When hunting, a Yokai can only hear voices close to it. ==Strategies== The Yokai is identifiable through two distinctive traits: it will hunt more often when players are together and talking near it, but its ability to detect hidden players during a hunt through voice or electronics will be limited. For example, it will be less likely to follow the player past multiple line-of-sight breaks, and will not be attracted to held electronics unless the Yokai is already very close to the holder. Although its 80% hunt threshold is theoretically the highest in the game, even greater than that of the Demon (outside of its hunt ability) and the youngest Thaye, in practice, these extremely early hunts are rare. The Yokai does not have any additional buffs (and is in fact weaker) when hunting, so escaping it will be generally easier. To test for a Yokai during a hunt, stand at a distance close enough to where the ghost is currently at that is outside of the ghost's immediate line of sight, preferably near a hiding spot, and then turn on an electronic device and/or begin speaking in voice chat. If the ghost does not seek out the player making this noise, especially if it causes disruption of the device and then passes by instead of homing in, then it is likely a Yokai. Note that the electronic disruption range is a little bit greater than the actual range in which most ghosts will actually sense the held device. Care should be taken to not mistake the Yokai's limited hearing and electronics detection sense with the Banshee ignoring players other than its target (if they are inside the investigation area) during a hunt, especially on Nightmare as both these ghosts share two evidence. The Monkey Paw's wish to unblock a hiding spot will cause the ghost to be able to hear the speech and held electronics of the player who used it from any distance, overriding the Yokai's weakness. This may make trying to test a Yokai from its trait much more difficult, and when playing singleplayer, outright impossible. In multiplayer, the Yokai becomes mildly more dangerous, as there are more players that could be talking near the Yokai at any given moment, and thus can elevate its hunt sanity threshold more often. Where possible, less experienced players should ideally keep voice communications as short as possible until the ghost room is found. Otherwise, completing objectives can be made easier by encouraging the Yokai to hunt through talking. Contrary to popular opinion, the Yokai does not hunt more aggressively if players speak near it, only raising its hunt threshold; this means that talking near it has no effect if the team's average sanity is already below the 50% normal hunt threshold, so if the sanity levels are already low, then there's no need to avoid using voice chat anymore. The Sound Recorder's record range, especially for tiers II and III, actually outranges a Yokai's electronics detection range; by utilizing a suitable hiding spot, it is possible to record a hunting Yokai as it passes by, without it detecting the player, to easily get a high-reward piece of media. ==Trivia== * In Japanese Folklore, Yokai (妖怪, or "strange apparition") is a term broadly encompassing unexplained phenomenons, supernatural apparitions or spirits, which can take a wide variety of forms going from animals to inanimate objects. ==History== {| class="fandom-table" ! colspan="2" |Early Access |- !0.29.6 |Added Yokai. |- !0.3.0 |Prior to 0.3.0, the evidence was Spirit Box, Ghost Orb, and Ghost Writing. |- !0.5.0 |Talking near the Yokai will now increase its activity. |} ==References== ==Notes== ru:Ёкай fr:Yokai Category:Ghosts
